What m4 version are you using? I'm using > 1.4.2. I think most if not all problems steam from the underlying > problem that all the macros are not properly initialized. > > >>>>>> [root@elza php-gtk]# './configure' '--prefix=/usr/local/php5' >>>>>> '--exec-prefix=/usr/local/php5' '--disable-scrollpane' >>>>>> '--disable-spaned' '--disable-sqpane' '--disable-combobutton' >>>>>> '--disable-libglade' '--disable-piemenu' >>>>>> -bash: ./configure: Permission denied > > > I'm having this problem repeatadly too. > >>>>>> ./configure: line 2682: s/.*>//: No such file or directory > > > Also very wierd. Some expressions are not properly quoted/expanded or > something like that. > >>>>>> checking for gawk... (cached) gawk >>>>>> ./configure: line 3262: -e: command not found >>>>>> ./configure: line 3274: >>>>>> s#@ext_srcdir@#/compartilhado/downloads/php-gtk2/php-gtk#g: No >>>>>> such file >>>>>> or directory >>>>>> ./configure: line 3274: s#@ext_builddir@#.#g: command not found > > > Same as above. Looks really like one of the tools in the chain doesn't > work properly. > >>>>>> checking for GLIB - version >= 2.6.0... yes (version 2.6.4) >>>>>> ./configure: line 9127: s/[^a-zA-Z0-9]/_/g: No such file or directory > > > I'm getting wondering if the shell could be the problem? But I don't > think so. > > > Jani is the god when it comes to this stuff (cc'ed him). > > > Anyway, the current requirements for php-gtk2 are really very fragile at > the moment as I'm running in similiar problems every time I need to set > up a development environment (and try not to change it once it's running). > > good luck, > > - Markus

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GtkMenu and popups
email.body:
Hi Ivan,
> Hello, I trying to do a popup menu, and I view the gtkmenu methods and > popup() method don't exists, I read the GNOME documentation, > http://developer.gnome.org/doc/API/2.0/gtk/GtkMenu.html and here this > method exits but in PHP-GTK2 no, somebody knows why?¿
I assume it's because gpointer isn't supported yet.
Regards/MfG, Christian Weiske -- XMMS is playing now: Wonderwall - Princess without Jewels
["signature.asc" (application/pgp-signature)]

email.subject: RE: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GtkMenu and popups
email.body:
Is there any insight on when a possible alpha/beta release of php-gtk2 is due? 2 weeks, 1 month, 3-6 months, ..
-----Oorspronkelijk bericht----- Van: Christian Weiske [mailto:cweiske@cweiske.de] Verzonden: maandag 30 mei 2005 21:42 Aan: Ivan Rodriguez CC: php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net Onderwerp: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GtkMenu and popups
Hi Ivan,
> Hello, I trying to do a popup menu, and I view the gtkmenu methods and > popup() method don't exists, I read the GNOME documentation, > http://developer.gnome.org/doc/API/2.0/gtk/GtkMenu.html and here this > method exits but in PHP-GTK2 no, somebody knows why?¿
I assume it's because gpointer isn't supported yet.
Regards/MfG, Christian Weiske -- XMMS is playing now: Wonderwall - Princess without Jewels

email.body:
gtk+ or php-gtk specifically?
----- Original Message ----- From: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> To: "Davy Hellemans" <davy@enoa.be> Cc: <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Tuesday, May 31, 2005 5:56 PM Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GtkMenu and popups
It's hard to say, especially because I am now having problems with running gtk+ apps after upgrading my Mac to Tiger release of Mac OS X. It takes about 30 seconds to startup and the fonts look weird too.
-Andrei

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GtkMenu and popups
email.body:
This has nothing to do with Zend. It's some sort of issue with Darwin's runtime loader.
-Andrei

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GtkMenu and popups
email.body:
I also have been having slow downs with GTK apps on OSX Tiger. Mainly using the Gimp while opening and saving a image it takes 5-10 seconds and uses near 100% of CPU just for a read or write. So I don't think its a PHP-GTK problem more likely a GTK problem in the file reading and writing after something changed in Darwin would be my guess.
-Chris
Andrei Zmievski wrote:
> It's hard to say, especially because I am now having problems with > running gtk+ apps after upgrading my Mac to Tiger release of Mac OS > X. It takes about 30 seconds to startup and the fonts look weird too. > > -Andrei > > > On May 30, 2005, at 2:45 PM, Davy Hellemans wrote: > > >> Is there any insight on when a possible alpha/beta release of php- >> gtk2 is >> due? 2 weeks, 1 month, 3-6 months, .. >> >> -----Oorspronkelijk bericht----- >> Van: Christian Weiske [mailto:cweiske@cweiske.de] >> Verzonden: maandag 30 mei 2005 21:42 >> Aan: Ivan Rodriguez >> CC: php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net >> Onderwerp: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GtkMenu and popups >> >> Hi Ivan, >> >> >> >> >>> Hello, I trying to do a popup menu, and I view the gtkmenu methods and >>> popup() method don't exists, I read the GNOME documentation, >>> http://developer.gnome.org/doc/API/2.0/gtk/GtkMenu.html and here this >>> method exits but in PHP-GTK2 no, somebody knows why?¿ >>> >>> >> >> I assume it's because gpointer isn't supported yet. >> >> >> Regards/MfG, >> Christian Weiske >> -- >> XMMS is playing now: >> Wonderwall - Princess without Jewels >> >> -- >> PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) >> To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >> >> >> >
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Any testers?
email.body:
Yeah, these are known warnings and should be fixed by in PHP distribution.
On Tue, 01 Mar 2005, Christian Weiske wrote: > Hi Andrei, > > >Has anyone checked out the latest PHP-GTK code from CVS and played > >around with it? I need some feedback - bug reports, what to concentrate > >on next, etc. > > I've got some warnings with buildconf: > ===================== > cweiske:/data/cvs/phpgtk2/php-gtk> ./buildconf > configure.in:9: warning: underquoted definition of PHP_WITH_PHP_CONFIG > run info '(automake)Extending aclocal' > or see http://sources.redhat.com/automake/automake.html#Extending-aclocal > configure.in:32: warning: underquoted definition of PHP_EXT_BUILDDIR > configure.in:33: warning: underquoted definition of PHP_EXT_DIR > configure.in:34: warning: underquoted definition of PHP_EXT_SRCDIR > configure.in:35: warning: underquoted definition of PHP_ALWAYS_SHARED > acinclude.m4:19: warning: underquoted definition of PHP_PROG_RE2C > . > . > . > . > Configuring for: > PHP Api Version: 20020918 > Zend Module Api No: 20020429 > Zend Extension Api No: 20021010 > rebuilding configure > aclocal-1.9: `configure.ac' and `configure.in' both present. > aclocal-1.9: proceeding with `configure.ac'. > configure.ac:9: warning: underquoted definition of PHP_WITH_PHP_CONFIG > run info '(automake)Extending aclocal' > or see http://sources.redhat.com/automake/automake.html#Extending-aclocal > configure.ac:32: warning: underquoted definition of PHP_EXT_BUILDDIR > configure.ac:33: warning: underquoted definition of PHP_EXT_DIR > configure.ac:34: warning: underquoted definition of PHP_EXT_SRCDIR > configure.ac:35: warning: underquoted definition of PHP_ALWAYS_SHARED > configure.ac:208: warning: underquoted definition of PHP_PATH_GDK_PIXBUF > configure.ac:419: warning: underquoted definition of PHP_PATH_GNOME_CONFIG > configure.ac:507: warning: underquoted definition of PHP_PATH_LIBGLADE > acinclude.m4:19: warning: underquoted definition of PHP_PROG_RE2C > ======================== > but that might by a problem on my system as there is a bunch (100+ > lines) of other files with the same problem which follow the output above. > > > > > Regards/MfG, > Christian Weiske > -- > XMMS is playing now: > Groove Coverage - bis mac
- Andrei
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Any testers?
email.body:
On Tue, 01 Mar 2005, Christian Weiske wrote: > Why is the library called php-gtk.so and not php-gtk2.so? > My old php-gtk programs silently fail now instead of giving me a > "php-gtk.so not found".
Yeah, you're right. I'll fix this.
- Andrei

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Any testers?
email.body:
Andrei Zmievski wrote:
> Has anyone checked out the latest PHP-GTK code from CVS and played > around with it? I need some feedback - bug reports, what to concentrate > on next, etc.
Hi Andrei,
I compiled yesterday with the latest CVS version with no problems. I did run into a problem when I tried writing some code that used connect(). Any script that had a call to connect() in it failed with an error about phpg_closure_new. Of course, I didn't capture the exact message because that would have made life too easy. Sorry about that.
Thanks, Scott Mattocks
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

I try to compile with the branch PHP_GTK_1 and when i run configure error ocurred, php-4.3.x need, why this? or what is the branch of PHP-GTK2?¿ I download with:
cvs -d :pserver:cvsread@cvs.php.net:/repository co -r PHP_GTK_1 php-gtk
I don´t know if is the correct form ...

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Any testers?
email.body:
Ivan Rodriguez wrote: > I try to compile with the branch PHP_GTK_1 and when i run configure > error ocurred, php-4.3.x need, why this? or what is the branch of > PHP-GTK2?¿ I download with:
For PHP_GTK_1 you need at least PHP 4. You can't use PHP 5. If you want to checkout PHP-GTK 2 use cvs -d :pserver:cvsread@cvs.php.net:/repository co php-gtk
-- Scott Mattocks scott@crisscott.com http://www.crisscott.com http://pear.php.net/user/scottmattocks
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Any testers?
email.body:
On Wed, 02 Mar 2005, Scott Mattocks wrote: > Hi Andrei, > > I compiled yesterday with the latest CVS version with no problems. I did > run into a problem when I tried writing some code that used connect(). > Any script that had a call to connect() in it failed with an error about > phpg_closure_new. Of course, I didn't capture the exact message because > that would have made life too easy. Sorry about that.
Did you run buildconf after checking out new code? Since phpg_closure.c file is added to php_gtk.m4 you need rerun buildconf, or run aclocal manually and then autoconf again.
- Andrei

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Weird build problem
email.body:
I just made a fresh checkout, and found I'm getting link failures over a missing gtkwidget_ce when I build ext/libglade.
This would be less weird if my previous checkout had had the same problem. A full diff -u of that old, working checkout against CVS doesn't explain it; it only has the treemodel bits and pieces and Tom's extension in it.
It _should_ be something to do with Andrei's fixes over the circular dependency, except that I took those on board at the time.
Any clues, anyone?
- Steph
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: A bit of a makefile.frag situation...
email.body:
On Wed, 12 Oct 2005, Steph wrote:
> Is there a way to check for files during make and delay further processing > until they're all generated?
Yes, you put such files as dependancy for the other file's build rule.
> The *nix build system, on the other hand, generates the 8 base gen_* files > from ext/gtk+/Makefile.frag, and then compiles them during > ext/gtk+/config.m4. This approach caused a problem in the *nix build when > gen_gtk.c included gen_gtk.h before it existed. Andrei addressed that > problem by not including the gen_*.h files at all. This is fine for > building PHP-GTK 2 itself, on either system, but of course the library > produced in this way no longer contains PHP-GTK 2 exports. (The gen_*.h > files consist solely of PHP_GTK_API extern PHP_GTK_EXPORT_CE() > declarations). That means we can't build PHP-GTK 2 extensions any more, on > either system.
Tell me how to reproduce the problem and I might be able to fix it too. (this explanation does not make any sense to me)
--Jani
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.body:
Sorry I didn't get anything up last month. The news that I collected for September has turned into October news. Here is what I have: Christian Weiske has written an article for PHP Magazin titled "Rapit Application Development Mit PHP-GTK" which discusses creating applications using PHP-GTK and Glade.

An unofficial pre-release of PHP-GTK 2 for Windows can be found at http://ftp.emini.dk/pub/php/win32/gtk2/. If you are interested in helping test this release, please send your comments to the . email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GtkListStore->insert()
email.body:
Hi Andrei,
I know that you are trying to stick with the Gtk api but I noticed that GtkListStore::apend()/prepend() have been overwritten to return a GtkTreeIter instead of using the by reference assignment style. Is there any reason insert() and friends were not overwritten? Should this be added to the TODO2 file?
Thanks, Scott

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Defeated
Re[2]: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Defeated
email.body:
Hi Steph,
Thursday, October 20, 2005, 10:47:26 PM, you wrote: S> Forget it, I played with the script I have here & the original function and S> it works now (in as much as it reaches the marshal). I'm trying to figure S> out wtf I was doing before to prevent it...
The way glade seems to work is you ask it for the widget that has a connect name of for example 'on_open1_activate' it then calls your marshal function and gives it a chance to do the real connect,
If you use the glade_xml_signal_autoconnect it repeatedly calls your marshal function for each widget that has a signal name in it. Perhaps you should change the name to glade_signal_connect instead of glade_signal_marshal ???
Anyway here is my test script and glade file:
<?php function on_open1_activate(){ echo "Button Pressed\n"; } $glade = new GladeXML("gladetest\\gladetest.glade"); $window = $glade->get_widget('window1'); // returns the widget named $menu1 = $glade->get_widget('menu1'); $items = $menu1->children();
print $window->get_name()."\n"; // returns widget's name via GTK+ print glade::get_widget_name($window->child)."\n"; // returns widget's name via libglade
var_dump(glade::get_widget_tree($window)); // returns current GladeXML object print $glade->relative_file($glade->filename)."\n"; // returns relative path (and given filename) $list = $glade->get_widget_prefix("button"); // returns every widget having the given id prefix foreach($list as $item) { print $item->get_name()."\n"; }
$window->connect_simple('destroy', array('gtk', 'main_quit')); // works as advertised $glade->signal_connect('on_open1_activate','on_open1_activate'); // untested, probably won't work
gtk::main(); ?>

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] First release?
email.body:
I haven't posted bug files about these yet but:
1) GtkTextTag attributes are not accessible. Also there is no method to set an attribute. This means that tags are basically useless. I could just be missing something though. If anyone knows how to use text tags in PHP-GTK 2 please let me know.
2) GtkCellRenderer attributes are not accessible. Also there is no GtkCellRenderer method to set an attribute. For example, I want to be able to change the background color of a cell if the value is zero. To do this I need to use GtkTreeViewColumn::set_cell_data_func. In the callback, the cellrenderer attribute for background should be set if the value equals zero. There is no way to set this attribute. Again, I could be missing something. If anyone knows how to do this please let me know.
Scott
Christian Weiske wrote: > Hi > > Steph asked for outstanding issues on 2005-09-19. Some have been fixed > since then; are there any more which prevent a first release? >
-- Scott Mattocks scott@crisscott.com http://www.crisscott.com http://pear.php.net/user/scottmattocks
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Defeated
Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Defeated
email.body:
? My problem was not EVER reaching the callback marshal, which is why I didn't start working on it!!
I think perhaps it would be fairly useful to see a working PHP script at this point - the things you are saying here are alien, so it's possible I just don't know how to use the callback in Glade...
- Steph
----- Original Message ----- From: "Tom Rogers" <trogers@kwikin.com> To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net>; "Andrei" <andrei@gravitonic.com> Sent: Thursday, October 20, 2005 9:29 AM Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Defeated
> Hi Steph, > > Tuesday, October 18, 2005, 1:24:06 AM, you wrote: > S> I just spent some hours trying to get > S> glade_xml_signal_connect() working. I > S> knew it'd be a bit of a challenge, but it's more of an Everest than the > S> anticipated large Alp. > > S> Quite possibly I'm attacking it from the wrong direction anyway. I'd have > S> _liked_ to use phpg_signal_connect_impl(), but a) it isn't exporting nicely > S> when I force it (possibly that's a win32 thing?), and b) it's effectively > S> private to /main at present (deliberately so?). > > S> I ended up with g_signal_connect() and friends - convenience functions in > S> glib - but somehow the data isn't even getting far enough to prove me wrong > S> over that. It never reaches the marshal function (GladeXMLConnectFunc), and > S> I've been looking at it for so long now I'm absolutely out of ideas as to > S> why. > > S> glade_xml_signal_connect() is the difficult one of the generic GladeXML > S> signal methods, the others will fall into place almost as soon as this one's > S> working. > > S> Any heroes out there? > > S> - Steph > > S> ps my effort's attached as a unified diff > > This works for me as a basic test and will need more work :) > > static void glade_signal_marshal(const gchar *handler_name, GObject *obj, const gchar *signal_name, > const gchar *signal_data, GObject *connect_object, gboolean after, gpointer data) > { > phpg_cb_data_t *cbd = (phpg_cb_data_t *)data; > char *callback_name; > guint signal_id, handler_id; > GQuark detail = 0; > GClosure *closure = NULL; > TSRMLS_FETCH(); > > fprintf(stdout, "DEBUG: reached the marshal function %s : %s\n",handler_name,signal_name); // I never get this far - why? > > if (!zend_is_callable(cbd->callback, 0, &callback_name)) { > php_error(E_WARNING, "unable to call GladeXML callback '%s' specified in %s on line %ld", > callback_name, cbd->src_filename, cbd->src_lineno); > efree(callback_name); > return; > } > > /* If we ever reach here, this is where cbd->user_args should be checked... */ > if (!g_signal_parse_name(signal_name, G_OBJECT_TYPE(obj), &signal_id, &detail, TRUE)) { > php_error(E_WARNING, "%s(): unknown signal name '%s'", get_active_function_name(TSRMLS_C), signal_name); > return; > } > > closure = phpg_closure_new(cbd->callback, cbd->user_args, PHPG_CONNECT_NORMAL TSRMLS_CC); > handler_id = g_signal_connect_closure_by_id(obj, signal_id, detail, closure, after); > > efree(callback_name); > } > > static PHP_METHOD(GladeXML, signal_connect) > { > char *signal = NULL; > zval *callback = NULL, *extra = NULL; > zend_bool free_signal; > phpg_cb_data_t *data; > > NOT_STATIC_METHOD(); > > if (!php_gtk_parse_varargs(ZEND_NUM_ARGS(), 2, &extra, "uV", &signal, &free_signal, &callback)) > return; > > zval_add_ref(&callback); > data = phpg_cb_data_new(callback, extra TSRMLS_CC); > > fprintf(stdout, "signal name is %s on line 175\n", signal); > > glade_xml_signal_connect_full(GLADE_XML(PHPG_GOBJECT(this_ptr)), signal, > (GladeXMLConnectFunc)glade_signal_marshal, data); > > if (free_signal) g_free(signal); > > RETURN_NULL(); > } > > > The function name in the xml file was > > <child> > <widget class="GtkImageMenuItem" id="open1"> > <property name="visible">True</property> > <property name="label">gtk-open</property> > <property name="use_stock">True</property> > <signal name="activate" handler="on_open1_activate" last_modification_time="Tue, 18 Oct 2005 00:12:42 GMT"/> > </widget> > </child> > > so my php function call was: > > $glade->signal_connect('on_open1_activate','on_open1_activate'); > > my call back function I also called 'on_open1_activate' > > Hope this helps a bit > > -- > regards, > Tom >
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GtkListStore->insert()
email.body:
As a follow up to my earlier message, I have made an attempt to make GtkListStore::insert work like append and prepend. I don't really know what I am doing but this worked for me. Please let me know if I am wasting my time because a) you don't want to override these methods or b) this is the saddest piece of code you have ever seen. If this patch is helpful I will try to override insert_after and insert_before.
Thanks, Scott
["gtkliststore_insert_diff.txt" (text/plain)]
Index: ext/gtk+/gtktreeview.overrides =================================================================== RCS file: /repository/php-gtk/ext/gtk+/gtktreeview.overrides,v retrieving revision 1.18 diff -u -r1.18 gtktreeview.overrides --- ext/gtk+/gtktreeview.overrides 11 Oct 2005 12:38:15 -0000 1.18 +++ ext/gtk+/gtktreeview.overrides 12 Oct 2005 23:13:03 -0000 @@ -161,6 +161,61 @@ }
%% +add-arginfo GtkListStore insert +static +ZEND_BEGIN_ARG_INFO_EX(ARGINFO_NAME, 0, 0, 0) + ZEND_ARG_INFO(0, position) +ZEND_END_ARG_INFO(); + +%% +override gtk_list_store_insert +PHP_METHOD +{ + /* Set up stuff that is beyond my understanding.*/ + /* There is some sort of triple pointer I think.*/ + GtkTreeIter iter; + zval ***items; + gint position; + + /* Get the number of arguments passed to the method.*/ + int argc = ZEND_NUM_ARGS(); + + /* This method may not be called statically.*/ + NOT_STATIC_METHOD(); + + /* Check the number of arguments given. It must be one.*/ + if (argc != 1) { + php_error(E_WARNING, "%s::%s() requires exactly 1 argument, %d given", + get_active_class_name(NULL TSRMLS_CC), get_active_function_name(TSRMLS_C), argc); + return; + } + + /* Get the arguments passed in. (Argument really)*/ + items = php_gtk_func_args(argc); + + /* It's been way too long. I really don't remember what this does.*/ + zval *zposition = *items[0]; + /* Call some function to get the value from a pointer?*/ + position = Z_LVAL_P(zposition); + + /* Check for a negative position. If we don't we get a nasty Gtk+ */ + /* error message. */ + if (position < 0) { + php_error(E_WARNING, "%s::%s() requires argument 1 to be greater than zero, %d given", + get_active_class_name(NULL TSRMLS_CC), get_active_function_name(TSRMLS_C), position); + return; + } + + /* Now we should have the data we need.*/ + /* Call the actual Gtk+ function.*/ + gtk_list_store_insert(GTK_LIST_STORE(PHPG_GOBJECT(this_ptr)), &iter, position); + + /* I am guessing that this sets the return value to the iter*/ + /* that was just assigned.*/ + phpg_gboxed_new(&return_value, GTK_TYPE_TREE_ITER, &iter, TRUE, TRUE TSRMLS_CC); +} + +%% add-arginfo GtkListStore set static ZEND_BEGIN_ARG_INFO(ARGINFO_NAME, 0)
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

-Andrei

It must be one.*/ > + if (argc != 1) { > + php_error(E_WARNING, "%s::%s() requires exactly 1 > argument, %d given", > + get_active_class_name(NULL TSRMLS_CC), > get_active_function_name(TSRMLS_C), argc); > + return; > + } > + > + /* Get the arguments passed in. If we don't we get a nasty > Gtk+ */ > + /* error message. */ > + if (position < 0) { > + php_error(E_WARNING, "%s::%s() requires argument 1 to be > greater than zero, %d given", > + get_active_class_name(NULL TSRMLS_CC), > get_active_function_name(TSRMLS_C), position); > + return; > + } > + > + /* Now we should have the data we need.*/ > + /* Call the actual Gtk+ function.*/ > + gtk_list_store_insert(GTK_LIST_STORE(PHPG_GOBJECT(this_ptr)), > &iter, position); > + > + /* I am guessing that this sets the return value to the iter*/ > + /* that was just assigned.*/ > + phpg_gboxed_new(&return_value, GTK_TYPE_TREE_ITER, &iter, > TRUE, TRUE TSRMLS_CC); > +} > + > +%% > add-arginfo GtkListStore set > static > ZEND_BEGIN_ARG_INFO(ARGINFO_NAME, 0) > > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GtkListStore->insert()
email.body:
I ended up taking your patch and expanding it. Should be in CVS now, let me know if it works for you. It actually does a little more than
GtkListStore::insert(position, array items = null)
If you pass items parameter, it will insert a new row and fill it out with the values from the array. This is more efficient than calling simple insert() and then set() due to this note:
http://developer.gnome.org/doc/API/2.0/gtk/GtkListStore.html#gtk-list- store-insert-with-values
-Andrei
On Oct 12, 2005, at 9:54 PM, Andrei Zmievski wrote:
> Scott, > > Good try, but it needs some more work. You may want to take a look > at the PyGTK implementation of the same in gtktreeview.override file > > _wrap_gtk_list_store_insert(PyGObject *self, PyObject *args, > PyObject *kwargs) > > -Andrei > >
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GtkListStore->insert()
email.body:
Hi Andrei,
Andrei Zmievski wrote: > I ended up taking your patch and expanding it. Should be in CVS now, > let me know if it works for you. It actually does a little more than > > GtkListStore::insert(position, array items = null)
I am running into some strange problems using insert with an array. Sometimes it gives me warning about things being initialized to NULL already. I added bug_gtkliststore_insert_with_array.php to the test file. It has more details and you should be able to reproduce the bug with that script.
Also, I copied the override for GtkListStore::append and changed the method name and Gtk function to prepend. The attached patch is your code with two words changed.
Thanks, Scott
["patch_gtkliststore_prepend.txt" (text/plain)]
--- gtktreeview.overrides 2005-10-14 12:48:41.566336864 -0400 +++ gtktreeview.overrides.prepend 2005-10-13 23:00:19.000000000 -0400 @@ -161,6 +161,26 @@ }
%% +override gtk_list_store_prepend +PHP_METHOD +{ + GtkTreeIter iter; + zval *items = NULL; + + NOT_STATIC_METHOD(); + + if (!php_gtk_parse_args(ZEND_NUM_ARGS(), "|a", &items)) + return; + + gtk_list_store_prepend(GTK_LIST_STORE(PHPG_GOBJECT(this_ptr)), &iter); + + if (items && phpg_model_set_row(GTK_TREE_MODEL(PHPG_GOBJECT(this_ptr)), &iter, items) == FAILURE) + return; + + phpg_gboxed_new(&return_value, GTK_TYPE_TREE_ITER, &iter, TRUE, TRUE TSRMLS_CC); +} + +%% override gtk_list_store_insert PHP_METHOD {
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Correct PEAR package.xml php-gtk dependency tag?
email.body:
Hi
Does somebody know what the correct dependency tag for php-gtk and php-gtk2 are? It's just the problem that I want to make sure that php-gtk or php-gtk2 are installed when a certain PEAR package is installed. All current Gtk_* packages have no php-gtk dependency, which isn't that good.
-- Regards/MfG, Christian Weiske
["signature.asc" (application/pgp-signature)]

package.xml v1: <dep type="pkg" rel="has">Foo</dep>
package.xml v2: <dependencies> <package> <name>System_Command</name> <channel>pear.php.net</channel> <min>1.0.2</min> </package> </required> </dependencies>

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Connection methods
email.body:
So, the official connect' methods will be:
connect and connect_after (passing the object as first param) connect_simple and connect_simple_after (do not passing)
is it right ?
best regards Pablo
On Qui, 2005-10-13 at 21:05 -0700, Andrei Zmievski wrote: > I've implemented the new connection method connect_simple() and > deprecated connect_object(), which will still work but issue a > notice. Now, do we really need connect_replace()? This is the method > that will replace the signal widget parameter with a user supplied > one, e.g.: > > $drawing_area->connect_replace('button_press_event', 'replace', > $window, array(1,2)); > > function replace($myparam, $event, $userarg) > { > /* $myparam is $window and $userarg is array(1,2) */ > } > > Is this useful at all? > > -Andrei > -- :: Pablo Dall'Oglio :: www.solis.coop.br - Lajeado, RS - Brasil :: www.dalloglio.net - Personal Home Page :: The software is free, but the work isn't.

This is the method > that will replace the signal widget parameter with a user supplied > one, e.g.: > > $drawing_area->connect_replace('button_press_event', 'replace', > $window, array(1,2)); > > function replace($myparam, $event, $userarg) > { > /* $myparam is $window and $userarg is array(1,2) */ > } > > Is this useful at all? > > -Andrei > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >

connect_simple() does not pass any parameters other than the user ones. Does that answer your question?
-Andrei

> It depends on whether connect_simple() allows user args in the way that > connect_object() did... assuming it does, this would seem to be over > the > top. > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> > To: "PHP DEV" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> > Sent: Friday, October 14, 2005 5:05 AM > Subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Connection methods > > >> I've implemented the new connection method connect_simple() and >> deprecated connect_object(), which will still work but issue a >> notice. Now, do we really need connect_replace()? This is the method >> that will replace the signal widget parameter with a user supplied >> one, e.g.: >> >> $drawing_area->connect_replace('button_press_event', 'replace', >> $window, array(1,2)); >> >> function replace($myparam, $event, $userarg) >> { >> /* $myparam is $window and $userarg is array(1,2) */ >> } >> >> Is this useful at all? >> >> -Andrei >> >> -- >> PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) >> To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >>
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.body:
Yes, unless we need connect_replace().

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Connection methods
email.body:
I think this is how things did/would work:
The callback for connect called on a button might have looked like this:
$button->connect('clicked', 'buttonClicked'); function buttonClicked($widget) {}
The callback for connect_object called on button a might have looked like this:
$button->connect_object('clicked', 'buttonClicked'); function buttonClicked() {}
The callback for connect_replace called on button a might look like this:
$button->connect_replace('clicked', 'buttonClicked', $otherButton); function buttonClicked($otherWidget) {}
Scott

> No, it's probably me that's confused :) I'm not good when it comes to > discussing things theoretically rather than in practical terms. > > So what are you saying, Andrei - connect_simple() will _only_ pass user > data, and connect_replace() will act as connect_object() did? > > If so we do need connect_replace().... > > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Scott Mattocks" <scott@crisscott.com> > To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> > Cc: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com>; "PHP DEV" > <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> > Sent: Friday, October 14, 2005 6:29 PM > Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Connection methods > > > >>I thought connect_object only leaves out the widget that fired the >>signal. email.body:
Yes, because if you want to do something with an object that isn't responsible for emitting the signal, it makes the code much more readable if you use connect_object() or something equivalent. Think about key-press-event signal and such.
We do need connect_replace() then...
Gone!

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Connection methods
email.body:
The one just about everyone uses is $window->connect_object('destroy', array('gtk', 'main_quit'));
It'd be confusing (and pointless) if you also passed $window, and it'd get needlessly complicated if you just used a straight connect() call.
You'd also use it anywhere you didn't want to pass the initial object but wanted to use one of its signals, and that does arise a fair deal. Sometimes you'll need the signal's parameters to be passed too, sometimes you won't. In event signals it's fairly common to want to do something with $event as well as with your user data (ie other widgets etc), but at present we don't have a way of passing $event without passing the initial object.
----- Original Message ----- From: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> Cc: "PHP DEV" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net>; "Scott Mattocks" <scott@crisscott.com> Sent: Friday, October 14, 2005 9:40 PM Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Connection methods
> Can you please an example of this? > > -Andrei > > On Oct 14, 2005, at 12:37 PM, Steph wrote: > > > Yes, because if you want to do something with an object that isn't > > responsible for emitting the signal, it makes the code much more > > readable if > > you use connect_object() or something equivalent. Think about > > key-press-event signal and such. > > > > We do need connect_replace() then... > > > > Gone! > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > From: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> > > To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> > > Cc: "PHP DEV" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net>; "Scott Mattocks" > > <scott@crisscott.com> > > Sent: Friday, October 14, 2005 8:29 PM > > Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Connection methods > > > > > >> No, connect_replace() would *not* act like connect_object(). It would > >> substitute user-specified object instead of the signal one, e.g.: > >> > >> $drawarea->connect_object('button_press_event', 'process_object', > >> $anotherarea); > >> > >> function process_object($event, $anotherarea) > >> { > >> /* note that $anotherarea is passed after event */ > >> } > >> > >> $drawarea->connect_replace('button_press_event', 'process_replace', > >> $anotherarea); > >> > >> function process_replace($anotherarea, $event) > >> { > >> /* note that $anotherarea is passed in place of the signal widget */ > >> } > >> > >> And also I'm curious, why do you need connect_object() or > >> connect_replace()? Any specific reason? > >> > >> -Andrei > >> > >> > >> On Oct 14, 2005, at 11:18 AM, Steph wrote: > >> > >>> No, it's probably me that's confused :) I'm not good when it comes > >>> to > >>> discussing things theoretically rather than in practical terms. > >>> > >>> So what are you saying, Andrei - connect_simple() will _only_ pass > >>> user > >>> data, and connect_replace() will act as connect_object() did? > >>> > >>> If so we do need connect_replace().... > >>> > >>> > >> >

email.subject: Fw: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Connection methods
email.body:
OK, now I've experimented you can forget my first paragraph earlier, you'd just use connect_simple() there because there aren't any signal parameter values you'd need to consider.
In GTK 2 tests the place connect_swapped() is most often used is:
g_signal_connect_swapped (button, "clicked", G_CALLBACK (gtk_widget_destroy), window);
which we can do without needing connect_swapped(), for the same reason.
I'm still wondering about what happens if you want to differentiate a right-click from a left-click in the callback, e.g. to bring up a context-driven popup menu? What if the callback was a flexible one that could be called from any of several widgets and/or in any of several ways?
We have workarounds for the event signals group, in the shape of gtk::get_current_event(), $event->type, and gtk::get_event_widget($event), so we don't necessarily need to pass $event as a signal parameter - but would these cater for every situation? What happens when, for example, row and column data are passed as signal parameters - are these _always_ the kind of signals that use connect()?
I agree we could do with some real-life examples, but I'm the last person to have any. Perhaps Pablo, Madeleine or Tom could argue more convincingly, or prove me wrong?
----- Original Message ----- From: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> To: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> Cc: "PHP DEV" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net>; "Scott Mattocks" <scott@crisscott.com> Sent: Sunday, October 16, 2005 1:58 PM Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Connection methods

Any specific reason? > > >> > > >> -Andrei > > >> > > >> > > >> On Oct 14, 2005, at 11:18 AM, Steph wrote: > > >> > > >>> No, it's probably me that's confused :) I'm not good when it comes > > >>> to > > >>> discussing things theoretically rather than in practical terms. > > >>> > > >>> So what are you saying, Andrei - connect_simple() will _only_ pass > > >>> user > > >>> data, and connect_replace() will act as connect_object() did? > > >>> > > >>> If so we do need connect_replace().... > > >>> > > >>> > > >> > > > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Connection methods
email.body:
On Oct 16, 2005, at 5:58 AM, Steph wrote:
> The one just about everyone uses is $window->connect_object('destroy', > array('gtk', 'main_quit'));
This is precisely what connect_simple() is for: it'll just invoke gtk::main_quit() without passing it anything.
> You'd also use it anywhere you didn't want to pass the initial > object but > wanted to use one of its signals, and that does arise a fair deal. > Sometimes you'll need the signal's parameters to be passed too, > sometimes > you won't. In event signals it's fairly common to want to do > something with > $event as well as with your user data (ie other widgets etc), but > at present > we don't have a way of passing $event without passing the initial > object.
But how will connect_replace() help you here? You will still need to pass an object, albeit not the one that emitted the signal, so the function signature will stay the same.
-Andrei
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GtkCellRendererCombo state
email.body:
Hi Ivan,
Objects and boxed types are declared in the 'types' files, e.g. gtk-types.defs.
- Steph

Now and other question, I want to implement but I don't know how to do this, I read some files like gtk.defs and gtk.overrides but i don't found anything of gtkcellrenderpixbuf or other gtkcellrenderer* widgets, where is the code of this widgets?¿

I read the gtk-types.defs and here the CellRendererCombo code is defined:
(define-object CellRendererCombo (in-module "Gtk") (parent "GtkCellRendererText") (c-name "GtkCellRendererCombo") (gtype-id "GTK_TYPE_CELL_RENDERER_COMBO") )

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: A bit of a makefile.frag situation...
email.body:
> > Is there a way to check for files during make and delay further processing > > until they're all generated? > > Yes, you put such files as dependancy for the other file's build rule.
That sounds a likely winner...
> > The *nix build system, on the other hand, generates the 8 base gen_* files > > from ext/gtk+/Makefile.frag, and then compiles them during > > ext/gtk+/config.m4. This approach caused a problem in the *nix build when > > gen_gtk.c included gen_gtk.h before it existed. Andrei addressed that > > problem by not including the gen_*.h files at all. This is fine for > > building PHP-GTK 2 itself, on either system, but of course the library > > produced in this way no longer contains PHP-GTK 2 exports. (The gen_*.h > > files consist solely of PHP_GTK_API extern PHP_GTK_EXPORT_CE() > > declarations). That means we can't build PHP-GTK 2 extensions any more, on > > either system. > > Tell me how to reproduce the problem and I might be able to fix it too. > (this explanation does not make any sense to me)
You'd need to be able to build a php-gtk extension, and I don't know if that's even possible on *nix at present. ext/libglade's in public CVS if you want to try.
Basically we need to be able to add the line #include "php_gtk_api.h" to gtk.overrides without breaking the *nix build of PHP-GTK itself (which might even be OK on your system in the first place, but isn't for everyone).
Where there's the line
PHP_GTK_EXTENSION([gtk+], no, [php_gtk+.c], [gen_atk.c gen_pango.c gen_gdk.c gen_gtk.c php_gtk+_types.c])
at the end of ext/gtk+/config.m4, there needs to be some kind of dependancy check for the gen_*.c files to ensure that their gen_*.h equivalent actually exists before the gen_*.c file is compiled. Although TBH it seems gen_gtk.c is the only one really causing problems, it'd be better to err on the side of caution.
Thanks Jani,
- Steph
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: A bit of a makefile.frag situation...
email.body:
On Wed, 12 Oct 2005, Steph wrote:
> Where there's the line > > PHP_GTK_EXTENSION([gtk+], no, [php_gtk+.c], [gen_atk.c gen_pango.c gen_gdk.c > gen_gtk.c php_gtk+_types.c]) > > at the end of ext/gtk+/config.m4, there needs to be some kind of dependancy > check for the gen_*.c files to ensure that their gen_*.h equivalent actually > exists before the gen_*.c file is compiled. Although TBH it seems gen_gtk.c > is the only one really causing problems, it'd be better to err on the side > of caution.
Dependancy in config.m4?? No, you need to make sure the config.m4's are included in right order. That's accomplished by putting the number in place of X in "configX.m4" if they're not in right order "alphabetically" already.
--Jani
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: A bit of a makefile.frag situation...
email.body:
On Oct 12, 2005, at 10:56 AM, Steph wrote: > You'd need to be able to build a php-gtk extension, and I don't > know if > that's even possible on *nix at present. ext/libglade's in public > CVS if > you want to try.
Bah, of course it's possible. I just did it.
> Basically we need to be able to add the line #include > "php_gtk_api.h" to > gtk.overrides without breaking the *nix build of PHP-GTK itself > (which might > even be OK on your system in the first place, but isn't for everyone).
Why do we need that line there? gtk.overrides already includes these:
#include "gen_atk.h" #include "gen_gdk.h" #include "gen_pango.h"
And they are generated in that exact order, so no problems there.
-Andrei
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: A bit of a makefile.frag situation...
email.body:
Jani,
She's not talking about m4 stuff. What she wants, is for all of the gen_*.c files to be generated first, and only then should they be compiled. Right now gen_atk.c is generated and compiled right away, then gen_pango.c, then gen_gdk.c, and so on. It might be an issue if gen_atk.c needs to include gen_gtk.h, for example, which it doesn't right now, but could potentially.
So, can we have a rule that generates the gen_* files all together first?
-Andrei
On Oct 12, 2005, at 11:01 AM, Jani Taskinen wrote:
> On Wed, 12 Oct 2005, Steph wrote: > > >> Where there's the line >> >> PHP_GTK_EXTENSION([gtk+], no, [php_gtk+.c], [gen_atk.c gen_pango.c >> gen_gdk.c >> gen_gtk.c php_gtk+_types.c]) >> >> at the end of ext/gtk+/config.m4, there needs to be some kind of >> dependancy >> check for the gen_*.c files to ensure that their gen_*.h >> equivalent actually >> exists before the gen_*.c file is compiled. Although TBH it seems >> gen_gtk.c >> is the only one really causing problems, it'd be better to err on >> the side >> of caution. >> > > Dependancy in config.m4?? No, you need to make sure the > config.m4's are > included in right order. That's accomplished by putting the > number in place > of X in "configX.m4" if they're not in right order > "alphabetically" already. > > --Jani >
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: A bit of a makefile.frag situation...
email.body:
Ah. The gen_*.h files are generated FROM the gen_*.c files, in ext/gtk+/Makefile.frag, which is called from php-gtk.config.m4, which is called from build2/build2.mk, which is called from build2/build.mk, which is called from ./buildconf.
As far as I can figure out, anyway.
The problem comes when the generation of the header files isn't complete before the next stage... and the four header and four source files are all generated in the same script, which is ext/gtk+/Makefile.frag. The C files seem to be already generated, but the H files are still only halfway complete by the time ext/gtk+/config.m4 tries to compile them. It's not the ordering of the config.m4 files that's the issue here, it's the time taken to generate those (large) files that causes the problem.
Is there no way to ensure that the files are completely generated before the Makefile.frag script ends?
----- Original Message ----- From: "Jani Taskinen" <sniper@iki.fi> To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> Cc: "Andrei" <andrei@gravitonic.com>; "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Wednesday, October 12, 2005 7:01 PM Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: A bit of a makefile.frag situation...

Although TBH it seems gen_gtk.c > > is the only one really causing problems, it'd be better to err on the side > > of caution. > > Dependancy in config.m4?? No, you need to make sure the config.m4's are > included in right order. That's accomplished by putting the number in place > of X in "configX.m4" if they're not in right order "alphabetically" already. > > --Jani >
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.body:
gen_gtk.h is no longer included from _anywhere_ in PHP-GTK source. That's why we're able to build PHP-GTK 2 but no extensions.

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: A bit of a makefile.frag situation...
email.body:
Steph, don't confuse configure and Makefile with each other. :)
a) ./cvsclean cleans the sources from all generated stuff (or should!) b) ./buildconf generates configure from all the config.m4's, including stuff like acinclude.m4, aclocal.m4, etc. c) ./configure generates Makefile from Makefile.global, all Makefile.frag files (sometimes conditionally included by some config.m4 file) and all the other Makefile.* files it first generates. d) "make" then uses the Makefile, it will not care about any config.m4 file.
--Jani
On Wed, 12 Oct 2005, Steph wrote:
> > Ah. The gen_*.h files are generated FROM the gen_*.c files, in > ext/gtk+/Makefile.frag, which is called from php-gtk.config.m4, which is > called from build2/build2.mk, which is called from build2/build.mk, which is > called from ./buildconf. > > As far as I can figure out, anyway. > > The problem comes when the generation of the header files isn't complete > before the next stage... and the four header and four source files are all > generated in the same script, which is ext/gtk+/Makefile.frag. The C files > seem to be already generated, but the H files are still only halfway > complete by the time ext/gtk+/config.m4 tries to compile them. It's not the > ordering of the config.m4 files that's the issue here, it's the time taken > to generate those (large) files that causes the problem. > > Is there no way to ensure that the files are completely generated before the > Makefile.frag script ends? > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Jani Taskinen" <sniper@iki.fi> > To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> > Cc: "Andrei" <andrei@gravitonic.com>; "PHP-GTK dev" > <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> > Sent: Wednesday, October 12, 2005 7:01 PM > Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: A bit of a makefile.frag situation... > > >> On Wed, 12 Oct 2005, Steph wrote: >> >>> Where there's the line >>> >>> PHP_GTK_EXTENSION([gtk+], no, [php_gtk+.c], [gen_atk.c gen_pango.c > gen_gdk.c >>> gen_gtk.c php_gtk+_types.c]) >>> >>> at the end of ext/gtk+/config.m4, there needs to be some kind of > dependancy >>> check for the gen_*.c files to ensure that their gen_*.h equivalent > actually >>> exists before the gen_*.c file is compiled. Although TBH it seems > gen_gtk.c >>> is the only one really causing problems, it'd be better to err on the > side >>> of caution. >> >> Dependancy in config.m4?? No, you need to make sure the config.m4's > are >> included in right order. That's accomplished by putting the number in > place >> of X in "configX.m4" if they're not in right order "alphabetically" > already. >> >> --Jani >> >
-- Give me your money at @ <http://pecl.php.net/wishlist.php/sniper> Donating money may make me happier and friendlier for a limited period! Death to all 4 letter abbreviations starting with P!

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Weird build problem
email.body:
I just checked out a fresh copy from CVS, configure it with:
'./configure' \ '--with-php-config=/usr/local/php5/bin/php-config' \ '--enable-debug'
And ran make. Everything worked beautifully. I was able to load the .so and execute a sample script.
So, what's wrong? Are you building ext/libglade as a separate extension or as part of php_gtk2.dll?
-Andrei
On Oct 11, 2005, at 4:19 AM, Steph wrote:
> I just made a fresh checkout, and found I'm getting link failures > over a > missing gtkwidget_ce when I build ext/libglade. > > This would be less weird if my previous checkout had had the same > problem. > A full diff -u of that old, working checkout against CVS doesn't > explain it; > it only has the treemodel bits and pieces and Tom's extension in it. > > It _should_ be something to do with Andrei's fixes over the circular > dependency, except that I took those on board at the time. > > Any clues, anyone? > > - Steph > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Weird build problem
email.body:
Andrei, the php-gtk2.lib does not contain exported symbols.
You can't build extensions against it.
----- Original Message ----- From: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Wednesday, October 12, 2005 7:02 PM Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Weird build problem
> I just checked out a fresh copy from CVS, configure it with: > > './configure' \ > '--with-php-config=/usr/local/php5/bin/php-config' \ > '--enable-debug' > > And ran make. Everything worked beautifully. I was able to load > the .so and execute a sample script. > > So, what's wrong? Are you building ext/libglade as a separate > extension or as part of php_gtk2.dll? > > > -Andrei > > > On Oct 11, 2005, at 4:19 AM, Steph wrote: > > > I just made a fresh checkout, and found I'm getting link failures > > over a > > missing gtkwidget_ce when I build ext/libglade. > > > > This would be less weird if my previous checkout had had the same > > problem. > > A full diff -u of that old, working checkout against CVS doesn't > > explain it; > > it only has the treemodel bits and pieces and Tom's extension in it. > > > > It _should_ be something to do with Andrei's fixes over the circular > > dependency, except that I took those on board at the time. > > > > Any clues, anyone? > > > > - Steph > > > > -- > > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > > >

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: A bit of a makefile.frag situation...
email.body:
Andrei, php_gtk_libglade.dll is built against php-gtk2.lib. php-gtk2.lib no longer contains the exported GTK classes. That is the problem. The .dll can't link against the library.
----- Original Message ----- From: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> Cc: "Jani Taskinen" <sniper@iki.fi>; "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Wednesday, October 12, 2005 7:54 PM Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: A bit of a makefile.frag situation...
> Sure it is. > > gen_libglade.c includes php_gtk_api.h which in turn includes gen_gtk.h. > > -Andrei > > > On Oct 12, 2005, at 11:33 AM, Steph wrote: > > > gen_gtk.h is no longer included from _anywhere_ in PHP-GTK source. > > That's > > why we're able to build PHP-GTK 2 but no extensions. > > > > > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > From: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> > > To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> > > Cc: "Jani Taskinen" <sniper@iki.fi>; "PHP-GTK dev" > > <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> > > Sent: Wednesday, October 12, 2005 7:05 PM > > Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: A bit of a makefile.frag situation... > > > > > > > >> On Oct 12, 2005, at 10:56 AM, Steph wrote: > >> > >>> You'd need to be able to build a php-gtk extension, and I don't > >>> know if > >>> that's even possible on *nix at present. ext/libglade's in public > >>> CVS if > >>> you want to try. > >>> > >> > >> Bah, of course it's possible. I just did it. > >> > >> > >>> Basically we need to be able to add the line #include > >>> "php_gtk_api.h" to > >>> gtk.overrides without breaking the *nix build of PHP-GTK itself > >>> (which might > >>> even be OK on your system in the first place, but isn't for > >>> everyone). > >>> > >> > >> Why do we need that line there? gtk.overrides already includes these: > >> > >> #include "gen_atk.h" > >> #include "gen_gdk.h" > >> #include "gen_pango.h" > >> > >> And they are generated in that exact order, so no problems there. > >> > >> -Andrei > > >
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GtkCellRendererCombo state
email.body:
Hi people
I search a little and I believe that to implement GtkCellRendererCombo gtk_tree_view_insert_column_with_attributes method of the GtkTreeView objec= t is necessary to implement, is this possible?
I found and example of GtkCellRendererCombo and use this method and gtktreeview.overrides don't have the method.
For example:
gtk_tree_view_insert_column_with_attributes (GTK_TREE_VIEW(list), -1, "Combo", renderer, "text", C_STRING, "text-column", C_TEXT_COLUMN, NULL);
If this is true I go to try to implement :-)

You'll have to look :) > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Ivan Rodriguez" <epplestun@gmail.com> > To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> > Cc: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com>; "PHP-GTK Dev" > <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> > Sent: Wednesday, October 12, 2005 7:24 PM > Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GtkCellRendererCombo state > > > Hi Steph > > I read the gtk-types.defs and here the CellRendererCombo code is defined: > > (define-object CellRendererCombo > (in-module "Gtk") > (parent "GtkCellRendererText") > (c-name "GtkCellRendererCombo") > (gtype-id "GTK_TYPE_CELL_RENDERER_COMBO") > ) > > The other widgets like GtkCellRendererProgress works fine because is > implemented, but if GtkCellRendererCombo is defined too why don't works?= =BF > The widget need overrides or something?=BF > > Thanks > > On 10/12/05, Steph <steph@zend.com> wrote: > > > > Hi Ivan, > > > > Objects and boxed types are declared in the 'types' files, e.g. > > gtk-types.defs. > > > > - Steph > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > From: "Ivan Rodriguez" <epplestun@gmail.com> > > To: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> > > Cc: "PHP-GTK Dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> > > Sent: Wednesday, October 12, 2005 6:40 PM > > Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GtkCellRendererCombo state > > > > > > Ok Andrei > > > > Now and other question, I want to implement but I don't know how to do > > this, > > I read some files like gtk.defs and gtk.overrides but i don't found > > anything > > of gtkcellrenderpixbuf or other gtkcellrenderer* widgets, where is the > > code > > of this widgets?=BF > > > > Thanks > > > > On 10/11/05, Andrei Zmievski <andrei@gravitonic.com> wrote: > > > > > > Not yet. > > > > > > -Andrei > > > > > > On Oct 11, 2005, at 4:27 AM, Ivan Rodriguez wrote: > > > > > > > Hi people > > > > > > > > What is the state of the GtkCellRendererCombo, it's implemented?=BF > > > > > > > > Thanks > > > > > > > > > > > >

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GtkUiManager overrides
email.body:
Hi Tom,
This doesn't build for me as-is. I needed to make the const-char* declarations const char* to allow it to build at all, and then cast the return value as (char *) in both those cases to make it build without complaining.
It works as advertised here following those minor changes. Cute ;)
- Steph

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Started on libglade and hit trouble
Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Connection methods
email.body:
Hello,
I think connect() and connect_simple() will be enough. I particullary just use connect_object() since php-gtk-0.0.1 came out, because almost 100% of the time you don't need the widget that fired the signal, and sometimes you need the event and other parameters it generates. But I liked the idea of the duo connect() and connect_simple() also. I guess the programmers will use most connect_simple() and sometimes they'll use connect() when the callback parameters are needed.
I would like we define these things soon in order to have a good start point for documentation and for application developments. Also I'm writing an article for Php Solutions Magazine to show some of the new features of PHP-GTK2 and I'll use connect() because I know this one won't change anymore ;-) ASAP I'll make it available under our site.
best regards Pablo
On Dom, 2005-10-16 at 12:46 -0700, Andrei Zmievski wrote: > On Oct 16, 2005, at 5:58 AM, Steph wrote: > > > The one just about everyone uses is $window->connect_object('destroy', > > array('gtk', 'main_quit')); > > This is precisely what connect_simple() is for: it'll just invoke > gtk::main_quit() without passing it anything. > > > > You'd also use it anywhere you didn't want to pass the initial > > object but > > wanted to use one of its signals, and that does arise a fair deal. > > Sometimes you'll need the signal's parameters to be passed too, > > sometimes > > you won't. In event signals it's fairly common to want to do > > something with > > $event as well as with your user data (ie other widgets etc), but > > at present > > we don't have a way of passing $event without passing the initial > > object. > > But how will connect_replace() help you here? You will still need to > pass an object, albeit not the one that emitted the signal, so the > function signature will stay the same. > > -Andrei > -- :: Pablo Dall'Oglio :: www.solis.coop.br - Lajeado, RS - Brasil :: www.dalloglio.net - Personal Home Page :: The software is free, but the work isn't.
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Weird dialog title problem
email.body:
Hi Steph,
> What's your codepage setting? Don't really know. In php.ini there is only the "default_charset" setting, but it's out-commented. So it should be iso-8859-1, because no other setting defines an encoding. The file itself has been saved as utf-8, but the title contains ascii-only chars. Also note that the title of the box changes with every new window.
-- Regards/MfG, Christian Weiske
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GtkListStore->insert()
email.body:
Should be fixed in CVS now. Try again.
-Andrei
On Oct 15, 2005, at 9:50 AM, Scott Mattocks wrote:
> Hi Andrei, > > Andrei Zmievski wrote: > >> I ended up taking your patch and expanding it. Should be in CVS >> now, let me know if it works for you. It actually does a little >> more than >> GtkListStore::insert(position, array items = null) >> > > I am running into some strange problems using insert with an array. > Sometimes it gives me warning about things being initialized to > NULL already. I added bug_gtkliststore_insert_with_array.php to the > test file. It has more details and you should be able to reproduce > the bug with that script. > > Also, I copied the override for GtkListStore::append and changed > the method name and Gtk function to prepend. The attached patch is > your code with two words changed. > > Thanks, > Scott > --- gtktreeview.overrides 2005-10-14 12:48:41.566336864 -0400 > +++ gtktreeview.overrides.prepend 2005-10-13 23:00:19.000000000 > -0400 > @@ -161,6 +161,26 @@ > } > > %% > +override gtk_list_store_prepend > +PHP_METHOD > +{ > + GtkTreeIter iter; > + zval *items = NULL; > + > + NOT_STATIC_METHOD(); > + > + if (!php_gtk_parse_args(ZEND_NUM_ARGS(), "|a", &items)) > + return; > + > + gtk_list_store_prepend(GTK_LIST_STORE(PHPG_GOBJECT(this_ptr)), > &iter); > + > + if (items && phpg_model_set_row(GTK_TREE_MODEL(PHPG_GOBJECT > (this_ptr)), &iter, items) == FAILURE) > + return; > + > + phpg_gboxed_new(&return_value, GTK_TYPE_TREE_ITER, &iter, > TRUE, TRUE TSRMLS_CC); > +} > + > +%% > override gtk_list_store_insert > PHP_METHOD > { > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Defeated
email.body:
Forget it, I played with the script I have here & the original function and it works now (in as much as it reaches the marshal). I'm trying to figure out wtf I was doing before to prevent it...
----- Original Message ----- From: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> To: "Tom Rogers" <trogers@kwikin.com> Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net>; "Andrei" <andrei@gravitonic.com> Sent: Thursday, October 20, 2005 1:23 PM Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Defeated
> ? My problem was not EVER reaching the callback marshal, which is why I > didn't start working on it!! > > I think perhaps it would be fairly useful to see a working PHP script at > this point - the things you are saying here are alien, so it's possible I > just don't know how to use the callback in Glade... > > - Steph > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Tom Rogers" <trogers@kwikin.com> > To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> > Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net>; "Andrei" > <andrei@gravitonic.com> > Sent: Thursday, October 20, 2005 9:29 AM > Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Defeated > > > > Hi Steph, > > > > Tuesday, October 18, 2005, 1:24:06 AM, you wrote: > > S> I just spent some hours trying to get > > S> glade_xml_signal_connect() working. I > > S> knew it'd be a bit of a challenge, but it's more of an Everest than the > > S> anticipated large Alp. > > > > S> Quite possibly I'm attacking it from the wrong direction anyway. I'd > have > > S> _liked_ to use phpg_signal_connect_impl(), but a) it isn't exporting > nicely > > S> when I force it (possibly that's a win32 thing?), and b) it's > effectively > > S> private to /main at present (deliberately so?). > > > > S> I ended up with g_signal_connect() and friends - convenience functions > in > > S> glib - but somehow the data isn't even getting far enough to prove me > wrong > > S> over that. It never reaches the marshal function > (GladeXMLConnectFunc), and > > S> I've been looking at it for so long now I'm absolutely out of ideas as > to > > S> why. > > > > S> glade_xml_signal_connect() is the difficult one of the generic GladeXML > > S> signal methods, the others will fall into place almost as soon as this > one's > > S> working. > > > > S> Any heroes out there? > > > > S> - Steph > > > > S> ps my effort's attached as a unified diff > > > > This works for me as a basic test and will need more work :) > > > > static void glade_signal_marshal(const gchar *handler_name, GObject *obj, > const gchar *signal_name, > > const gchar *signal_data, GObject *connect_object, gboolean after, > gpointer data) > > { > > phpg_cb_data_t *cbd = (phpg_cb_data_t *)data; > > char *callback_name; > > guint signal_id, handler_id; > > GQuark detail = 0; > > GClosure *closure = NULL; > > TSRMLS_FETCH(); > > > > fprintf(stdout, "DEBUG: reached the marshal function %s : > %s\n",handler_name,signal_name); // I never get this far - why? > > > > if (!zend_is_callable(cbd->callback, 0, &callback_name)) { > > php_error(E_WARNING, "unable to call GladeXML callback '%s' > specified in %s on line %ld", > > callback_name, cbd->src_filename, cbd->src_lineno); > > efree(callback_name); > > return; > > } > > > > /* If we ever reach here, this is where cbd->user_args should be > checked... */ > > if (!g_signal_parse_name(signal_name, G_OBJECT_TYPE(obj), &signal_id, > &detail, TRUE)) { > > php_error(E_WARNING, "%s(): unknown signal name '%s'", > get_active_function_name(TSRMLS_C), signal_name); > > return; > > } > > > > closure = phpg_closure_new(cbd->callback, cbd->user_args, > PHPG_CONNECT_NORMAL TSRMLS_CC); > > handler_id = g_signal_connect_closure_by_id(obj, signal_id, detail, > closure, after); > > > > efree(callback_name); > > } > > > > static PHP_METHOD(GladeXML, signal_connect) > > { > > char *signal = NULL; > > zval *callback = NULL, *extra = NULL; > > zend_bool free_signal; > > phpg_cb_data_t *data; > > > > NOT_STATIC_METHOD(); > > > > if (!php_gtk_parse_varargs(ZEND_NUM_ARGS(), 2, &extra, "uV", &signal, > &free_signal, &callback)) > > return; > > > > zval_add_ref(&callback); > > data = phpg_cb_data_new(callback, extra TSRMLS_CC); > > > > fprintf(stdout, "signal name is %s on line 175\n", signal); > > > > glade_xml_signal_connect_full(GLADE_XML(PHPG_GOBJECT(this_ptr)), > signal, > > > (GladeXMLConnectFunc)glade_signal_marshal, data); > > > > if (free_signal) g_free(signal); > > > > RETURN_NULL(); > > } > > > > > > The function name in the xml file was > > > > <child> > > <widget class="GtkImageMenuItem" id="open1"> > > <property name="visible">True</property> > > <property name="label">gtk-open</property> > > <property name="use_stock">True</property> > > <signal name="activate" handler="on_open1_activate" > last_modification_time="Tue, 18 Oct 2005 00:12:42 GMT"/> > > </widget> > > </child> > > > > so my php function call was: > > > > $glade->signal_connect('on_open1_activate','on_open1_activate'); > > > > my call back function I also called 'on_open1_activate' > > > > Hope this helps a bit > > > > -- > > regards, > > Tom > > >
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Fw: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Defeated - next question
email.body:
Anyone have an example of a working 'connect_object' call that used to work in Glade 1, please?
(just the relevant line from the Glade file will do this time!)
Thanks,
- Steph
ps Andrei, is it sane to use 'PHPG_CONNECT_SIMPLE' for connect_object calls? - there are no other options than connect_object and connect in Glade 2... (give or take 'after' for both)
----- Original Message ----- From: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> To: "Tom Rogers" <trogers@kwikin.com> Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net>; "Andrei" <andrei@gravitonic.com> Sent: Thursday, October 20, 2005 1:47 PM Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Defeated
> Forget it, I played with the script I have here & the original function and > it works now (in as much as it reaches the marshal). I'm trying to figure > out wtf I was doing before to prevent it... > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> > To: "Tom Rogers" <trogers@kwikin.com> > Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net>; "Andrei" > <andrei@gravitonic.com> > Sent: Thursday, October 20, 2005 1:23 PM > Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Defeated > > > > ? My problem was not EVER reaching the callback marshal, which is why I > > didn't start working on it!! > > > > I think perhaps it would be fairly useful to see a working PHP script at > > this point - the things you are saying here are alien, so it's possible I > > just don't know how to use the callback in Glade... > > > > - Steph > > > > > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > From: "Tom Rogers" <trogers@kwikin.com> > > To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> > > Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net>; "Andrei" > > <andrei@gravitonic.com> > > Sent: Thursday, October 20, 2005 9:29 AM > > Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Defeated > > > > > > > Hi Steph, > > > > > > Tuesday, October 18, 2005, 1:24:06 AM, you wrote: > > > S> I just spent some hours trying to get > > > S> glade_xml_signal_connect() working. I > > > S> knew it'd be a bit of a challenge, but it's more of an Everest than > the > > > S> anticipated large Alp. > > > > > > S> Quite possibly I'm attacking it from the wrong direction anyway. I'd > > have > > > S> _liked_ to use phpg_signal_connect_impl(), but a) it isn't exporting > > nicely > > > S> when I force it (possibly that's a win32 thing?), and b) it's > > effectively > > > S> private to /main at present (deliberately so?). > > > > > > S> I ended up with g_signal_connect() and friends - convenience > functions > > in > > > S> glib - but somehow the data isn't even getting far enough to prove me > > wrong > > > S> over that. It never reaches the marshal function > > (GladeXMLConnectFunc), and > > > S> I've been looking at it for so long now I'm absolutely out of ideas > as > > to > > > S> why. > > > > > > S> glade_xml_signal_connect() is the difficult one of the generic > GladeXML > > > S> signal methods, the others will fall into place almost as soon as > this > > one's > > > S> working. > > > > > > S> Any heroes out there? > > > > > > S> - Steph > > > > > > S> ps my effort's attached as a unified diff > > > > > > This works for me as a basic test and will need more work :) > > > > > > static void glade_signal_marshal(const gchar *handler_name, GObject > *obj, > > const gchar *signal_name, > > > const gchar *signal_data, GObject *connect_object, gboolean after, > > gpointer data) > > > { > > > phpg_cb_data_t *cbd = (phpg_cb_data_t *)data; > > > char *callback_name; > > > guint signal_id, handler_id; > > > GQuark detail = 0; > > > GClosure *closure = NULL; > > > TSRMLS_FETCH(); > > > > > > fprintf(stdout, "DEBUG: reached the marshal function %s : > > %s\n",handler_name,signal_name); // I never get this far - why? > > > > > > if (!zend_is_callable(cbd->callback, 0, &callback_name)) { > > > php_error(E_WARNING, "unable to call GladeXML callback '%s' > > specified in %s on line %ld", > > > callback_name, cbd->src_filename, cbd->src_lineno); > > > efree(callback_name); > > > return; > > > } > > > > > > /* If we ever reach here, this is where cbd->user_args should be > > checked... */ > > > if (!g_signal_parse_name(signal_name, G_OBJECT_TYPE(obj), > &signal_id, > > &detail, TRUE)) { > > > php_error(E_WARNING, "%s(): unknown signal name '%s'", > > get_active_function_name(TSRMLS_C), signal_name); > > > return; > > > } > > > > > > closure = phpg_closure_new(cbd->callback, cbd->user_args, > > PHPG_CONNECT_NORMAL TSRMLS_CC); > > > handler_id = g_signal_connect_closure_by_id(obj, signal_id, detail, > > closure, after); > > > > > > efree(callback_name); > > > } > > > > > > static PHP_METHOD(GladeXML, signal_connect) > > > { > > > char *signal = NULL; > > > zval *callback = NULL, *extra = NULL; > > > zend_bool free_signal; > > > phpg_cb_data_t *data; > > > > > > NOT_STATIC_METHOD(); > > > > > > if (!php_gtk_parse_varargs(ZEND_NUM_ARGS(), 2, &extra, "uV", > &signal, > > &free_signal, &callback)) > > > return; > > > > > > zval_add_ref(&callback); > > > data = phpg_cb_data_new(callback, extra TSRMLS_CC); > > > > > > fprintf(stdout, "signal name is %s on line 175\n", signal); > > > > > > glade_xml_signal_connect_full(GLADE_XML(PHPG_GOBJECT(this_ptr)), > > signal, > > > > > (GladeXMLConnectFunc)glade_signal_marshal, data); > > > > > > if (free_signal) g_free(signal); > > > > > > RETURN_NULL(); > > > } > > > > > > > > > The function name in the xml file was > > > > > > <child> > > > <widget class="GtkImageMenuItem" id="open1"> > > > <property name="visible">True</property> > > > <property name="label">gtk-open</property> > > > <property name="use_stock">True</property> > > > <signal name="activate" handler="on_open1_activate" > > last_modification_time="Tue, 18 Oct 2005 00:12:42 GMT"/> > > > </widget> > > > </child> > > > > > > so my php function call was: > > > > > > $glade->signal_connect('on_open1_activate','on_open1_activate'); > > > > > > my call back function I also called 'on_open1_activate' > > > > > > Hope this helps a bit > > > > > > -- > > > regards, > > > Tom > > > > > > > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >

email.subject: Re: Re[2]: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Defeated
email.body:
Yep, I was trying to connect the signal name rather than the callback handler name... nothing to do with internals, At All, just me not understanding that I wasn't supposed to use the signal name there...
Haven't even started to implement glade_xml_signal_autoconnect() yet, I'm still trying to get glade_xml_signal_connect() to pass user data (specifically: to pass an object when it's supposed to be a connect_object call from within Glade).
----- Original Message ----- From: "Tom Rogers" <trogers@kwikin.com> To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net>; "Andrei" <andrei@gravitonic.com> Sent: Thursday, October 20, 2005 4:34 PM Subject: Re[2]: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Defeated
> Hi Steph, > > Thursday, October 20, 2005, 10:47:26 PM, you wrote: > S> Forget it, I played with the script I have here & the original function and > S> it works now (in as much as it reaches the marshal). I'm trying to figure > S> out wtf I was doing before to prevent it... > > The way glade seems to work is you ask it for the widget that has a > connect name of for example 'on_open1_activate' it then calls your > marshal function and gives it a chance to do the real connect, > > If you use the glade_xml_signal_autoconnect it repeatedly calls your > marshal function for each widget that has a signal name in it. > Perhaps you should change the name to glade_signal_connect instead of > glade_signal_marshal ??? > > > > Anyway here is my test script and glade file: > > > > <?php > function on_open1_activate(){ > echo "Button Pressed
"; > } > $glade = new GladeXML("gladetest\gladetest.glade"); > $window = $glade->get_widget('window1'); > // returns the widget named > $menu1 = $glade->get_widget('menu1'); > $items = $menu1->children(); > > print $window->get_name()."
"; > // returns widget's name via GTK+ > print glade::get_widget_name($window->child)."
"; > // returns widget's name via libglade > > var_dump(glade::get_widget_tree($window)); > // returns current GladeXML object > print $glade->relative_file($glade->filename)."
"; > // returns relative path (and given filename) > $list = $glade->get_widget_prefix("button"); > // returns every widget having the given id prefix > foreach($list as $item) { > print $item->get_name()."
"; > } > > $window->connect_simple('destroy', array('gtk', 'main_quit')); > // works as advertised > $glade->signal_connect('on_open1_activate','on_open1_activate'); > // untested, probably won't work > > gtk::main(); > ?> > > <?xml version="1.0" standalone="no"?> <!--*- mode: xml -*--> > <!DOCTYPE glade-interface SYSTEM "http://glade.gnome.org/glade-2.0.dtd"> > > <glade-interface> > > <widget email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GdkGC vs. GdkGCX11
email.body:
It's normal.
-Andrei
On Oct 20, 2005, at 9:14 AM, Christian Weiske wrote:
> Hi > > When var_dump'ing the style of a widget, black_gc and white_gc are of > type "GdkGCX11". Is that ok? The user normally has no access to that > type of class. > > -- > Regards/MfG, > Christian Weiske
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: September News --> October News
email.body:
Thanks Jp. It has been fixed.
Jp wrote: > Scott wrote: >> That should be <a href="http://gtk.php.net/resources.php">... > > Guess something slipped there, as the homepage hapilly states: > "If you are interested in helping test PHP-GTK 2 on Windows, please send > your comments to the . " > > Does this means no comments are accepted? lol =) > > -Jp >
-- Scott Mattocks scott@crisscott.com http://www.crisscott.com http://pear.php.net/user/scottmattocks

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] #34954 [NEW]: Segmentation fault when trying to set a Hebrew letter in GtkEntry
[PHP-GTK-DEV] php-gtk or php-gtk2
email.body:
Hi
I don't know if we ever had the discussion, but why does the extension is still named "php-gtk" and not "php-gtk2"? So you always have to check the gtk version instead of just checking if the correct extension is loaded.
-- Regards/MfG, Christian Weiske
["signature.asc" (application/pgp-signature)]

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] #34954 [Opn->Fbk]: Segmentation fault when trying to set a Hebrew letter in GtkEntry
email.body:
ID: 34954 Updated by: sfox@php.net Reported By: isotop at gmail dot com -Status: Open +Status: Feedback Bug Type: PHP-GTK related Operating System: Linux(gentoo) -PHP Version: 1.0.0 (GTK) +PHP Version: 2.0.0-dev (GTK) New Comment:
1) Where is the Hebrew text? This script doesn't have any.. and the Zend and PHP versions are hard-coded in English.. I need to be able to reproduce what you're seeing before I can fix anything. 2) What is your codepage setting (in your php.ini)? 3) Shorter scripts are very much welcomed. Example:
<?php
function shutdown() { print("Shutting down...\n"); gtk::main_quit(); }
function on_button1_clicked($php, $zend) { $php->set_text($zend->get_text()); }
$glade = new GladeXML( dirname( __FILE__) . "/xml.glade"); $glade->signal_autoconnect();
$php = $glade->get_widget("php"); $php->set_text(phpversion()); $zend = $glade->get_widget("zend"); $zend->set_text(zend_version());
gtk::main();
?>
