email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] First release?
email.body:
I need to look at libglade implementation first. And some GdkGC stuff.
-Andrei
On Oct 21, 2005, at 1:26 PM, Scott Mattocks wrote:
> I haven't posted bug files about these yet but: > > 1) GtkTextTag attributes are not accessible. Also there is no > method to set an attribute. This means that tags are basically > useless. I could just be missing something though. If anyone knows > how to use text tags in PHP-GTK 2 please let me know. > > 2) GtkCellRenderer attributes are not accessible. Also there is no > GtkCellRenderer method to set an attribute. For example, I want to > be able to change the background color of a cell if the value is > zero. To do this I need to use > GtkTreeViewColumn::set_cell_data_func. In the callback, the > cellrenderer attribute for background should be set if the value > equals zero. There is no way to set this attribute. Again, I could > be missing something. If anyone knows how to do this please let me > know. > > Scott > > Christian Weiske wrote: > >> Hi >> Steph asked for outstanding issues on 2005-09-19. Some have been >> fixed >> since then; are there any more which prevent a first release? >> > > -- > Scott Mattocks > scott@crisscott.com > http://www.crisscott.com > http://pear.php.net/user/scottmattocks > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] #34954 [Fbk]: Segmentation fault when trying to set a Hebrew letter in GtkEntry
[PHP-GTK-DEV] #34954 [Fbk->Csd]: Segmentation fault when trying to set a Hebrew letter in GtkEntry
Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Correct PEAR package.xml php-gtk dependency tag?
email.body:
Steph,
> Do we need to have a package.xml file too to fit into PEAR's system? No. Let me explain: PEAR packages are just PHP code. This code may depend on other packages and have some other requirements (e.g. only php version > 5.1 or pear installer version > 1.4.2). Every PEAR package has to have a package.xml file which contains the name, description, author(s), maintainer(s) and so on - and the dependencies. So when installing, pear will either tell you that some deps are missing or it automatically installs them for you when wished.
Now you also can depend on PECL packages which can be even compiled automatically. Just php-gtk doesn't fit in that schema; it's not in pecl. I just asked Greg if he could do a "special case" for php-gtk to check if the php-gtk is loaded or can be loaded (loaded for php-gtk1), so that we can have deps on php-gtk.
-- Regards/MfG, Christian Weiske
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] php-gtk or php-gtk2
email.body:
Because PHP is still PHP.
Also.
The extension is not an extension. It has a CVS module to itself.

-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] uint vs int
email.body:
done
----- Original Message ----- From: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Friday, September 02, 2005 5:57 PM Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] uint vs int
> You can change it to 'int'. > > On Sep 2, 2005, at 2:47 AM, Steph wrote: > > > Hi Andrei, > > > > In php_gtk+_types.c, you have: > > > > static const uint STYLE_NUM_STATES = 5; > > > > It's used to check the positive end of ranges in a couple of places > > against > > a straight int, e.g. > > > > if (index < 0 || index >= STYLE_NUM_STATES) { > > > > and as a counter, again positive, in one place, e.g. > > > > for (i = 0; i < STYLE_NUM_STATES; i++) { > > > > The only reason I can see for it being declared as a uint at all is: > > > > static int style_helper_count_elements(zval *object, long *count > > TSRMLS_DC) > > { > > *count = STYLE_NUM_STATES; > > return SUCCESS; > > } > > > > If you were planning to implement style_helper_count_elements() fully > > and > > declare STYLE_NUM_STATES from there, uint would make some kind of > > sense. As > > a constant, it makes no sense at all. > > > > Can I kill it and get rid of my compiler warnings pliz? > > > > - Steph > > > > -- > > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] warnings to kill
email.body:
Andrei,
I got rid of all the generator errors now. Apart from the logging issue most of them were ZTS-related, and there were two link errors because GtkPlug and GtkSocket don't exist in Tor's library, so I added win32-specific override commands to the generator.
It should create release and debug builds out of the box now, but I still have some work to do on configure options.
I'm getting a few compiler warnings, mostly over float-to-double conversions, and I haven't figured out where they're coming from yet.
In the phpg_gdkevent_read_property_handler() declaration you have
guint i = 0;
when i is about to be used in a for loop. Can I 'gint' it please? - it'll give me one less warning to be twitchy about :)
- Steph
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] messy hack
email.body:
<?php

$window = new GtkWindow('Testing stuff');
$window->connect_object('destroy', array('gtk', 'main_quit'));

$button = new GtkButton('');
$label = $button->child;
$label->set_text_with_mnemonic('_Suck it and see');
$window->add($button);

$window->show_all();

gtk::main();

?>

It took a while to understand why use_underline is TRUE by default, but it
has to be better than working around it in userland.

I think I can probably tackle those outstanding 'mnemonic' calls with my
copy/paste skills, there are a few incidences of it already in the source.

Do you have any strong feelings about that approach, Andrei?

- Steph

-- 
PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/)

email.subject: Fw: [PHP-GTK-DEV] messy hack and stability
email.body:
I finally got GTK+ source to download (definitely bedtime now). Just say 'no' to dialup, kids...
If use_underline is true and there's no mnemonic value set, gtk_label_set_uline_text_internal() simply returns GDK_VoidSymbol as the accelerator key. The mnemonic widget by default is the parent widget, i.e. the button or menu item containing the label. However if the label itself can't find an 'activatable ancestor' to use as a target, you get a warning beep and a bit of barfing. So it's not a good idea to have use_underline = 1 indiscriminately in things like set_text() or even in gtklabel (because it would generally find its ancestral gtkwindow, which might make for confusion, and because labels in gtknotebook would act completely differently from everywhere else), but it _is_ a good idea to apply it with discrimination, in the places where people are likely to want to use it more often than they are likely to want to escape it.
So can I make that small change in the button and menuitem constructors and make PHP-GTK a tad easier to use, please?
----- Original Message ----- From: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> To: "Andrei" <andrei@gravitonic.com> Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Monday, September 05, 2005 6:43 PM Subject: Fw: [PHP-GTK-DEV] messy hack
> OK, I looked again now and discovered the second parameter in > gtk_button_new. > > I think what I'm asking, then, is whether that second parameter couldn't be > made a more intuitive '1' by default, i.e. it's switch-off-able but is > generally 'just there' in things like menu items, labels and buttons using > the text parameter, and probably also in set_text(). > > I'm having trouble getting access to the C source for gtk+/win32 at present, > so I've no idea whether that's going to render those widgets unstable. > > It _appears_ to work without problems here for GtkButton and GtkLabel. > > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> > To: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> > Cc: "Andrei" <andrei@gravitonic.com> > Sent: Sunday, September 04, 2005 4:18 PM > Subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] messy hack > > > > <?php > > > > $window = new GtkWindow('Testing stuff'); > > $window->connect_object('destroy', array('gtk', 'main_quit')); > > > > $button = new GtkButton(''); > > $label = $button->child; > > $label->set_text_with_mnemonic('_Suck it and see'); > > $window->add($button); > > > > $window->show_all(); > > > > gtk::main(); > > > > ?> > > > > It took a while to understand why use_underline is TRUE by default, but it > > has to be better than working around it in userland. > > > > I think I can probably tackle those outstanding 'mnemonic' calls with my > > copy/paste skills, there are a few incidences of it already in the source. > > > > Do you have any strong feelings about that approach, Andrei? > > > > - Steph > > > > -- > > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > > >

email.subject: Re[2]: [PHP-GTK-DEV] reduce compiler warnings (win32)
Re[4]: [PHP-GTK-DEV] reduce compiler warnings (win32)
email.body:
Hi,
Sunday, September 11, 2005, 10:27:54 PM, you wrote: S> Hi Tom,
S> Hrm..
S> rem S> rem Root of Visual C++ installed files. S> rem S> set MSVCDir=C:\PROGRA~1\MICROS~3\VC98
S> - is what goes into vcvars32.bat automatically, without me touching S> anything. How come you're needing to escape whitespace?
S> If you need to add a path of your own you do something like: S> set MSDevDir=C:\sandbox S> SET S> PATH=C:\PROGRA~1\MICROS~3\VC98\BIN\;%MSDevDir%\BIN\;%MSDevDir%\php5\Release_ S> TS\;%PATH%
S> (and similar with the lib and include paths)
S> I couldn't get jscript's substr() to work here without the length parameter, S> apparently this is a known issue (not your fault, MS's). So it was adding S> an extra backslash to everything.
S> Does the attached work for you? (and making your env vars sane paths?)
Its only needed for the dreaded rc, the rest are picked up in the env.
This is what gets put in the makefile with my patch
MC="d:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\VC98\bin\mc.exe" RC="C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\Common\MSDev98\Bin\rc.exe" LD="d:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\VC98\bin\link.exe"
I don't use the vars bat file, they are always in the enviroment.
You see that rc.exe is not in with the others .. perhaps thats why?? -- regards, Tom
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

Checking for cl.exe ... <in default path> Checking for mc.exe ... d:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\VC98\bin Checking for rc.exe ... C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\Common\MSDev98\Bin Checking for link.exe ... d:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\VC98\bin Checking for nmake.exe ... <in default path> Checking for lib.exe ... <in default path>

Question is, should we be making everything 'u' now rather than 's'?
----- Original Message ----- From: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Monday, September 12, 2005 6:07 PM Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] [PATCH] making GtkTextBuffer::set_text() accept single param
> Any text passed to Gtk+ should be in UTF-8, so yes, "u" is appropriate. > Don't forget to free the converted string, for example: > > static PHP_METHOD(Gtk, accel_map_add_entry) > { > char *accel_path; > zend_bool free_accel_path; > long accel_key; > GdkModifierType accel_mods; > zval *php_accel_mods = NULL; > > if (!php_gtk_parse_args(ZEND_NUM_ARGS(), "uiV", &accel_path, > &free_accel_path, &accel_key, &php_accel_mods)) > return; > > if (php_accel_mods && phpg_gvalue_get_flags(GDK_TYPE_MODIFIER_TYPE, > php_accel_mods, (gint *)&accel_mods) == FAILURE) { > return; > } > > gtk_accel_map_add_entry(accel_path, (guint)accel_key, accel_mods); > if (free_accel_path) g_free(accel_path); > > } > > -Andrei > > On Sep 12, 2005, at 6:52 AM, Steph wrote: > > > I don't have a test script for this, I just want to keep it somewhere > > safe > > for now (and can't see any reason for it to fail). Compiles OK. > > > > GtkImageMenuItem's constructor represents the stock_id parameter as 'u' > > (encoded string) rather than as 's' (string) - this is the only place > > in the > > overrides where stock_id's represented that way. Should the others > > also > > accept encoded strings, or is it a typo? > > > > - Steph > > <textbuffer.txt>-- > > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] [PATCH] making GtkTextBuffer::set_text() accept single param
email.body:
Like I said, any text passed to Gtk+ API has to be UTF-8, so we need to use "u". And, when returning a string, we need to convert from UTF-8 to whatever codepage we have.
-Andrei
On Sep 12, 2005, at 1:13 PM, Steph wrote:
> Thanks for that, it's helpful. > > Question is, should we be making everything 'u' now rather than 's'? > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> > To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> > Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> > Sent: Monday, September 12, 2005 6:07 PM > Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] [PATCH] making GtkTextBuffer::set_text() > accept > single param > > >> Any text passed to Gtk+ should be in UTF-8, so yes, "u" is >> appropriate. >> Don't forget to free the converted string, for example: >> >> static PHP_METHOD(Gtk, accel_map_add_entry) >> { >> char *accel_path; >> zend_bool free_accel_path; >> long accel_key; >> GdkModifierType accel_mods; >> zval *php_accel_mods = NULL; >> >> if (!php_gtk_parse_args(ZEND_NUM_ARGS(), "uiV", &accel_path, >> &free_accel_path, &accel_key, &php_accel_mods)) >> return; >> >> if (php_accel_mods && >> phpg_gvalue_get_flags(GDK_TYPE_MODIFIER_TYPE, >> php_accel_mods, (gint *)&accel_mods) == FAILURE) { >> return; >> } >> >> gtk_accel_map_add_entry(accel_path, (guint)accel_key, >> accel_mods); >> if (free_accel_path) g_free(accel_path); >> >> } >> >> -Andrei >> >> On Sep 12, 2005, at 6:52 AM, Steph wrote: >> >>> I don't have a test script for this, I just want to keep it somewhere >>> safe >>> for now (and can't see any reason for it to fail). Compiles OK. >>> >>> GtkImageMenuItem's constructor represents the stock_id parameter as >>> 'u' >>> (encoded string) rather than as 's' (string) - this is the only place >>> in the >>> overrides where stock_id's represented that way. Should the others >>> also >>> accept encoded strings, or is it a typo? >>> >>> - Steph >>> <textbuffer.txt>-- >>> PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) >>> To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >> >> -- >> PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) >> To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >>

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] [PATCH] making GtkTextBuffer::set_text() accept single param
email.body:
I recall issues with this under win32 in GTK 1, it's not an entirely new thing - GTK always did use utf8 strings internally.
I haven't had any problems with plain strings on WinXP so far, but then I haven't really pushed the boat out either. Will do some checking when I've more time.

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] [PATCH] making GtkTextBuffer::set_text() accept single param
email.body:
Of course, UTF-8 is compatible with ASCII, so if your string argument happens to contain only chars in the 0-127 range, then it wouldn't be a problem. But we still need to do the conversion in case non-ASCII stuff is passed.
-Andrei
On Sep 12, 2005, at 3:57 PM, Steph wrote:
> I recall issues with this under win32 in GTK 1, it's not an entirely > new > thing - GTK always did use utf8 strings internally. > > I haven't had any problems with plain strings on WinXP so far, but > then I > haven't really pushed the boat out either. email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] [PATCH] making GtkTextBuffer::set_text() accept single param
email.body:
OK, but I need to see it in action before I know precisely what you mean by that.
With PHP-GTK 1, Frank had to convert incoming non-UTF8 strings for the doze version (and you didn't need to for *nix). I hoped Pango might do that for us now... either that or Tor might have already gone that way...
----- Original Message ----- From: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Tuesday, September 13, 2005 5:19 PM Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] [PATCH] making GtkTextBuffer::set_text() accept single param
> Of course, UTF-8 is compatible with ASCII, so if your string argument > happens to contain only chars in the 0-127 range, then it wouldn't be a > problem. But we still need to do the conversion in case non-ASCII stuff > is passed. > > -Andrei > > On Sep 12, 2005, at 3:57 PM, Steph wrote: > > > I recall issues with this under win32 in GTK 1, it's not an entirely > > new > > thing - GTK always did use utf8 strings internally. > > > > I haven't had any problems with plain strings on WinXP so far, but > > then I > > haven't really pushed the boat out either. Will do some checking when > > I've > > more time. > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > From: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> > > To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> > > Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> > > Sent: Monday, September 12, 2005 9:21 PM > > Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] [PATCH] making GtkTextBuffer::set_text() > > accept > > single param > > > > > >> Like I said, any text passed to Gtk+ API has to be UTF-8, so we need > >> to > >> use "u". And, when returning a string, we need to convert from UTF-8 > >> to > >> whatever codepage we have. > >> > >> -Andrei > >> > >> On Sep 12, 2005, at 1:13 PM, Steph wrote: > >> > >>> Thanks for that, it's helpful. > >>> > >>> Question is, should we be making everything 'u' now rather than 's'? > >>> > >>> ----- Original Message ----- > >>> From: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> > >>> To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> > >>> Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> > >>> Sent: Monday, September 12, 2005 6:07 PM > >>> Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] [PATCH] making GtkTextBuffer::set_text() > >>> accept > >>> single param > >>> > >>> > >>>> Any text passed to Gtk+ should be in UTF-8, so yes, "u" is > >>>> appropriate. > >>>> Don't forget to free the converted string, for example: > >>>> > >>>> static PHP_METHOD(Gtk, accel_map_add_entry) > >>>> { > >>>> char *accel_path; > >>>> zend_bool free_accel_path; > >>>> long accel_key; > >>>> GdkModifierType accel_mods; > >>>> zval *php_accel_mods = NULL; > >>>> > >>>> if (!php_gtk_parse_args(ZEND_NUM_ARGS(), "uiV", &accel_path, > >>>> &free_accel_path, &accel_key, &php_accel_mods)) > >>>> return; > >>>> > >>>> if (php_accel_mods && > >>>> phpg_gvalue_get_flags(GDK_TYPE_MODIFIER_TYPE, > >>>> php_accel_mods, (gint *)&accel_mods) == FAILURE) { > >>>> return; > >>>> } > >>>> > >>>> gtk_accel_map_add_entry(accel_path, (guint)accel_key, > >>>> accel_mods); > >>>> if (free_accel_path) g_free(accel_path); > >>>> > >>>> } > >>>> > >>>> -Andrei > >>>> > >>>> On Sep 12, 2005, at 6:52 AM, Steph wrote: > >>>> > >>>>> I don't have a test script for this, I just want to keep it > >>>>> somewhere > >>>>> safe > >>>>> for now (and can't see any reason for it to fail). Compiles OK. > >>>>> > >>>>> GtkImageMenuItem's constructor represents the stock_id parameter as > >>>>> 'u' > >>>>> (encoded string) rather than as 's' (string) - this is the only > >>>>> place > >>>>> in the > >>>>> overrides where stock_id's represented that way. Should the others > >>>>> also > >>>>> accept encoded strings, or is it a typo? > >>>>> > >>>>> - Steph > >>>>> <textbuffer.txt>-- > >>>>> PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > >>>>> To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > >>>> > >>>> -- > >>>> PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > >>>> To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > >>>> > >> > >> -- > >> PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > >> To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > >> >
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] [PATCH] making GtkTextBuffer::set_text() accept single param
email.body:
OK, I did some experimenting with codepages, 'u', 's' and stuff now. Works fine here - strings that get thrown out when they're 's' are converted nicely when they're 'u'. Of course doze can't then print out the contents of the label correctly for debugging etc, but that's a minor consideration.
Wouldn't it make more sense, internally, to have the 's' representation have the functionality of the 'u' representation? Or are there places where we need 's' to mean what it normally means?
----- Original Message ----- From: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Tuesday, September 13, 2005 5:19 PM Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] [PATCH] making GtkTextBuffer::set_text() accept single param
> Of course, UTF-8 is compatible with ASCII, so if your string argument > happens to contain only chars in the 0-127 range, then it wouldn't be a > problem. But we still need to do the conversion in case non-ASCII stuff > is passed. > > -Andrei > > On Sep 12, 2005, at 3:57 PM, Steph wrote: > > > I recall issues with this under win32 in GTK 1, it's not an entirely > > new > > thing - GTK always did use utf8 strings internally. > > > > I haven't had any problems with plain strings on WinXP so far, but > > then I > > haven't really pushed the boat out either. Will do some checking when > > I've > > more time. > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > From: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> > > To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> > > Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> > > Sent: Monday, September 12, 2005 9:21 PM > > Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] [PATCH] making GtkTextBuffer::set_text() > > accept > > single param > > > > > >> Like I said, any text passed to Gtk+ API has to be UTF-8, so we need > >> to > >> use "u". email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] reduce compiler warnings (win32)
email.body:
S'funny, I was doing that last night too (and went the new-class-for-floats route).
We need to test both options - both get rid of compiler warnings. Yours is prettier.
The other two are code-related - need to check them with Andrei.
- Steph
----- Original Message ----- From: "Tom Rogers" <trogers@kwikin.com> To: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Cc: "Andrei" <andrei@gravitonic.com>; "Steph" <steph@zend.com> Sent: Sunday, September 11, 2005 6:01 AM Subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] reduce compiler warnings (win32)
> Hi > > Here is a patch to get rid of compiler warnings: > > conversion from 'double ' to 'float ', possible loss of data > > RCS file: /repository/php-gtk/generator/arg_types.php,v > retrieving revision 1.73 > diff -u -w -b -r1.73 arg_types.php > --- arg_types.php 3 Sep 2005 19:06:12 -0000 1.73 > +++ arg_types.php 11 Sep 2005 04:55:00 -0000 > @@ -300,8 +300,11 @@ > $info->var_list->add('double', $name . ' = ' . $default); > else > $info->var_list->add('double', $name); > - $info->arg_list[] = $name; > $info->add_parse_list('d', '&' . $name); > + if($type == 'gfloat') > + $info->arg_list[] = "(float)$name"; > + else > + $info->arg_list[] = $name; > } > > function write_return($type, $owns_return, $info) > > > Or should there be a whole new class for floats ? > > -- > > Tom > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >

email.subject: Re: Re[2]: [PHP-GTK-DEV] reduce compiler warnings (win32)
email.body:
Hi Tom,
Hrm..
rem rem Root of Visual C++ installed files. rem set MSVCDir=C:\PROGRA~1\MICROS~3\VC98
- is what goes into vcvars32.bat automatically, without me touching anything. How come you're needing to escape whitespace?
If you need to add a path of your own you do something like: set MSDevDir=C:\sandbox SET PATH=C:\PROGRA~1\MICROS~3\VC98\BIN\;%MSDevDir%\BIN\;%MSDevDir%\php5\Release_ TS\;%PATH%
(and similar with the lib and include paths)
I couldn't get jscript's substr() to work here without the length parameter, apparently this is a known issue (not your fault, MS's). So it was adding an extra backslash to everything.
Does the attached work for you? (and making your env vars sane paths?)
----- Original Message ----- From: "Tom Rogers" <trogers@kwikin.com> To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net>; "Andrei" <andrei@gravitonic.com> Sent: Sunday, September 11, 2005 9:53 AM Subject: Re[2]: [PHP-GTK-DEV] reduce compiler warnings (win32)
> Hi, > > Sunday, September 11, 2005, 6:14:40 PM, you wrote: > S> S'funny, I was doing that last night too (and went the new-class-for-floats > S> route). > > S> We need to test both options - both get rid of compiler warnings. Yours is > S> prettier. > > S> The other two are code-related - need to check them with Andrei. > > Can you also check this change needed to compile using vc6 > > RCS file: /repository/php-gtk/win32/confutils.js,v > retrieving revision 1.5 > diff -u -w -b -r1.5 confutils.js > --- confutils.js 8 Sep 2005 03:19:44 -0000 1.5 > +++ confutils.js 11 Sep 2005 08:50:18 -0000 > @@ -392,7 +392,9 @@ > if (place == true) { > > place = exe; > > } else if (place != false) { > > + if(place.substr(-1) != "\\") place = place+"\\" > place = place + exe; > > + if(place.indexOf(' ')) place = '"'+place+'"'; > } > > > > if (place) { > > > -- > regards, > Tom > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >
["configure.txt" (text/plain)]
Index: win32/confutils.js =================================================================== RCS file: /repository/php-gtk/win32/confutils.js,v retrieving revision 1.5 diff -u -r1.5 confutils.js --- win32/confutils.js 8 Sep 2005 03:19:44 -0000 1.5 +++ win32/confutils.js 11 Sep 2005 12:20:15 -0000 @@ -392,7 +392,13 @@ if (place == true) { place = exe; } else if (place != false) { + + if (place.lastIndexOf("\\") != place.length - 1) { + place += "\\"; + } + place = place + exe; + }
if (place) {

email.subject: Fw: Fw: [PHP-GTK-DEV] messy hack and stability
Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] messy hack and stability
email.body:
WTF is gtk_label_set_uline_text_internal?
-Andrei
On Sep 5, 2005, at 7:38 PM, Steph wrote:
> I finally got GTK+ source to download (definitely bedtime now). > Just say > 'no' to dialup, kids... > > If use_underline is true and there's no mnemonic value set, > gtk_label_set_uline_text_internal() simply returns GDK_VoidSymbol > as the > accelerator key. The mnemonic widget by default is the parent > widget, i.e. > the button or menu item containing the label. However if the label > itself > can't find an 'activatable ancestor' to use as a target, you get a > warning > beep and a bit of barfing. So it's not a good idea to have > use_underline = > 1 indiscriminately in things like set_text() or even in gtklabel > (because it > would generally find its ancestral gtkwindow, which might make for > confusion, and because labels in gtknotebook would act completely > differently from everywhere else), but it _is_ a good idea to apply > it with > discrimination, in the places where people are likely to want to > use it more > often than they are likely to want to escape it. > > So can I make that small change in the button and menuitem > constructors and > make PHP-GTK a tad easier to use, please? > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> > To: "Andrei" <andrei@gravitonic.com> > Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> > Sent: Monday, September 05, 2005 6:43 PM > Subject: Fw: [PHP-GTK-DEV] messy hack > > > >> OK, I looked again now and discovered the second parameter in >> gtk_button_new. >> >> I think what I'm asking, then, is whether that second parameter >> couldn't >> > be > >> made a more intuitive '1' by default, i.e. it's switch-off-able >> but is >> generally 'just there' in things like menu items, labels and >> buttons using >> the text parameter, and probably also in set_text(). >> >> I'm having trouble getting access to the C source for gtk+/win32 at >> > present, > >> so I've no idea whether that's going to render those widgets >> unstable. >> >> It _appears_ to work without problems here for GtkButton and >> GtkLabel. >> >> >> ----- Original Message ----- >> From: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> >> To: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> >> Cc: "Andrei" <andrei@gravitonic.com> >> Sent: Sunday, September 04, 2005 4:18 PM >> Subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] messy hack >> >> >> >>> <?php >>> >>> $window = new GtkWindow('Testing stuff'); >>> $window->connect_object('destroy', array('gtk', 'main_quit')); >>> >>> $button = new GtkButton(''); >>> $label = $button->child; >>> $label->set_text_with_mnemonic('_Suck it and see'); >>> $window->add($button); >>> >>> $window->show_all(); >>> >>> gtk::main(); >>> >>> ?> >>> >>> It took a while to understand why use_underline is TRUE by >>> default, but >>> > it > >>> has to be better than working around it in userland. >>> >>> I think I can probably tackle those outstanding 'mnemonic' calls >>> with my >>> copy/paste skills, there are a few incidences of it already in the >>> > source. > >>> >>> Do you have any strong feelings about that approach, Andrei? >>> >>> - Steph >>> >>> -- >>> PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) >>> To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >>> >>> >> >
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] uint vs int
email.body:
You can change it to 'int'.
On Sep 2, 2005, at 2:47 AM, Steph wrote:
> Hi Andrei, > > In php_gtk+_types.c, you have: > > static const uint STYLE_NUM_STATES = 5; > > It's used to check the positive end of ranges in a couple of places > against > a straight int, e.g. > > if (index < 0 || index >= STYLE_NUM_STATES) { > > and as a counter, again positive, in one place, e.g. > > for (i = 0; i < STYLE_NUM_STATES; i++) { > > The only reason I can see for it being declared as a uint at all is: > > static int style_helper_count_elements(zval *object, long *count > TSRMLS_DC) > { > *count = STYLE_NUM_STATES; > return SUCCESS; > } > > If you were planning to implement style_helper_count_elements() fully > and > declare STYLE_NUM_STATES from there, uint would make some kind of > sense. As > a constant, it makes no sense at all. > > Can I kill it and get rid of my compiler warnings pliz? > > - Steph > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

Patch attached, I daren't start committing C without you looking it over first but it works on my box [TM].
----- Original Message ----- From: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> To: "Tom Rogers" <trogers@kwikin.com> Cc: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> Sent: Sunday, September 04, 2005 7:13 AM Subject: Re: [UNSURE] Re: some success :)
> Uh, are you trying to override properties or methods? > > -Andrei > > > On Sep 3, 2005, at 9:00 PM, Tom Rogers wrote: > > > Hi, > > > > Here is my first attempt, it fixes > > > > GtkColorSelection get_current_color() > > GtkColorSelection get_previous_color() > > (Both reporting they need one value passed) > > > > %% > > override-prop GtkColorSelection get_current_color > > PHPG_PROP_READER > > { > > > > GdkColor php_retval; > > > > gtk_color_selection_get_current_color(GTK_COLOR_SELECTION > > (PHPG_GOBJECT(this_ptr)), &php_retval); > > phpg_gboxed_new(&return_value, GDK_TYPE_COLOR, &php_retval, > > TRUE, TRUE TSRMLS_CC); > > > > return SUCCESS; > > > > } > > > > %% > > override-prop GtkColorSelection get_previous_color > > PHPG_PROP_READER > > { > > > > GdkColor php_retval; > > > > gtk_color_selection_get_previous_color(GTK_COLOR_SELECTION > > (PHPG_GOBJECT(this_ptr)), &php_retval); > > phpg_gboxed_new(&return_value, GDK_TYPE_COLOR, &php_retval, > > TRUE, TRUE TSRMLS_CC); > > > > return SUCCESS; > > > > } > > > > > > ************************************************* > > What is the command line to rerun the generator scripts? > > Any rules/conventions regarding placement of new overides? > > > > -- > > regards, > > Tom > > >
["colorselector.txt" (text/plain)]
Index: ext/gtk+/gtk.overrides =================================================================== RCS file: /repository/php-gtk/ext/gtk+/gtk.overrides,v retrieving revision 1.115 diff -u -r1.115 gtk.overrides --- ext/gtk+/gtk.overrides 3 Sep 2005 19:06:11 -0000 1.115 +++ ext/gtk+/gtk.overrides 4 Sep 2005 05:37:51 -0000 @@ -573,6 +573,46 @@ } %% }}}
+%% {{{ GtkColorSelection +%% +override gtk_color_selection_get_current_color +PHP_METHOD +{ + + GdkColor color = { 0 , 0 , 0 , 0 }; + + if (ZEND_NUM_ARGS() > 0) { + php_error(E_WARNING, "%s::%s() requires 0 arguments, %d given", + get_active_class_name(NULL TSRMLS_CC), + get_active_function_name(TSRMLS_C), ZEND_NUM_ARGS()); + return; + } + + gtk_color_selection_get_current_color(GTK_COLOR_SELECTION(PHPG_GOBJECT(this_ptr)), &color); + phpg_gboxed_new(&return_value, GDK_TYPE_COLOR, &color, TRUE, TRUE TSRMLS_CC); + +} + +%% +override gtk_color_selection_get_previous_color +PHP_METHOD +{ + + GdkColor color = { 0 , 0 , 0 , 0 }; + + if (ZEND_NUM_ARGS() > 0) { + php_error(E_WARNING, "%s::%s() requires 0 arguments, %d given", + get_active_class_name(NULL TSRMLS_CC), + get_active_function_name(TSRMLS_C), ZEND_NUM_ARGS()); + return; + } + + gtk_color_selection_get_previous_color(GTK_COLOR_SELECTION(PHPG_GOBJECT(this_ptr)), &color); + phpg_gboxed_new(&return_value, GDK_TYPE_COLOR, &color, TRUE, TRUE TSRMLS_CC); + +} +%% }}} + %% include gtkcontainer.overrides
%% {{{ GtkDialog

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Instructions to follow
email.body:
Hi Scott,
Both things apply, except that you need to have a native MS build environment to build it (basically the same tools you'd need for building PHP). It's based on the build system Wez Furlong wrote for PHP 5, which is pretty stable - all the official PHP 5 win32 distros use it.
If anyone other than Frank, Tom and myself would like to test the PHP-GTK 2 version now, it'd be much appreciated... apparently this is the first time anyone's used this system for anything outside the PHP source tree, so something's bound to fall apart.
I'll get around to updating the .dsw/.dsp build system in a week or so, I've a fair amount of catching up to do @ work at present.
- Steph
----- Original Message ----- From: "Scott Mattocks" <scott@crisscott.com> To: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Friday, September 02, 2005 8:05 PM Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Instructions to follow
> Hi Steph, > > For those of us who have no idea what your recent batch of commits > means, can you please explain what the windows build system means to the > average developer? Will we be able to build our own PHP-GTK 2 for > windows like we do Linux or is this just the ground work for being able > to release a windows version? > > Thanks, > Scott > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Fw: [PHP-GTK-DEV] messy hack
email.body:
OK, I looked again now and discovered the second parameter in gtk_button_new.
I think what I'm asking, then, is whether that second parameter couldn't be made a more intuitive '1' by default, i.e. it's switch-off-able but is generally 'just there' in things like menu items, labels and buttons using the text parameter, and probably also in set_text().
I'm having trouble getting access to the C source for gtk+/win32 at present, so I've no idea whether that's going to render those widgets unstable.
It _appears_ to work without problems here for GtkButton and GtkLabel.
----- Original Message ----- From: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> To: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Cc: "Andrei" <andrei@gravitonic.com> Sent: Sunday, September 04, 2005 4:18 PM Subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] messy hack
> <?php > > $window = new GtkWindow('Testing stuff'); > $window->connect_object('destroy', array('gtk', 'main_quit')); > > $button = new GtkButton(''); > $label = $button->child; > $label->set_text_with_mnemonic('_Suck it and see'); > $window->add($button); > > $window->show_all(); > > gtk::main(); > > ?> > > It took a while to understand why use_underline is TRUE by default, but it > has to be better than working around it in userland. > > I think I can probably tackle those outstanding 'mnemonic' calls with my > copy/paste skills, there are a few incidences of it already in the source. > > Do you have any strong feelings about that approach, Andrei? > > - Steph > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: Re[2]: [UNSURE] Fw: [UNSURE] Fw: [UNSURE] Re: [UNSURE] Re: [UNSURE] Fw: [UNSURE] R
email.body:
Hi Tom,
Making the suggested changes in the configuration process actually breaks the build for me on WinXP. Please can you give me details of:
1) the OS you're using 2) what comes back when you echo PHP_OS (in case we need to make finegrained OS-specific changes in the generator as you suggested below) 3) your current build env layout 4) the contents of vcvars32.bat (by default it lives in C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\VC98\Bin)
If we're going to debug this thing properly I need to know exactly what happens when you _don't_ make any changes to the CVS version, e.g. error messages and which point they turn up at. Would you mind very much renaming the php-gtk dir that works for you, getting a fresh check-out, following the instructions there (I sanitized the include paths now) and starting from scratch?
Thank you for all your hard work in testing this yesterday, I know you spent some several hours on it!
- Steph
----- Original Message ----- From: "Tom Rogers" <trogers@kwikin.com> To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> Sent: Wednesday, September 07, 2005 9:05 AM Subject: Re[2]: [UNSURE] Fw: [UNSURE] Fw: [UNSURE] Re: [UNSURE] Re: [UNSURE] Fw: [UNSURE] Re: some success :)
> Hi Steph, > > Getting closer :) > The reason overrides were not being processed is windows habit of > changing \n to \r\n which screwed the parser. I have a small fix for > that. > //overrides.php > > function _parse_block($block, $blocklineno, $file_name) > { > > if (strpos($block, "\n")){ > $test = preg_split('/\r\n|\n/',ltrim($block)); > $line = array_shift($test); > $rest = implode("\n",$test); > } > else { > $line = $block; > $rest = ''; > } > $words = preg_split('!\s+!', $line, -1, PREG_SPLIT_NO_EMPTY); > $command = array_shift($words); > switch ($command) { > > > > Next in config-utils.js need to add a backslash to the PATH_PROG() > function like this: > > if (place == true) { > > place = exe; > > } else if (place != false) { > > place = '"'+place +'\\'+ exe+'"'; > > } > > Or maybe a test to see if place has a trailing backslash? > > Also in config.w32.in I had to add another backslash to the single . > in the include line (also the ..\\..) > //Base includes > ADD_FLAG("CFLAGS_PHP_GTK", "/I .\\ /I ..\\ /I ..\\..\\ /I main /I ..\\main /I ext /I ..\\ext"); > > With those changes it compiles through to the dll. > It will run stock_browser.php with the release version and no crashes > > Whew :) > -- > regards, > Tom >
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] messy hack and stability
email.body:
It's an internal GTK function... we don't touch it, but it's how the thang works.
----- Original Message ----- From: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Thursday, September 08, 2005 7:49 PM Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] messy hack and stability
> WTF is gtk_label_set_uline_text_internal? > > -Andrei > > > On Sep 5, 2005, at 7:38 PM, Steph wrote: > > > I finally got GTK+ source to download (definitely bedtime now). > > Just say > > 'no' to dialup, kids... > > > > If use_underline is true and there's no mnemonic value set, > > gtk_label_set_uline_text_internal() simply returns GDK_VoidSymbol > > as the > > accelerator key. The mnemonic widget by default is the parent > > widget, i.e. > > the button or menu item containing the label. However if the label > > itself > > can't find an 'activatable ancestor' to use as a target, you get a > > warning > > beep and a bit of barfing. So it's not a good idea to have > > use_underline = > > 1 indiscriminately in things like set_text() or even in gtklabel > > (because it > > would generally find its ancestral gtkwindow, which might make for > > confusion, and because labels in gtknotebook would act completely > > differently from everywhere else), but it _is_ a good idea to apply > > it with > > discrimination, in the places where people are likely to want to > > use it more > > often than they are likely to want to escape it. > > > > So can I make that small change in the button and menuitem > > constructors and > > make PHP-GTK a tad easier to use, please? > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > From: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> > > To: "Andrei" <andrei@gravitonic.com> > > Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> > > Sent: Monday, September 05, 2005 6:43 PM > > Subject: Fw: [PHP-GTK-DEV] messy hack > > > > > > > >> OK, I looked again now and discovered the second parameter in > >> gtk_button_new. > >> > >> I think what I'm asking, then, is whether that second parameter > >> couldn't > >> > > be > > > >> made a more intuitive '1' by default, i.e. it's switch-off-able > >> but is > >> generally 'just there' in things like menu items, labels and > >> buttons using > >> the text parameter, and probably also in set_text(). > >> > >> I'm having trouble getting access to the C source for gtk+/win32 at > >> > > present, > > > >> so I've no idea whether that's going to render those widgets > >> unstable. > >> > >> It _appears_ to work without problems here for GtkButton and > >> GtkLabel. > >> > >> > >> ----- Original Message ----- > >> From: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> > >> To: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> > >> Cc: "Andrei" <andrei@gravitonic.com> > >> Sent: Sunday, September 04, 2005 4:18 PM > >> Subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] messy hack > >> > >> > >> > >>> <?php > >>> > >>> $window = new GtkWindow('Testing stuff'); > >>> $window->connect_object('destroy', array('gtk', 'main_quit')); > >>> > >>> $button = new GtkButton(''); > >>> $label = $button->child; > >>> $label->set_text_with_mnemonic('_Suck it and see'); > >>> $window->add($button); > >>> > >>> $window->show_all(); > >>> > >>> gtk::main(); > >>> > >>> ?> > >>> > >>> It took a while to understand why use_underline is TRUE by > >>> default, but > >>> > > it > > > >>> has to be better than working around it in userland. > >>> > >>> I think I can probably tackle those outstanding 'mnemonic' calls > >>> with my > >>> copy/paste skills, there are a few incidences of it already in the > >>> > > source. > > > >>> > >>> Do you have any strong feelings about that approach, Andrei? > >>> > >>> - Steph > >>> > >>> -- > >>> PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > >>> To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > >>> > >>> > >> > > > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.body:
On Fri, 9 Sep 2005, Andrei Zmievski wrote:
> I know you fixed PHP-GTK build stuff, but what about the PHP 5.1's phpize? > Doesn't it still use aclocal?
Nope. Not in any branch. PHP 4.4.0 and 5.0.5 both have phpize which doesn't use aclocal.
--Jani

----- Original Message ----- From: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> To: "Tom Rogers" <trogers@kwikin.com> Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Sunday, September 11, 2005 1:27 PM Subject: Re: Re[2]: [PHP-GTK-DEV] reduce compiler warnings (win32)
> Hi Tom, > > Hrm.. > > rem > rem Root of Visual C++ installed files. > rem > set MSVCDir=C:\PROGRA~1\MICROS~3\VC98 > > - is what goes into vcvars32.bat automatically, without me touching > anything. How come you're needing to escape whitespace? > > If you need to add a path of your own you do something like: > set MSDevDir=C:\sandbox > SET > PATH=C:\PROGRA~1\MICROS~3\VC98\BIN\;%MSDevDir%\BIN\;%MSDevDir%\php5\Release_ > TS\;%PATH% > > (and similar with the lib and include paths) > > I couldn't get jscript's substr() to work here without the length parameter, > apparently this is a known issue (not your fault, MS's). So it was adding > an extra backslash to everything. > > Does the attached work for you? (and making your env vars sane paths?) > > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Tom Rogers" <trogers@kwikin.com> > To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> > Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net>; "Andrei" > <andrei@gravitonic.com> > Sent: Sunday, September 11, 2005 9:53 AM > Subject: Re[2]: [PHP-GTK-DEV] reduce compiler warnings (win32) > > > > Hi, > > > > Sunday, September 11, 2005, 6:14:40 PM, you wrote: > > S> S'funny, I was doing that last night too (and went the > new-class-for-floats > > S> route). > > > > S> We need to test both options - both get rid of compiler warnings. > Yours is > > S> prettier. > > > > S> The other two are code-related - need to check them with Andrei. > > > > Can you also check this change needed to compile using vc6 > > > > RCS file: /repository/php-gtk/win32/confutils.js,v > > retrieving revision 1.5 > > diff -u -w -b -r1.5 confutils.js > > --- confutils.js 8 Sep 2005 03:19:44 -0000 1.5 > > +++ confutils.js 11 Sep 2005 08:50:18 -0000 > > @@ -392,7 +392,9 @@ > > if (place == true) { > > > > place = exe; > > > > } else if (place != false) { > > > > + if(place.substr(-1) != "\\") place = place+"\\" > > place = place + exe; > > > > + if(place.indexOf(' ')) place = '"'+place+'"'; > > } > > > > > > > > if (place) { > > > > > > -- > > regards, > > Tom > > > > -- > > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > > >
---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ----

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GTK2 configure error w/ OSX
email.body:
Hoping someone has a simple suggestion on this one, as it looks fine to me. When I run configure w/ PHP-GTK (latest CVS as of this afternoon) w/ PHP-5.1.0RC2 I get the following errors:
checking for PHP executable in /usr/local/bin... found version 5.1.0RC2-dev checking for gawk... (cached) awk ./configure: line 3069: syntax error near unexpected token `debug,' ./configure: line 3069: `PHP_GTK_ARG_ENABLE(debug, whether to include debugging symbols,'
Any ideas anyone?
-Jeremy
-- --------------------------- Jeremy Johnstone http://www.jeremyjohnstone.com jsjohnst@php.net

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] reduce compiler warnings (win32)
email.body:
Sorry Andrei, it's obvious to me and Tom both - I forgot you don't see them :)
One's where a counter 'i' is declared as guint in gdk.overrides - going on history, it shouldn't make any difference if that's an int, apart from killing a compiler warning.
The other's a double-to-long conversion from gtk_label_get_angle() in gtk.defs. I've no idea why that one alone should cause VC6 to complain (there are others that are also declared as 'gdouble' in GTK+ and 'gint' in our defs files and no problem) but it does. _Should_ be okay to change it back, given that it's a 'get' function....?
Tom's patch to clear up the rest of the compiler warnings definitely looks nicer than mine, and takes a completely different approach. I still need to re-run compilation with an un-patched version to figure out which functions were affected so I can make sure their behaviour isn't changed any, before committing it.
Is there any chance of your reviewing my other recent patches fairly soon, please? It's getting to the point where it's going to be fun & games sorting out the different bits prior to committing... assuming they're okay to commit at all...
- Steph
----- Original Message ----- From: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> Cc: "Tom Rogers" <trogers@kwikin.com>; "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Sunday, September 11, 2005 4:53 PM Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] reduce compiler warnings (win32)
> Which two? > > -Andrei > > > On Sep 11, 2005, at 1:14 AM, Steph wrote: > > > S'funny, I was doing that last night too (and went the new-class- > > for-floats > > route). > > > > We need to test both options - both get rid of compiler warnings. > > Yours is > > prettier. > > > > The other two are code-related - need to check them with Andrei. > > > > - Steph > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > From: "Tom Rogers" <trogers@kwikin.com> > > To: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> > > Cc: "Andrei" <andrei@gravitonic.com>; "Steph" <steph@zend.com> > > Sent: Sunday, September 11, 2005 6:01 AM > > Subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] reduce compiler warnings (win32) > > > > > > > >> Hi > >> > >> Here is a patch to get rid of compiler warnings: > >> > >> conversion from 'double ' to 'float ', possible loss of data > >> > >> RCS file: /repository/php-gtk/generator/arg_types.php,v > >> retrieving revision 1.73 > >> diff -u -w -b -r1.73 arg_types.php > >> --- arg_types.php 3 Sep 2005 19:06:12 -0000 1.73 > >> +++ arg_types.php 11 Sep 2005 04:55:00 -0000 > >> @@ -300,8 +300,11 @@ > >> $info->var_list->add('double', $name . ' = ' . > >> $default); > >> else > >> $info->var_list->add('double', $name); > >> - $info->arg_list[] = $name; > >> $info->add_parse_list('d', '&' . $name); > >> + if($type == 'gfloat') > >> + $info->arg_list[] = "(float)$name"; > >> + else > >> + $info->arg_list[] = $name; > >> } > >> > >> function write_return($type, $owns_return, $info) > >> > >> > >> Or should there be a whole new class for floats ? > >> > >> -- > >> > >> Tom > >> > >> -- > >> PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > >> To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > >> > >> > > > > -- > > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > > >
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] this time it's for real
Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] [PATCH] making GtkTextBuffer::set_text() accept single param
email.body:
Yep, we still need 's'. Let's not mash everything together.
-Andrei
On Sep 13, 2005, at 12:55 PM, Steph wrote:
> OK, I did some experimenting with codepages, 'u', 's' and stuff now. > Works > fine here - strings that get thrown out when they're 's' are converted > nicely when they're 'u'. Of course doze can't then print out the > contents > of the label correctly for debugging etc, but that's a minor > consideration. > > Wouldn't it make more sense, internally, to have the 's' > representation have > the functionality of the 'u' representation? Or are there places > where we > need 's' to mean what it normally means? > > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> > To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> > Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> > Sent: Tuesday, September 13, 2005 5:19 PM > Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] [PATCH] making GtkTextBuffer::set_text() > accept > single param > > >> Of course, UTF-8 is compatible with ASCII, so if your string argument >> happens to contain only chars in the 0-127 range, then it wouldn't be >> a >> problem. But we still need to do the conversion in case non-ASCII >> stuff >> is passed. >> >> -Andrei >> >> On Sep 12, 2005, at 3:57 PM, Steph wrote: >> >>> I recall issues with this under win32 in GTK 1, it's not an entirely >>> new >>> thing - GTK always did use utf8 strings internally. >>> >>> I haven't had any problems with plain strings on WinXP so far, but >>> then I >>> haven't really pushed the boat out either. Will do some checking >>> when >>> I've >>> more time. >>> >>> ----- Original Message ----- >>> From: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> >>> To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> >>> Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> >>> Sent: Monday, September 12, 2005 9:21 PM >>> Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] [PATCH] making GtkTextBuffer::set_text() >>> accept >>> single param >>> >>> >>>> Like I said, any text passed to Gtk+ API has to be UTF-8, so we need >>>> to >>>> use "u". And, when returning a string, we need to convert from UTF-8 >>>> to >>>> whatever codepage we have. >>>> >>>> -Andrei >>>> >>>> On Sep 12, 2005, at 1:13 PM, Steph wrote: >>>> >>>>> Thanks for that, it's helpful. >>>>> >>>>> Question is, should we be making everything 'u' now rather than >>>>> 's'? >>>>> >>>>> ----- Original Message ----- >>>>> From: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> >>>>> To: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> >>>>> Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> >>>>> Sent: Monday, September 12, 2005 6:07 PM >>>>> Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] [PATCH] making GtkTextBuffer::set_text() >>>>> accept >>>>> single param >>>>> >>>>> >>>>>> Any text passed to Gtk+ should be in UTF-8, so yes, "u" is >>>>>> appropriate. >>>>>> Don't forget to free the converted string, for example: >>>>>> >>>>>> static PHP_METHOD(Gtk, accel_map_add_entry) >>>>>> { >>>>>> char *accel_path; >>>>>> zend_bool free_accel_path; >>>>>> long accel_key; >>>>>> GdkModifierType accel_mods; >>>>>> zval *php_accel_mods = NULL; >>>>>> >>>>>> if (!php_gtk_parse_args(ZEND_NUM_ARGS(), "uiV", &accel_path, >>>>>> &free_accel_path, &accel_key, &php_accel_mods)) >>>>>> return; >>>>>> >>>>>> if (php_accel_mods && >>>>>> phpg_gvalue_get_flags(GDK_TYPE_MODIFIER_TYPE, >>>>>> php_accel_mods, (gint *)&accel_mods) == FAILURE) { >>>>>> return; >>>>>> } >>>>>> >>>>>> gtk_accel_map_add_entry(accel_path, (guint)accel_key, >>>>>> accel_mods); >>>>>> if (free_accel_path) g_free(accel_path); >>>>>> >>>>>> } >>>>>> >>>>>> -Andrei >>>>>> >>>>>> On Sep 12, 2005, at 6:52 AM, Steph wrote: >>>>>> >>>>>>> I don't have a test script for this, I just want to keep it >>>>>>> somewhere >>>>>>> safe >>>>>>> for now (and can't see any reason for it to fail). Compiles OK. >>>>>>> >>>>>>> GtkImageMenuItem's constructor represents the stock_id parameter >>>>>>> as >>>>>>> 'u' >>>>>>> (encoded string) rather than as 's' (string) - this is the only >>>>>>> place >>>>>>> in the >>>>>>> overrides where stock_id's represented that way. Should the >>>>>>> others >>>>>>> also >>>>>>> accept encoded strings, or is it a typo? >>>>>>> >>>>>>> - Steph >>>>>>> <textbuffer.txt>-- >>>>>>> PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) >>>>>>> To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >>>>>> >>>>>> -- >>>>>> PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) >>>>>> To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >>>>>> >>>> >>>> -- >>>> PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) >>>> To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >>>> >> >> -- >> PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) >> To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >>
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] #33472 [Opn]: header redirection at the middle of PHP+HTML file
email.body:
ID: 33472 User updated by: tarun27in at gmail dot com Reported By: tarun27in at gmail dot com Status: Open Bug Type: PHP-GTK related Operating System: Windows Xp PHP Version: 4.3.10 New Comment:
dude , i m already doin that way , but this is not a permanent solution in PHP , like the way u have in ASP response.redirect which does not give any header sent error there shud be something through which u can redirect even at the middle of the page withour caring for whats sent and whats not.
Anyways thanks for ur reply.
Cheers
Previous Comments: ------------------------------------------------------------------------
[2005-07-05 12:19:16] timo dot schmid at gmail dot com
This is not a Bug, this is becaus the Headers of your Page MUST been sent BEFORE you output any Text/Html. Use the following instead: <script type="text/javascript"> document.location = 'http://www.php.net'; </script>
------------------------------------------------------------------------
[2005-06-25 13:08:42] tarun27in at gmail dot com
Description: ------------ Though I m not a php guru but still i have been obsessed with a big with header location which often troubles me a lot , I often use html tags in php file as i use dreamweaver as html editor and whenever i want to redirect to some remote url in the middle of the page it always prompt me of a warning that headers already sent , i have researched a lot but didn't find any satisfactory solutions. Though i was able to redirect via javascript href tag but i think thats quite a bug as I also designed sites on ASP and response.redirect works anywhere in a file.
Just want to take in to your considerations.
thanks and regards TARUN SHARMA
------------------------------------------------------------------------
-- Edit this bug report at http://bugs.php.net/?id=33472&edit=1
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

Hi again, I found about the response.redirect that it sends a HTML-Header with a <meta> tag. If you do this AFTER outputting any data (except headers) you will get a document that is NOT valid HTML/XHTML or whatever. Not beautyful. As I think, JS is the only Possibility to make it conform.

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: [PHP-GTK] installation question
email.body:
Thanks Madeleine. I have committed these changes to CVS they should appear on the site in about a half hour or so. Andrei, Steph, Christian, etc... Madeleine reworked the Win32 installation entry in the FAQ. If you have a minute please read it over to double check that everything is ok. Thanks, Scott Madeleine D. wrote: > Scott - > > HTML page attached. I based it on the existing one, so it should be easy > to integrate to the FAQ page. > > Do we need to run this by anybody else, just to make sure the powers that > be are happy with it??? Some of the points I added are valid to both > UX/Win, but they're the kind of thing a newbie really needs to be aware of, > so I did them anyway. > > thanks > Madeleine D. > > > At 01:35 PM 6/27/05 -0400, you wrote: > > > Hi Madeleine, > > > > I have no experience with PHP-GTK on windows. If you have an updated > > answer to that question I would be happy to update that page. > > > > Thanks, > > Scott > > > > Madeleine D. wrote: > > > > > > > Scott - > > > > > > Below - from this morning's php-gen list: I think his first question is > > > coming from the FAQ page, where it lists these files belonging in the > > > Windows directory. > > > > > > http://gtk.php.net/faq.php > > > > > > Since those files no longer exist, should the page maybe be updated? > > > > > > Also - this one is probably open for discussion, but I personally disagree > > > with the recommendation that there be any files in the Win directory, > > > including php.ini. I think it works much better to isolate the whole setup > > > in a directory of its own. Maybe this could be an alternative suggestion. > > > > > > Just a thought. > > > Madeleine D. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > From: "data control" > > > > To: > > > > Date: Mon, 27 Jun 2005 18:26:30 +1000 > > > > X-MSMail-Priority: Normal > > > > X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2900.2180 > > > > X-TPG-Antivirus: Passed > > > > Subject: [PHP-GTK] installation question > > > > > > > > Hi, all > > > > I'm new to php-gtk. According to the installation instruction, I copied > > > > > > php4 to C:\php4, test in c:\php4\test and php.ini in windows. And I did the > > > association for .php with php-win.exe. I can run the test programs in test > > > folder. But there are tow problems: (1)I don't have gtk-1.3.dll, > > > tdg-1.3.dll,,, in my windows folder. Where I can get them? (2)there are > > > lots of gtk warning in a dos windows said unable to locate image in > > > pixmap_path. Please give me a help! Thank you in advance. > > > > > > > > > > Jack > > > > > > > > -- > > Scott Mattocks > > scott@crisscott.com > > http://www.crisscott.com > > http://pear.php.net/user/scottmattocks > > > > > > ------------------------------------------------------------------------ > > > > > > Frequently Asked Questions - Windows installation > >
>
> How do I install PHP-GTK on Win32? >
>

> > Download the latest binaries from href="http://gtk.php.net/download.php">gtk.php.net. The zip file contains all \ > binaries needed to run core PHP-GTK, as well as extra features such as Glade/XML \ > and Scintilla. Extract the files to a temporary directory and then copy them into \ > the following locations:

>

> For Windows 98/NT/2000/XP: >

>

In your PHP directory (e.g., c:\php4): >

    >
  • php.exe >
  • php_win.exe >
  • php-cgi.exe >
  • php.ini >
  • php.ini-gtk >
  • all .dll files >
> In a test directory (e.g., c:\php4\test): >
    >
  • all .php files >
  • testgtkrc >
  • testgtkrc2 >
  • window.xpm >

> NOTE: You can install the php.ini into your Windows > directory (i.e., c:\winnt or c:\windows) as indicated by the zip file, but it is \ > often not a good option, depending on the installation. > It is also no longer required; the php.exe (CLI version as of PHP 4.3.0) will \ > search the working directory, e.g., c:\php4, as well as the Windows directory. Or \ > you can specify your php.ini location in your command line statement with '-c' \ > option, as given in the php_win example below. >

>

> For Windows 95: > >

>

> PHP-GTK has not been tested on Windows 95 ... sorry. >


> >

> Testing the installation: >

>

When the PHP-GTK files are installed, you can verify your setup using a \ > DOS command line. A typical example would be:

>

c:\php4\php c:\php4\test\hello.php

>

>

To avoid the DOS box, you can use the php_win executable, provided in \ > the install file:

c:\php4\php_win c:\php4\test\hello.php

>

or:

>

start c:\php4\php_win c:\php4\test\hello.php

>

or:

>

c:\php4\php_win -c \php4\php.ini -f c:\php4\test\hello.php

>

(If you have installed your php.ini file in your windows directory, the -c \ > option can be dropped. For more information on command line options, see href="http://us3.php.net/manual/en/features.commandline.php">'Using PHP from the \ > command line' on the main PHP site.)

>

> Troubleshooting: >

>

If you can't produce the hello window, try the following:

>
    >
  • Verify the hello.php location, i.e., [drive:]\php4\test >
  • Open hello.php in Notepad, and make sure there is no obvious corruption to the \ > code.
  • Modify your php.ini file, to log any errors, as detailed below. >
  • Review the postings at the href="http://marc.theaimsgroup.com/?l=php-gtk-general">PHP-GTK discussion list \ > archive for possible solutions.
  • If you still have a problem, subscribe to \ > the PHP-GTK general \ > discussion list and post your question there.
> >

> Tips/Tricks: >

>
    >
  • To debug your scripts, modify the php.ini file as follows: >
      >
    • Find the line for 'log_errors'. Set it to 'On'. >
    • Find the line for 'error_log'. Remove the beginning semicolon (uncomment) and \ > replace 'filename' with an actual file location.
      Example: \ > error_log=c:\php4\error_log.txt.
    • If the error file does not exist, php will \ > create it on the next run. Open the file and review.
    >
  • If you are planning to launch on an association, decide which extension you \ > want to use for your scripts. Be aware that other applications register .php, so \ > something like .php-gtk might be a better option.
  • Check out the Code Snippets \ > and Code Hints on the PHP-GTK Wiki page. \ >
  • You can set your scripts to use Win32 themes, courtesy of Christian Weiske. \ > Check out the info page at:
    http://www.cweiske.de/phpgtk_themes.htm
  • Install the href="http://www.cweiske.de/phpgtk_apps.htm#phpgtklauncher">php-gtk launcher. \ > It handles many of the Windows directory issues and provides a series of PHP-GTK \ > icons. Also from Christian.
  • Consider using Glade/XML for setting up your \ > screens and reducing maintenance time.
    - Start with the info page at: href="http://gtk.php.net/manual/en/glade.gladexml.php">http://gtk.php.net/manual/en/glade.gladexml.php.
    \ >
    >
> >
> -- Scott Mattocks scott@crisscott.com http://www.crisscott.com http://pear.php.net/user/scottmattocks -- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] PHP-GTK manual and demo scripts coding standards [WAS: Viewport critical warnings - so
email.body:
OK - since PEAR CS already exists and is well documented, it's probably better to go with that standard for demo/bug-test scripts than to create one of our own. (Forget the fact that I don't like it.) For anyone not already aware, the standard's online at http://pear.php.net/manual/en/standards.php.
Items like Gtk::SELECTION_SINGLE really aren't pretty though - can we agree to have enums and flags upper cased throughout, as though they were constants?
I don't like Gtk::main() either - I think functions without an object should be treated as standard PHP functions, i.e. lowercased.
User-side functions and methods should be studlyCapped if we're sticking to the PEAR CS. I don't like that either, but it does at least make it very clear which functions belong to the user side and which to PHP-GTK itself. We're kind of mixed at present.
Does anyone else have strong feelings about any style issues mentioned here?
Also we need to decide where to put our Coding Standards file - should it be in php-gtk-doc or php-gtk module, or both?
(Internals is easier, everyone that contributed already went with PHP's internal CS recommendations).
- Steph
----- Original Message ----- From: "Christian Weiske" <cweiske@cweiske.de> To: "Steph Fox" <steph@zend.com> Cc: "PHP-GTK Dev list" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Monday, October 24, 2005 7:44 AM Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Viewport critical warnings - sorted
> Steph, > > > > version hot from my desktop. Beware, we don't use the same CS - maybe we > > should decide on a set at some point? I notice Jeremy has a third way... > I use full PEAR CS. > > -- > Regards/MfG, > Christian Weiske
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: [PHP-GTK] Re: Enums, flags and ::
email.body:
Hi Andrei,
> > So the question is, do enums and flags _have_ to be registered as class > > entry constants for ZE 2 to deal with them? Or is it just a matter of > > convenience? > > It's a matter of not polluting global namespace. > > > - and the next question is, assuming it's possible to register them as > > global constants, should we? > > I don't think so.
OK, in that case we're going to need to be loud and clear in the docs.
Christian: now that's established, I'm going to put in a plea for upper cased constants for gtk.php.net's CS (that's upper cased *including the classname*), on grounds of readability if nothing else.
Maybe it's due to our respective mother tongues, but I also have problems with Gtk::main() as opposed to gtk::main() - I start looking around for an object when I see 'Gtk'.
If we can come to a consensus (that means we need input from everyone affected) on those minor points, I'll put a CODING_STANDARDS file together tomorrow and we can start work on cleaning up the demo/test/manual xml files in accordance with it.
(Just call me Moshe.)
- Steph
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

Going to apply that mini-patch, will revert if it breaks anything on *nix.

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Viewport critical warnings
email.body:
The phpgtk2-demo.php produces some really bad warnings and sometimes crashes just from scrolling: Open phpgtk2-demo.php, switch to the "Demo" tab. Select another demo. Select the buttonbox demo again. Scroll. Your shell will be flooded with messages as ---------------- (phpgtk2-demo.php:9803): Gtk-CRITICAL **: gtk_viewport_adjustment_value_changed: assertion `GTK_IS_VIEWPORT (data)' failed ---------------- and sometimes even crash php-gtk with a segmentation fault.
Maybe it's because the demo widget isn't destroyed after a new one is loaded, but that should be done automatically by php.
-- Regards/MfG, Christian Weiske
["signature.asc" (application/pgp-signature)]

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Enums, flags and ::
email.body:
Before it's too late (assuming it isn't already): Is there any way we can return enums/flags to the standard GTK format, as they were in PHP-GTK 1?
If you remember that far back, I spent more than a day trying to work out what I was doing wrong when every enum in sight failed in an old script I upgraded to PHP-GTK 2. I don't think I'm going to be the only scriptkiddie baffled by that change.
It's also the one area Christian and I can't come to an agreement over in our coding standards discussions, because what _should_ be a constant is being treated as some kind of a pseudo-method, which makes either approach inconsistent by definition.
I know it'd be a BC breakage for PHP-GTK 2 to change this now, but then again we haven't released v. 2 yet. At present it's a BC breakage for PHP-GTK 1, which is probably more serious.
So the question is, do enums and flags _have_ to be registered as class entry constants for ZE 2 to deal with them? Or is it just a matter of convenience?
- and the next question is, assuming it's possible to register them as global constants, should we?
- Steph
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Fw: [PHP-GTK] ext/libglade complete?
Fw: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Fw: [PHP-GTK] ext/libglade complete?
email.body:
OK, so there's no way to pass arbitrary data from within glade files. Groovy.
I've been looking at other languages to see how they've resolved the signal_autoconnect() problem, and they _all_ have different ways. Perl's version has three separate functions for signal_autoconnect(), two of which are 'convenience functions'.... heck, even libglade only has two...
We've the choice of implementing signal_autoconnect_full() (which is libglade's own solution to the dilemma) or else doing more or less as you did before. I really don't like this array('gladefile_callback' => array('php_callback', $data)...) set-up - my initial instinct was to kill that 'php_callback', but then Christian won't get his $this. It'd be nice to make that 'php_callback' element an optional array - it shouldn't ever be used unless it _is_ an array, if that were the case.
Thoughts?
/me gets on with it
----- Original Message ----- From: "Steph Fox" <steph@zend.com> To: "Andrei" <andrei@gravitonic.com> Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Sunday, October 30, 2005 5:09 PM Subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Fw: [PHP-GTK] ext/libglade complete?
> OK, I see what you mean now. It's ugly, though - it makes a lot of > unnecessary work, mapping every callback manually. The whole point of > signal_autoconnect() is supposed to be that you don't need to do that. From > source: > > /* > * use gmodule to connect signals automatically. Basically a symbol with > * the name of the signal handler is searched for, and that is connected to > * the associated symbols. So setting gtk_main_quit as a signal handler > * for the destroy signal of a window will do what you expect. > */ > void glade_xml_signal_autoconnect (GladeXML *self); > > /* if the gtk_signal_connect_object behaviour is required, connect_object > * will point to the object, otherwise it will be NULL. > > > I'll see if I can find a nicer way around it than we had in PHP-GTK 1 and > keep to the spirit of the original. The marshal appears to allow user data > to be passed, but I need to figure out how user data is specified in Glade. > > - Steph > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Steph Fox" <steph@zend.com> > To: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> > Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> > Sent: Sunday, October 30, 2005 4:08 PM > Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK] ext/libglade complete? > > > > Andrei, hi, > > > > 1. Thanks :) I really couldn't see how that was supposed to work. > > 2. signal_autoconnect() will take an object instance specified via Glade > > (e.g. 'button3'). It calls connect_object() for those calls, and > connect() > > for the rest. Same goes for *_after(). We don't need it to do any more > > than that. Glade 2 itself doesn't offer further connect_* alternatives, > so > > to offer anything further would lead to users having to alter the XML file > > manually. > > 3. I'm not 100% certain what you mean here, but I'll look into it. > > > > Thanks for reviewing the code, > > > > - Steph > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > From: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> > > To: "Steph Fox" <steph@zend.com> > > Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> > > Sent: Sunday, October 30, 2005 12:57 AM > > Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK] ext/libglade complete? > > > > > > > Hi, > > > > > > I sat down and looked at the libglade extension implementation, > > > especially the signal connection functions. I have a few comments. > > > > > > 1. I'll take care of custom widget handlers. It requires implementing > > > our own GObject subclass. > > > 2. It will be useful to have a signal_autoconnect_object() method > > > that can take an object instance and auto-connect the glade handlers > > > to the methods of the class. > > > 3. The current implementation of signal_autoconnect() supposedly > > > takes additional user data to pass to callbacks, but it passes the > > > *same* data to every callback. If you look at how it worked in PHP- > > > GTK-1, you will see that it was a lot more flexible: > > > > > > http://gtk.php.net/manual/en/ > > > glade.gladexml.method.signal_autoconnect.php > > > > > > 4. I am not sure how useful it is to be able to supply callbacks in > > > the "class::method" form. It only allows you to invoke static methods > > > of the class. Working with an object instance is a lot more useful > > > (see comment #2). > > > > > > 5. Why do we have this: > > > > > > if (strcmp(php_class, "gtk") == 0 || strcmp(php_class, > > > "gdk") == 0) { > > > gtk_flag = 1; > > > } > > > > > > Assuming we want to keep the "class::method" callback > > > functionality, why do we need to explicitly check for 'gtk' and > > > 'gdk'? What about 'pango', 'atk', and everything else? > > > > > > That's it so far. > > > > > > -Andrei > > > > > > > > > On Oct 21, 2005, at 7:20 AM, Steph Fox wrote: > > > > > > > Hi all, > > > > > > > > I think I just finished work on the libglade extension. > > > > > > > > There are two functions I don't know whether to implement. > > > > > > > > One is GladeXML::new_from_buffer(), which replaces Glade 1's > > > > new_from_memory(). Does anyone (or _has_ anyone) actually tried > > > > using this? > > > > If there's any demand for it at all, I'll need a test script > > > > demonstrating > > > > its usage. It doesn't need to be written in PHP. > > > > > > > > The other is glade::set_custom_handler(). This appears to be > > > > intended for > > > > advance usage, and I'm not sure how useful it is outside C, but > > > > again - if > > > > anyone's used it in any language _other_ than C, I'll implement it if > > > > there's a) demand and b) a test script available demonstrating the > > > > way in > > > > which it is used. > > > > > > > > Four functions will never be implemented. These are > > > > GladeXML::signal_connect_data() because we don't need it, the > > > > *_connect_full() methods aren't intended for use other than > > > > internally, and > > > > the GladeXML::construct() method - a hangover from GtkObject - > > > > isn't useful > > > > other than internally. > > > > > > > > Everything else should work as advertised - please test! Bug > > > > reports to > > > > http://bugs.php.net in the PHP-GTK section. > > > > > > > > Thanks, > > > > > > > > - Steph > > > > > > > > ps win32 implementation and short test script - > > > > http://ftp.emini.dk/pub/php/win32/gtk2/php-gtk2-patched.zip > > > > > > > > -- > > > > PHP-GTK General Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > > > > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > > > > > > > > > > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >
