email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Fw: [PHP-GTK] ext/libglade complete?
email.body:
On Oct 30, 2005, at 9:09 AM, Steph Fox wrote:
> OK, I see what you mean now. It's ugly, though - it makes a lot of > unnecessary work, mapping every callback manually. The whole point of > signal_autoconnect() is supposed to be that you don't need to do > that. From > source: > > /* > * use gmodule to connect signals automatically. Basically a > symbol with > * the name of the signal handler is searched for, and that is > connected to > * the associated symbols. So setting gtk_main_quit as a signal > handler > * for the destroy signal of a window will do what you expect. > */ > void glade_xml_signal_autoconnect (GladeXML *self);
I _know_ what signal_autoconnect() is supposed to be. If you notice, the argument to the function in PHP-GTK is optional. If you don't specify it, then signal_autoconnect() looks in the function table to find the callbacks. The argument is mainly so you can remap certain handlers to specific function calls that are named different and/or pass custom user data.
> I'll see if I can find a nicer way around it than we had in PHP-GTK > 1 and > keep to the spirit of the original. The marshal appears to allow > user data > to be passed, but I need to figure out how user data is specified > in Glade.
I don't think it will be possible. A lot of times the user data is dynamic, depending on what happened in the script before that, and Glade pretty much lets you specify only static data.
-Andrei
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Fw: [PHP-GTK] ext/libglade complete?
email.body:
On Oct 30, 2005, at 10:59 AM, Steph Fox wrote:
> OK, so there's no way to pass arbitrary data from within glade files. > Groovy. > > I've been looking at other languages to see how they've resolved the > signal_autoconnect() problem, and they _all_ have different ways. > Perl's > version has three separate functions for signal_autoconnect(), two > of which > are 'convenience functions'.... heck, even libglade only has two... > > We've the choice of implementing signal_autoconnect_full() (which is > libglade's own solution to the dilemma) or else doing more or less > as you > did before. I really don't like this array('gladefile_callback' => > array('php_callback', $data)...) set-up - my initial instinct was > to kill > that 'php_callback', but then Christian won't get his $this. It'd > be nice > to make that 'php_callback' element an optional array - it > shouldn't ever be > used unless it _is_ an array, if that were the case.
What's really wrong with it?
signal_autoconnect('gladefile_callback' => array('my_callback', $my_data));
This will allow you to re-map a callback in .glade file to a PHP callback. If there are other callbacks specified in the .glade file, then they will be connected automatically to the functions of the same name. I don't see what's so horrible about this.
-Andrei
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Fw: [PHP-GTK] ext/libglade complete?
email.body:
> > did before. I really don't like this array('gladefile_callback' => > > array('php_callback', $data)...) set-up - my initial instinct was > > to kill > > that 'php_callback', but then Christian won't get his $this. It'd > > be nice > > to make that 'php_callback' element an optional array - it > > shouldn't ever be > > used unless it _is_ an array, if that were the case. > > What's really wrong with it? > > signal_autoconnect('gladefile_callback' => array('my_callback', > $my_data)); > > This will allow you to re-map a callback in .glade file to a PHP > callback. If there are other callbacks specified in the .glade file, > then they will be connected automatically to the functions of the > same name. I don't see what's so horrible about this.
What's really wrong with it is that it encourages name changing. That parameter should only be used if there's a reason for it, i.e. if you want to have array($this, 'gladefile_callback'); in there. The rest of the time, why type extra stuff?
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Fw: [PHP-GTK] ext/libglade complete?
email.body:
On Oct 30, 2005, at 11:46 AM, Steph Fox wrote:
>> >> What's really wrong with it? >> >> signal_autoconnect('gladefile_callback' => array('my_callback', >> $my_data)); >> >> This will allow you to re-map a callback in .glade file to a PHP >> callback. If there are other callbacks specified in the .glade file, >> then they will be connected automatically to the functions of the >> same name. I don't see what's so horrible about this. >> > > What's really wrong with it is that it encourages name changing. That > parameter should only be used if there's a reason for it, i.e. if > you want > to have array($this, 'gladefile_callback'); in there. The rest of > the time, > why type extra stuff?
Sure. Most of the time you won't even need that parameter, and hell, if you just want to add some user data to a callback, maybe the first entry in the array is 'null' instead of callback name, so the callback gets hooked up to the function of the same name.
- Andrei
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: [PHP-GTK] ext/libglade complete?
email.body:
That email was too long, I missed 4 and 5 :)
4. I'd dispute that. It's useful to people like Christian (who in fact asked for it), because his code is primarily object oriented. Look at zend_is_callable_ex() in the Zend Engine (you probably wrote it) - it checks for static calls. It also checks specifically for self:: and parent::.
5. What else has static methods that we're likely to want to use in a callback?
----- Original Message ----- From: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> To: "Steph Fox" <steph@zend.com> Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Sunday, October 30, 2005 12:57 AM Subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: [PHP-GTK] ext/libglade complete?
> Hi, > > I sat down and looked at the libglade extension implementation, > especially the signal connection functions. I have a few comments. > > 1. I'll take care of custom widget handlers. It requires implementing > our own GObject subclass. > 2. It will be useful to have a signal_autoconnect_object() method > that can take an object instance and auto-connect the glade handlers > to the methods of the class. > 3. The current implementation of signal_autoconnect() supposedly > takes additional user data to pass to callbacks, but it passes the > *same* data to every callback. If you look at how it worked in PHP- > GTK-1, you will see that it was a lot more flexible: > > http://gtk.php.net/manual/en/ > glade.gladexml.method.signal_autoconnect.php > > 4. I am not sure how useful it is to be able to supply callbacks in > the "class::method" form. It only allows you to invoke static methods > of the class. Working with an object instance is a lot more useful > (see comment #2). > > 5. Why do we have this: > > if (strcmp(php_class, "gtk") == 0 || strcmp(php_class, > "gdk") == 0) { > gtk_flag = 1; > } > > Assuming we want to keep the "class::method" callback > functionality, why do we need to explicitly check for 'gtk' and > 'gdk'? What about 'pango', 'atk', and everything else? > > That's it so far. > > -Andrei > > > On Oct 21, 2005, at 7:20 AM, Steph Fox wrote: > > > Hi all, > > > > I think I just finished work on the libglade extension. > > > > There are two functions I don't know whether to implement. > > > > One is GladeXML::new_from_buffer(), which replaces Glade 1's > > new_from_memory(). Does anyone (or _has_ anyone) actually tried > > using this? > > If there's any demand for it at all, I'll need a test script > > demonstrating > > its usage. It doesn't need to be written in PHP. > > > > The other is glade::set_custom_handler(). This appears to be > > intended for > > advance usage, and I'm not sure how useful it is outside C, but > > again - if > > anyone's used it in any language _other_ than C, I'll implement it if > > there's a) demand and b) a test script available demonstrating the > > way in > > which it is used. > > > > Four functions will never be implemented. These are > > GladeXML::signal_connect_data() because we don't need it, the > > *_connect_full() methods aren't intended for use other than > > internally, and > > the GladeXML::construct() method - a hangover from GtkObject - > > isn't useful > > other than internally. > > > > Everything else should work as advertised - please test! Bug > > reports to > > http://bugs.php.net in the PHP-GTK section. > > > > Thanks, > > > > - Steph > > > > ps win32 implementation and short test script - > > http://ftp.emini.dk/pub/php/win32/gtk2/php-gtk2-patched.zip > > > > -- > > PHP-GTK General Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > > > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: [PHP-GTK] ext/libglade complete?
email.body:
> We're all getting confused here, partly because I don't have Glade2 > installed yet, I think. When you talk about "object instance > specified via Glade ('button'3)", are you talking about a widget > named 'button3'? If so, it has nothing to do with what I suggested, > which is being able to easily connect a bunch of callbacks to methods > of a PHP object. Like this: > > class MyApp { > > function on_ok_clicked($button) { ... } > function on_notebook_switched_page($notebook, $page) { ... } > function on_destroy($widget) { ... } > > } > > $app = new MyApp(); > > $glade = new GladeXML($file); > $glade->signal_autoconnect_object($app); > > Now everything is connected to the methods of that object.
Thing 1, which you won't know yet because you don't have the code handy, is there is no such thing as signal_autoconnect_object() in libglade now. signal_autoconnect() does it all.
Thing 2 is that there's already a way to achieve this. I don't see what's so problematic about having a callback in the Glade file called 'MyApp::on_ok_clicked'... if you have some issue with the callbacks being public you can just move the whole lot, including the call to gtk::main(), inside the class and use self:: instead. What am I missing here?
Thing 3 is that there's no precedent for that syntax. Doesn't mean it couldn't be done, but _should_ it be done? - personally I think not, given that you were right about the need for the optional array parameter to pass data. The main problems with the signal_autoconnect() function are the ones I'm working on addressing now.
- Steph
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

Dunno. It's clever internals stuff. It works :)
> > 5. What else has static methods that we're likely to want to use in a > > callback? > > Any other extension, possibly.
OK, so what should I be checking for there?
- Steph

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: [PHP-GTK] ext/libglade complete?
email.body:
Steph,
> Thing 2 is that there's already a way to achieve this. I don't see what's > so problematic about having a callback in the Glade file called > 'MyApp::on_ok_clicked'... if you have some issue with the callbacks being > public you can just move the whole lot, including the call to gtk::main(), > inside the class and use self:: instead. What am I missing here?
The problematic thing is that a /static/ function is called, not the one of the object instance. I don't need static calls, because programming object oriented means having *objects* and not only stateless functions which are defined in a class by accident.
-- Regards/MfG, Christian Weiske
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: [PHP-GTK] ext/libglade complete?
email.body:
On Oct 30, 2005, at 11:36 AM, Steph Fox wrote:
> Thing 1, which you won't know yet because you don't have the code > handy, is > there is no such thing as signal_autoconnect_object() in libglade now. > signal_autoconnect() does it all.
<groan>
Of course there is no such API in Glade. I just sat on my ass, stared at the ceiling tiles for a bit, and invented it. Is that so wrong? Besides, signal_autoconnect() in Glade is C, which means that it only looks at the C level functions.
> Thing 2 is that there's already a way to achieve this. I don't see > what's > so problematic about having a callback in the Glade file called > 'MyApp::on_ok_clicked'... if you have some issue with the callbacks > being > public you can just move the whole lot, including the call to > gtk::main(), > inside the class and use self:: instead. What am I missing here?
The issue with 'MyApp::on_ok_clicked' is that you are required to know the name of the implementing class in PHP during implementation of your Glade interface. That sucks. The issue with self::, well, I still need to see what self:: resolves to during signal_autoconnect() call. I'm building Glade2 right now so I can try it out.
> Thing 3 is that there's no precedent for that syntax. Doesn't mean it > couldn't be done, but _should_ it be done? - personally I think > not, given > that you were right about the need for the optional array parameter > to pass > data. The main problems with the signal_autoconnect() function are > the ones > I'm working on addressing now.
Is there precedence for 'MyApp::callback' syntax? If you are not happy about having a separate signal_autoconnect_object() method, it wouldn't be that hard to modify signal_autoconnect() to check whether it got an object instance as the first parameter, and if so, hook up the callbacks to it. I prefer to have a separate function because it's cleaner.
- Andrei
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: [PHP-GTK] ext/libglade complete?
email.body:
Hi,
I sat down and looked at the libglade extension implementation, especially the signal connection functions. I have a few comments.
1. I'll take care of custom widget handlers. It requires implementing our own GObject subclass. 2. It will be useful to have a signal_autoconnect_object() method that can take an object instance and auto-connect the glade handlers to the methods of the class. 3. The current implementation of signal_autoconnect() supposedly takes additional user data to pass to callbacks, but it passes the *same* data to every callback. If you look at how it worked in PHP- GTK-1, you will see that it was a lot more flexible:
http://gtk.php.net/manual/en/ glade.gladexml.method.signal_autoconnect.php
4. I am not sure how useful it is to be able to supply callbacks in the "class::method" form. It only allows you to invoke static methods of the class. Working with an object instance is a lot more useful (see comment #2).
5. Why do we have this:
if (strcmp(php_class, "gtk") == 0 || strcmp(php_class, "gdk") == 0) { gtk_flag = 1; }
Assuming we want to keep the "class::method" callback functionality, why do we need to explicitly check for 'gtk' and 'gdk'? What about 'pango', 'atk', and everything else?
That's it so far.
-Andrei
On Oct 21, 2005, at 7:20 AM, Steph Fox wrote:
> Hi all, > > I think I just finished work on the libglade extension. > > There are two functions I don't know whether to implement. > > One is GladeXML::new_from_buffer(), which replaces Glade 1's > new_from_memory(). Does anyone (or _has_ anyone) actually tried > using this? > If there's any demand for it at all, I'll need a test script > demonstrating > its usage. It doesn't need to be written in PHP. > > The other is glade::set_custom_handler(). This appears to be > intended for > advance usage, and I'm not sure how useful it is outside C, but > again - if > anyone's used it in any language _other_ than C, I'll implement it if > there's a) demand and b) a test script available demonstrating the > way in > which it is used. > > Four functions will never be implemented. These are > GladeXML::signal_connect_data() because we don't need it, the > *_connect_full() methods aren't intended for use other than > internally, and > the GladeXML::construct() method - a hangover from GtkObject - > isn't useful > other than internally. > > Everything else should work as advertised - please test! Bug > reports to > http://bugs.php.net in the PHP-GTK section. > > Thanks, > > - Steph > > ps win32 implementation and short test script - > http://ftp.emini.dk/pub/php/win32/gtk2/php-gtk2-patched.zip > > -- > PHP-GTK General Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: [PHP-GTK] ext/libglade complete?
email.body:
> 4. I am not sure how useful it is to be able to supply callbacks in the > "class::method" form. It only allows you to invoke static methods of > the class. Working with an object instance is a lot more useful (see > comment #2). That's what has been my original intention, but Steph said it's impossible.
-- Regards/MfG, Christian Weiske

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: [PHP-GTK] ext/libglade complete?
email.body:
Andrei, hi,
1. Thanks :) I really couldn't see how that was supposed to work. 2. signal_autoconnect() will take an object instance specified via Glade (e.g. 'button3'). It calls connect_object() for those calls, and connect() for the rest. Same goes for *_after(). We don't need it to do any more than that. Glade 2 itself doesn't offer further connect_* alternatives, so to offer anything further would lead to users having to alter the XML file manually. 3. I'm not 100% certain what you mean here, but I'll look into it.
Thanks for reviewing the code,
- Steph

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: [PHP-GTK] ext/libglade complete?
email.body:
> On Oct 30, 2005, at 11:36 AM, Steph Fox wrote: > > > Thing 1, which you won't know yet because you don't have the code > > handy, is > > there is no such thing as signal_autoconnect_object() in libglade now. > > signal_autoconnect() does it all. > > <groan> > > Of course there is no such API in Glade. I just sat on my ass, stared > at the ceiling tiles for a bit, and invented it. Is that so wrong? > Besides, signal_autoconnect() in Glade is C, which means that it only > looks at the C level functions.
It's wrong, because the object being passed is defined in the Glade file...
> > Thing 2 is that there's already a way to achieve this. I don't see > > what's > > so problematic about having a callback in the Glade file called > > 'MyApp::on_ok_clicked'... if you have some issue with the callbacks > > being > > public you can just move the whole lot, including the call to > > gtk::main(), > > inside the class and use self:: instead. What am I missing here? > > The issue with 'MyApp::on_ok_clicked' is that you are required to > know the name of the implementing class in PHP during implementation > of your Glade interface. That sucks. The issue with self::, well, I > still need to see what self:: resolves to during signal_autoconnect() > call. I'm building Glade2 right now so I can try it out.
Yes, sorry, I didn't realise that was a serious question. Having to download PHP 5.1 from scratch over a very slow connection at present so I can find out. (I broke it somehow, don't ask.)
> > Thing 3 is that there's no precedent for that syntax. Doesn't mean it > > couldn't be done, but _should_ it be done? - personally I think > > not, given > > that you were right about the need for the optional array parameter > > to pass > > data. The main problems with the signal_autoconnect() function are > > the ones > > I'm working on addressing now. > > Is there precedence for 'MyApp::callback' syntax? If you are not > happy about having a separate signal_autoconnect_object() method, it > wouldn't be that hard to modify signal_autoconnect() to check whether > it got an object instance as the first parameter, and if so, hook up > the callbacks to it. > I prefer to have a separate function because it's cleaner.
Yes, I'm thinking that way now too.
- Steph

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: [PHP-GTK] ext/libglade complete?
email.body:
Well, I wanted to try it first and see if it was a stupid idea or a brainwave - sometimes it's hard for me to tell the difference y'know :)
The main thing is to force connect_object to be used internally for classes, right? And they're always going to be static calls, ie they'll be fed to ZE as arrays, so spotting them's straightforward. The bit I'm not sure about is whether self:: and parent:: need to call connect_object too...

>> <groan> >> >> Of course there is no such API in Glade. I just sat on my ass, stared >> at the ceiling tiles for a bit, and invented it. Is that so wrong? >> Besides, signal_autoconnect() in Glade is C, which means that it only >> looks at the C level functions. >> > > It's wrong, because the object being passed is defined in the Glade > file...

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: [PHP-GTK] ext/libglade complete?
email.body:
no, no, no, no. no. no-no.
The only time connect_object is passed to you, is when your Glade widget says that yes, here is a callback, but please pass this other widget as the first argument instead of me. That's it. It has nothing to do with calling static methods or not.
-Andrei

email.subject: Fw: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: [PHP-GTK] ext/libglade complete?
email.body:
> > Is there precedence for 'MyApp::callback' syntax? If you are not > > happy about having a separate signal_autoconnect_object() method, it > > wouldn't be that hard to modify signal_autoconnect() to check whether > > it got an object instance as the first parameter, and if so, hook up > > the callbacks to it. > > I prefer to have a separate function because it's cleaner. > > Yes, I'm thinking that way now too.
Erm, wait, I just realized what you meant by that.
No, it's not cleaner, because of the way Glade works. In PHP-GTK 1, if you set up the object to be passed in Glade it never worked, because signal_autoconnect() didn't recognise it. This way, it does work, and signal_autoconnect() caters for four separate kinds of signals. Its only problems are a) passing data and b) connecting to a callback defined within a class, non-statically.
I think it would be sensible to have a separate function that passed an object as first parameter if you wanted to be able to access callbacks within that class, and data mapping as a second parameter. I don't think it would be a good idea to call it signal_autoconnect_object() though, because that means something other.
- Steph
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.body:
> > Erm, wait, I just realized what you meant by that. > > > > No, it's not cleaner, because of the way Glade works. In PHP-GTK > > 1, if you > > set up the object to be passed in Glade it never worked, because > > signal_autoconnect() didn't recognise it. > > PHP-GTK 1 only cared about functions, really. > > > This way, it does work, and > > signal_autoconnect() caters for four separate kinds of signals. > > Its only > > problems are a) passing data and b) connecting to a callback > > defined within > > a class, non-statically. > > I'm still not sure what you're talking about here, "four separate > kinds of signals". I think it may be best if I just re-implement > signal_autoconnect() and take a vote on the implementation.
connect(), connect_after(), connect_object() and connect_object_after() are the types of signals that can be created from within Glade. Please don't mess with that, it's the first time it's worked properly!
> > I think it would be sensible to have a separate function that > > passed an > > object as first parameter if you wanted to be able to access callbacks > > within that class, and data mapping as a second parameter. I don't > > think it > > would be a good idea to call it signal_autoconnect_object() though, > > because > > that means something other. > > Ok, I definitely need to reimplement it now. Build faster, Glade2!
Huh?
> > - Andrei
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Weird behaviour with declared PHP classes and GDK drawing functions
Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Enums, flags and ::
email.body:
Steph,
> Before it's too late (assuming it isn't already): Is there any way we can > return enums/flags to the standard GTK format, as they were in PHP-GTK 1? I vote against it. I don't know how much php-gtk1 programs are out there, but I doubt that there are thousands of them. The programs need to be changed anyway, so they can change the enums, too.
> So the question is, do enums and flags _have_ to be registered as class > entry constants for ZE 2 to deal with them? Or is it just a matter of > convenience? I even had the idea to not only register them under Gtk:: and Gdk::, but even make extra classes just for the enums, e.g. GtkState::ACTIVE.
-- Regards/MfG, Christian Weiske
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Enums, flags and ::
email.body:
> > Before it's too late (assuming it isn't already): Is there any way we can > > return enums/flags to the standard GTK format, as they were in PHP-GTK 1? > I vote against it. I don't know how much php-gtk1 programs are out > there, but I doubt that there are thousands of them. > The programs need to be changed anyway, so they can change the enums, too.
Mm, I was just feeling the temperature...
> > So the question is, do enums and flags _have_ to be registered as class > > entry constants for ZE 2 to deal with them? Or is it just a matter of > > convenience? > I even had the idea to not only register them under Gtk:: and Gdk::, but > even make extra classes just for the enums, e.g. GtkState::ACTIVE.
Noooooooooooooo! That's UGLY!
> -- > Regards/MfG, > Christian Weiske

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Enums, flags and ::
email.body:
Steph -
I hit the same thing on my upgrade attempt.
Christian's right, in that I see so much that needs to be changed already, the Enums/Flags would be just one more thing to do. Since I've got about 40k of code, that's no small thing, but it's not fatal either.
My question is: why do they need to change? What is being gained here?
Madeleine D.
At 04:50 PM 10/25/05 +0100, Steph Fox wrote: >Before it's too late (assuming it isn't already): Is there any way we can >return enums/flags to the standard GTK format, as they were in PHP-GTK 1? > >If you remember that far back, I spent more than a day trying to work out >what I was doing wrong when every enum in sight failed in an old script I >upgraded to PHP-GTK 2. I don't think I'm going to be the only scriptkiddie >baffled by that change. > >It's also the one area Christian and I can't come to an agreement over in >our coding standards discussions, because what _should_ be a constant is >being treated as some kind of a pseudo-method, which makes either approach >inconsistent by definition. > >I know it'd be a BC breakage for PHP-GTK 2 to change this now, but then >again we haven't released v. 2 yet. At present it's a BC breakage for >PHP-GTK 1, which is probably more serious. > >So the question is, do enums and flags _have_ to be registered as class >entry constants for ZE 2 to deal with them? Or is it just a matter of >convenience? > >- and the next question is, assuming it's possible to register them as >global constants, should we? > >- Steph > >-- >PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) >To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > >
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Enums, flags and ::
email.body:
Hi Madeleine,
It's down to PHP 5/Zend Engine 2's object support. We didn't have this in PHP 4, so the bindings were made via GtkEnumType and we had the same syntax as in GTK+.
Basically all it means is that something like, say, GTK_WIN_POS_MOUSE, is now registered as a constant named WIN_POS_MOUSE within a zend_class_entry struct named GTK.
I have to say it makes absolute sense to do it this way from an internals perspective - much cleaner, and probably faster when it comes to lookups - it's just a bit of a thrower on the user side.
- Steph

Since I've got about > 40k of code, that's no small thing, but it's not fatal either. > > My question is: why do they need to change? I don't think I'm going to be the only scriptkiddie > >baffled by that change. > > > >It's also the one area Christian and I can't come to an agreement over in > >our coding standards discussions, because what _should_ be a constant is > >being treated as some kind of a pseudo-method, which makes either approach > >inconsistent by definition. > > > >I know it'd be a BC breakage for PHP-GTK 2 to change this now, but then > >again we haven't released v. 2 yet. At present it's a BC breakage for > >PHP-GTK 1, which is probably more serious. > > > >So the question is, do enums and flags _have_ to be registered as class > >entry constants for ZE 2 to deal with them? Or is it just a matter of > >convenience? > > > >- and the next question is, assuming it's possible to register them as > >global constants, should we? > > > >- Steph > > > >-- > >PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > >To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > > > >

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Enums, flags and ::
email.body:
Actually, looking up GTK_WIN_POS_MOUSE is faster than Gtk::WIN_POS_MOUSE, but not by that much. My main goal was to separate things cleanly, so that the global namespace doesn't contain all the constants. If you think that this is not something we should worry about, I guess we can put the constants back into the global scope.
-Andrei

> constants. If you think that this is not something we should worry > about, I guess we can put the constants back into the global scope. I think we should worry about that, and it's more beautiful the new way. Don't put it back to global scope, please. -- Regards/MfG, Christian Weiske
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Enums, flags and ::
email.body:
Hi Andrei,
See what you mean - I hadn't gone as far as actually looking at the code, just assumed you were accessing the GEnumValue directly without reference to the GEnumClass somehow. (Don't ask, it's Tuesday, my brain doesn't kick in til Thursday night.)
What's the deal about global scope? OK there could be namespace collisions - but on the other hand those are GTK+ constants, easily recognisable and AFAIK used everywhere that uses GTK+. It'd have to be a very 'newbie' error to name a local constant GTK_*, given that scenario.
If it's trivial to go back to global scope and doesn't have any god-awful side-effects, I for one would very much like to see it happen.
Thanks,
- Steph

Since I've got > >> about > >> 40k of code, that's no small thing, but it's not fatal either. > >> > >> My question is: why do they need to change? What is being gained > >> here? > >> > >> Madeleine D. > >> > >> > >> > >> At 04:50 PM 10/25/05 +0100, Steph Fox wrote: > >>> Before it's too late (assuming it isn't already): Is there any way > >>> we can > >>> return enums/flags to the standard GTK format, as they were in > >>> PHP-GTK 1? > >>> > >>> If you remember that far back, I spent more than a day trying to > >>> work out > >>> what I was doing wrong when every enum in sight failed in an old > >>> script I > >>> upgraded to PHP-GTK 2. I don't think I'm going to be the only > > scriptkiddie > >>> baffled by that change. > >>> > >>> It's also the one area Christian and I can't come to an agreement > >>> over in > >>> our coding standards discussions, because what _should_ be a > >>> constant is > >>> being treated as some kind of a pseudo-method, which makes either > > approach > >>> inconsistent by definition. > >>> > >>> I know it'd be a BC breakage for PHP-GTK 2 to change this now, but > >>> then > >>> again we haven't released v. 2 yet. At present it's a BC breakage > >>> for > >>> PHP-GTK 1, which is probably more serious. > >>> > >>> So the question is, do enums and flags _have_ to be registered as > >>> class > >>> entry constants for ZE 2 to deal with them? Or is it just a matter > >>> of > >>> convenience? > >>> > >>> - and the next question is, assuming it's possible to register them > >>> as > >>> global constants, should we? > >>> > >>> - Steph > >>> > >>> -- > >>> PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > >>> To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > >>> > >>> >
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Enums, flags and ::
email.body:
On Oct 25, 2005, at 1:04 PM, Steph Fox wrote:
> What's the deal about global scope? OK there could be namespace > collisions - but on the other hand those are GTK+ constants, easily > recognisable and AFAIK used everywhere that uses GTK+. It'd have to > be a > very 'newbie' error to name a local constant GTK_*, given that > scenario.
What about GDK_*? PANGO_*? ATK_*? GLADE_*? SOMEOTHEREXTENSION_*? How will this look when all the extensions register their constants globally?
-Andrei
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Enums, flags and ::
email.body:
Christian -
... 'worry about that' how? Back to my original question - what's the benefit?
Madeleine D.
At 09:46 PM 10/25/05 +0200, Christian Weiske wrote: > >> constants. If you think that this is not something we should worry >> about, I guess we can put the constants back into the global scope. >I think we should worry about that, and it's more beautiful the new way. >Don't put it back to global scope, please. >-- >Regards/MfG, >Christian Weiske > >-- >PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) >To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > >
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Enums, flags and ::
email.body:
Andrei Zmievski wrote: > On Oct 25, 2005, at 1:04 PM, Steph Fox wrote: > >> What's the deal about global scope? OK there could be namespace >> collisions - but on the other hand those are GTK+ constants, easily >> recognisable and AFAIK used everywhere that uses GTK+. It'd have to be a >> very 'newbie' error to name a local constant GTK_*, given that scenario. > > What about GDK_*? PANGO_*? ATK_*? GLADE_*? SOMEOTHEREXTENSION_*? How > will this look when all the extensions register their constants globally?
Personally, I like having everything separated out by extension. I think Gtk::SOME_CONSTANT is cleaner than GTK_SOME_CONSTANT. (Please note my not so subtle vote for Gtk as opposed to GTK) I don't think that sticking with Gtk+ style is a valid argument. By that argument we should have the same function calls to. I don't think anyone wants to have gtk_tree_view_get_selection() instead of $treeView->get_selection().
I don't think the scope of a constant matters much to the end user. No matter what scope a constant is in, it should behave the same. I think this needs to be addressed from a PHP-GTK programmer's readability point of view and I just think that Gtk:: is easier to read and follow than GTK_.
Scott
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Enums, flags and ::
email.body:
Madeleine,
> ... 'worry about that' how? Back to my original question > - what's the > benefit?
Worry and benefit: If you register all constants globally, you pollute the global namespace like Andrei said. So if you want to debug something and need to check if a given constant is registered globally, you will have to dig through the gtk constants to find yours.
-- Regards/MfG, Christian Weiske
["signature.asc" (application/pgp-signature)]

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Enums, flags and ::
email.body:
Hey Scott,
The readability point of view's where we started. Unfortunately your 'readability point of view' clashes diametrically with mine :)
I just did some rough head-counts: ATK has 8 enum classes PANGO has 12 enum classes and 1 flag class GDK has 39 enum classes and 10 flag classes GTK has 69 enum classes, 19 flag classes, 5 non-enum constants and 15 fundamental types GLADE doesn't register anything other than its class type
So far so good. Then I looked at Tom's early Scintilla work and blanched. SCN (or whatever its prefix ends up being) apparently has over a thousand separate registered class constants. This may or may not be the way ext/scintilla ends up - but it kind of gives weight to Andrei's argument.
Point taken. It's not what we have now, it's what we _might_ have in the future that's the issue here. In the face of which, I'm forced to back down & mourn the passing of GTK_*.
Anyone else have any strong views over the way GTK::INTERNAL_ENUM should be written in our code and docs, while we're there?
- Steph
----- Original Message ----- From: "Scott Mattocks" <scott@crisscott.com> To: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> Cc: "Steph Fox" <steph@zend.com>; "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net>; "Madeleine D." <mmdrake@bctonline.com> Sent: Tuesday, October 25, 2005 9:31 PM Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Enums, flags and ::
> Andrei Zmievski wrote: > > On Oct 25, 2005, at 1:04 PM, Steph Fox wrote: > > > >> What's the deal about global scope? OK there could be namespace > >> collisions - but on the other hand those are GTK+ constants, easily > >> recognisable and AFAIK used everywhere that uses GTK+. It'd have to be a > >> very 'newbie' error to name a local constant GTK_*, given that scenario. > > > > What about GDK_*? PANGO_*? ATK_*? GLADE_*? SOMEOTHEREXTENSION_*? How > > will this look when all the extensions register their constants globally? > > Personally, I like having everything separated out by extension. I think > Gtk::SOME_CONSTANT is cleaner than GTK_SOME_CONSTANT. (Please note my > not so subtle vote for Gtk as opposed to GTK) I don't think that > sticking with Gtk+ style is a valid argument. By that argument we should > have the same function calls to. I don't think anyone wants to have > gtk_tree_view_get_selection() instead of $treeView->get_selection(). > > I don't think the scope of a constant matters much to the end user. No > matter what scope a constant is in, it should behave the same. I think > this needs to be addressed from a PHP-GTK programmer's readability point > of view and I just think that Gtk:: is easier to read and follow than GTK_. > > Scott

----- Original Message ----- From: "Jeremy Johnstone" <phpdev@gmail.com> To: "PHP-GTK Dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Sunday, October 16, 2005 9:38 AM Subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Glade current status?
Been trying to get Glade working this evening and not having much luck. I was overly ambitious at first, but have now got my test cases down to about the smallest possible and it still doesn't work. When I say doesn't work, I mean I get the following error message and then the app just sits there with no GUI window appearing and I am forced to Cntrl-C my way back to a prompt. The error I get is:
(test.php:14474): libglade-CRITICAL **: glade_xml_build_interface: assertion `wid != NULL' failed
I am attaching the two files in hopes someone else will try and see if they run on their build. Please let me know if you have any tips you can share. I am really wanting to include stuff on libGlade in my talk next month at IPC, but if I can't get even something this basic running it will force me to have to leave it off.
-Jeremy
-- --------------------------- Jeremy Johnstone http://www.jeremyjohnstone.com jsjohnst@php.net

email.body:
You know, it would help if you attached your diff to this message. Really. We don't want to include php_gtk_api.h from gtk.overrides, because that *is* part of the API.
-Andrei
On Oct 11, 2005, at 4:56 AM, Steph wrote:
> OK, I found the breakage now, tho' I'm still confused as to why it > didn't > show up on my diffs. > > The only way I can see to fix it without going back to where we were > is by > including php_gtk_api.h from gtk.overrides. > > Going to apply that mini-patch, will revert if it breaks anything on > *nix. > > - Steph > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@php.net> > To: <php-gtk-cvs@lists.php.net> > Sent: Sunday, October 09, 2005 6:53 PM > Subject: [php-gtk-cvs] cvs: php-gtk /ext/libglade Makefile.frag > php_libglade.h > > >> andrei Sun Oct 9 13:53:12 2005 EDT >> >> Modified files: >> /php-gtk/ext/libglade Makefile.frag php_libglade.h >> Log: >> - Don't include gen_libglade.h from php_libglade.h >> - Adjust make files to remove extra gen_ prefix >> >> >> > http://cvs.php.net/diff.php/php-gtk/ext/libglade/Makefile.frag? > r1=1.3&r2=1.4&ty=u >> Index: php-gtk/ext/libglade/Makefile.frag >> diff -u php-gtk/ext/libglade/Makefile.frag:1.3 > php-gtk/ext/libglade/Makefile.frag:1.4 >> --- php-gtk/ext/libglade/Makefile.frag:1.3 Thu Oct 6 03:03:13 2005 >> +++ php-gtk/ext/libglade/Makefile.frag Sun Oct 9 13:53:10 2005 >> @@ -2,7 +2,7 @@ >> $(builddir)/gen_libglade.c: $(srcdir)/libglade.defs > $(srcdir)/libglade.overrides >> ( \ >> $(PHP) $(top_srcdir)/generator/generator.php \ >> - -l $(@D)/gen_$(*F).log \ >> + -l $(@D)/$(*F).log \ >> -r ext/gtk+/atk-types.defs \ >> -r ext/gtk+/pango-types.defs \ >> -r ext/gtk+/gdk-types.defs \ >> @@ -10,5 +10,5 @@ >> -o ext/libglade/libglade.overrides \ >> -p Glade \ >> -f $@ ext/libglade/libglade.defs \ >> - && grep -h "^PHP_GTK_EXPORT_CE" $@ | sed -e "s!^!extern !" > > $(@D)/gen_$(*F).h \ >> + && grep -h "^PHP_GTK_EXPORT_CE" $@ | sed -e "s!^!extern !" > > $(@D)/$(*F).h \ >> ) >> > http://cvs.php.net/diff.php/php-gtk/ext/libglade/php_libglade.h? > r1=1.9&r2=1.10&ty=u >> Index: php-gtk/ext/libglade/php_libglade.h >> diff -u php-gtk/ext/libglade/php_libglade.h:1.9 > php-gtk/ext/libglade/php_libglade.h:1.10 >> --- php-gtk/ext/libglade/php_libglade.h:1.9 Sun Oct 2 18:58:26 2005 >> +++ php-gtk/ext/libglade/php_libglade.h Sun Oct 9 13:53:10 2005 >> @@ -18,7 +18,7 @@ >> * Foundation, Inc., 59 Temple Place, Suite 330, Boston, MA >> 02111-1307 > USA >> */ >> >> -/* $Id: php_libglade.h,v 1.9 2005/10/02 22:58:26 sfox Exp $: */ >> +/* $Id: php_libglade.h,v 1.10 2005/10/09 17:53:10 andrei Exp $: */ >> >> #ifndef PHP_LIBGLADE_H >> #define PHP_LIBGLADE_H >> @@ -28,7 +28,6 @@ >> #if HAVE_LIBGLADE >> >> #include <glade/glade.h> >> -#include "gen_libglade.h" >> >> extern php_gtk_ext_entry libglade_ext_entry; >> #define php_gtk_ext_libglade_ptr &libglade_ext_entry >> >> -- >> PHP-GTK CVS Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) >> To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >> > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

Yes, I know it's going back to the circular route - but doing it any other way breaks the win32 build, which until now has worked fine (and is exactly the same way as it worked in PHP-GTK 1).
I did say I'd revert this if it broke *nix builds - does it?

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Fw: [php-gtk-cvs] cvs: php-gtk /ext/libglade libglade.overrides
email.body:
Andrei, hi,
Can't find you on irc.
I wanted to say, I'm not happy about the hardcoded value part (at all) but the only option I can see right now is to force everyone to use two parameters for the constructor. At least this way we can doc it saying 'if you changed your root element you'll need to add its name as a parameter'. It's NOT okay to have NULL for the second parameter, even though it says it is in libglade docs and source. Do it this way, and most users can forget about it altogether.
I can't see a way to determine the name of the root just from the libglade object within GTK+. It's probably more straightforward in PHP internals... nuts tho' it seems...
- Steph
----- Original Message ----- From: "Steph" <sfox@php.net> To: <php-gtk-cvs@lists.php.net> Sent: Sunday, October 16, 2005 10:03 PM Subject: [php-gtk-cvs] cvs: php-gtk /ext/libglade libglade.overrides
> sfox Sun Oct 16 17:03:06 2005 EDT > > Modified files: > /php-gtk/ext/libglade libglade.overrides > Log: > Make libglade constructor work out of the box in most cases. > > http://cvs.php.net/diff.php/php-gtk/ext/libglade/libglade.overrides?r1=1.14&r2=1.15&ty=u > Index: php-gtk/ext/libglade/libglade.overrides > diff -u php-gtk/ext/libglade/libglade.overrides:1.14 php-gtk/ext/libglade/libglade.overrides:1.15 > --- php-gtk/ext/libglade/libglade.overrides:1.14 Thu Oct 6 16:35:18 2005 > +++ php-gtk/ext/libglade/libglade.overrides Sun Oct 16 17:03:02 2005 > @@ -8,8 +8,33 @@ > *_get_type > %% > ignore > - glade_xml_new > - glade_xml_signal_connect_full > - glade_xml_signal_connect_data > - glade_xml_signal_autoconnect_full > + glade_xml_construct > > +%% {{{ GladeXML > +%% > +override glade_xml_new > +PHP_METHOD > +{ > + char *fname, *root = NULL, *domain = NULL; > + zend_bool free_fname, free_root, free_domain; > + GObject *wrapped_obj; > + > + if (!php_gtk_parse_args(ZEND_NUM_ARGS(), "u|uu", &fname, &free_fname, &root, &free_root, &domain, &free_domain)) { > + PHPG_THROW_CONSTRUCT_EXCEPTION(GladeXML); > + } > + > + /* Glade's default name for the toplevel window is hard-coded - but there may be a better way */ > + if (!root) root = (char *)"window1"; > + > + wrapped_obj = (GObject *) glade_xml_new(fname, root, domain); > + if (free_fname) g_free(fname); > + if (free_root) g_free(root); > + if (free_domain) g_free(domain); > + > + if (!wrapped_obj) { > + PHPG_THROW_CONSTRUCT_EXCEPTION(GladeXML); > + } > + phpg_gobject_set_wrapper(this_ptr, wrapped_obj TSRMLS_CC); > +} > + > +%% }}} > > -- > PHP-GTK CVS Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Fw: [php-gtk-cvs] cvs: php-gtk / CODING_STANDARDS
email.body:
The only thing that I would change is the part about user defined global constants:
For other constants in the global namespace (that is, constants in your PHP code), stay with the PEAR format: MYCLASS_CONSTANT_NAME.
The PEAR CS has to be backward compatible for PHP 4. That is why they require MYCLASS_*. Since we don't have to worry about PHP 4 any more, I think we should divert from PEAR a little here. Consistency would be better in my opinion. How about this:
User defined classes should not declare constants in the global namespace. All user defined classes should declare constants in the class namespace. For example: MyClass::SOME_CONSTANT instead of MYCLASS_SOME_CONSTANT.
Scott
Steph Fox wrote: > OK guys, tear it apart :) > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Steph Fox" <sfox@php.net> > To: <php-gtk-cvs@lists.php.net> > Sent: Wednesday, October 26, 2005 2:14 PM > Subject: [php-gtk-cvs] cvs: php-gtk / CODING_STANDARDS > > >> sfox Wed Oct 26 09:14:32 2005 EDT >> >> Added files: >> /php-gtk CODING_STANDARDS >> Log: >> Initial commit of coding standards file. >> >> >> -- >> PHP-GTK CVS Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) >> To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >> >
-- Scott Mattocks scott@crisscott.com http://www.crisscott.com http://pear.php.net/user/scottmattocks
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

Anyone else have any strong feelings about this (hands up - I don't).
- Steph

That is why they > require MYCLASS_*. Since we don't have to worry about PHP 4 any more, I > think we should divert from PEAR a little here. Consistency would be > better in my opinion. How about this: > > User defined classes should not declare constants in the global > namespace. All user defined classes should declare constants in the > class namespace. For example: MyClass::SOME_CONSTANT instead of > MYCLASS_SOME_CONSTANT. > > Scott > > Steph Fox wrote: > > OK guys, tear it apart :) > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > From: "Steph Fox" <sfox@php.net> > > To: <php-gtk-cvs@lists.php.net> > > Sent: Wednesday, October 26, 2005 2:14 PM > > Subject: [php-gtk-cvs] cvs: php-gtk / CODING_STANDARDS > > > > > >> sfox Wed Oct 26 09:14:32 2005 EDT > >> > >> Added files: > >> /php-gtk CODING_STANDARDS > >> Log: > >> Initial commit of coding standards file. > >> > >> > >> -- > >> PHP-GTK CVS Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > >> To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > >> > > > > -- > Scott Mattocks > scott@crisscott.com > http://www.crisscott.com > http://pear.php.net/user/scottmattocks > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Fw: [php-gtk-cvs] cvs: php-gtk / CODING_STANDARDS
email.body:
We have PHP5, so we should use it, IMHO. There is no reason to be backwards compatible as the same code wouldn't run in PHP4 anyway.
If your writing a class and have constants related to the class, then they belong inside the class. If instead your making a constant which isn't related to a class, then global constants are fine. To word another way no MYCLASS_* only MyClass::* but BLAHBLAHBLAH is allowed.
-Jeremy
On 10/26/05, Steph Fox <steph@zend.com> wrote: > > That's consistent with PHP-GTK 2's approach to GTK+, but not to PHP... > > Anyone else have any strong feelings about this (hands up - I don't). > > - Steph > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Scott Mattocks" <scott@crisscott.com> > To: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> > Sent: Wednesday, October 26, 2005 4:59 PM > Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Fw: [php-gtk-cvs] cvs: php-gtk / > CODING_STANDARDS > > > > The only thing that I would change is the part about user defined globa= l > > constants: > > > > For other constants in the global namespace (that is, constants in > > your PHP code), stay with the PEAR format: MYCLASS_CONSTANT_NAME. > > > > The PEAR CS has to be backward compatible for PHP 4. That is why they > > require MYCLASS_*. Since we don't have to worry about PHP 4 any more, I > > think we should divert from PEAR a little here. Consistency would be > > better in my opinion. How about this: > > > > User defined classes should not declare constants in the global > > namespace. All user defined classes should declare constants in the > > class namespace. For example: MyClass::SOME_CONSTANT instead of > > MYCLASS_SOME_CONSTANT. > > > > Scott > > > > Steph Fox wrote: > > > OK guys, tear it apart :) > > > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > > From: "Steph Fox" <sfox@php.net> > > > To: <php-gtk-cvs@lists.php.net> > > > Sent: Wednesday, October 26, 2005 2:14 PM > > > Subject: [php-gtk-cvs] cvs: php-gtk / CODING_STANDARDS > > > > > > > > >> sfox Wed Oct 26 09:14:32 2005 EDT > > >> > > >> Added files: > > >> /php-gtk CODING_STANDARDS > > >> Log: > > >> Initial commit of coding standards file. > > >> > > >> > > >> -- > > >> PHP-GTK CVS Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > > >> To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > > >> > > > > > > > -- > > Scott Mattocks > > scott@crisscott.com > > http://www.crisscott.com > > http://pear.php.net/user/scottmattocks > > > > -- > > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > > > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > >

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: [PHP-GTK] Re: Enums, flags and ::
email.body:
Honestly I have to agree with you gtk::main() "looks" better, but from a logical standpoint I think it is actually not as clear as Gtk::main(). It's a subtle difference, but having the first letter uppercase makes it a lot clearer that it is a static class method rather than a function. On the other point, please remember that you aren't forced to use Gtk::WHATEVER fo= r your own code if you absolutely don't want too. It's not something I would do, but you are of course free to do something like the following:
define("GTK_WHATEVER", Gtk::WHATEVER);
The flip side is that it's not feasible to do the reverse (atleast not easily), so it's more flexible doing it the way we are. I also feel very strongly about segregating the constants because it makes looking them up s= o much easier. If I am looking for all Gtk constants it much easier this way than having to grep all the hundreds of global constants for things startin= g with GTK_.
-Jeremy
On 10/26/05, Steph Fox <steph@zend.com> wrote: > > > Well, it is a class after all. What's wrong with Gtk as a class name? > > I'd rather we choose one case standard for class names and stick to > > it. Let's not be inconsistent. > > > <sigh /> > > I better not run for any kind of candidacy this year, eh? > > - Steph > > -- > PHP-GTK General Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > >

I can see how it would be useful. > > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Christian Weiske" <cweiske@cweiske.de> > To: "Steph Fox" <steph@zend.com> > Sent: Monday, October 24, 2005 6:39 PM > Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GladeXML: signal_autoconnect to an object? > > > > Steph, > > > > > Sample pseudocode? > > Assume I have a glade file with a button, and that button's "clicked" > > signal has been connected to the "btnClicked" function. > > Now when doing a $glade->signal_autoconnect(), I have to have the > > following code: > > > > <?php > > $glade = null;//load glade here > > $glade->signal_autoconnect(); > > > > function btnClicked() > > { > > echo "button has been clicked"; > > } > > ?> > > > > > > However, I want to be able to do the following: > > <?php > > class MyApp > > { > > function init() { > > $glade = null;//load glade here > > $glade->signal_autoconnect($this); > > > > } > > > > function btnClicked() > > { > > echo "button has been clicked"; > > } > > } > > $app = new MyApp(); > > $app->init(); > > ?> > > > > > > -- > > Regards/MfG, > > Christian Weiske >

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GladeXML: signal_autoconnect to an object?
email.body:
I just added support for this into CVS.
Staying with your example below, you need to declare either "self::btnClicked" or "MyApp::btnClicked" as the callback handler within the Glade file, rather than plain-vanilla "btnClicked".
Adding any parameter to the signal_autoconnect() call simply passes that data to the callback(s), no change there.
I'd like to make static GTK calls work in a similar way to this - especially main_quit, for obvious reasons! - but that'll take a little more umming and ahhing over here... at present there's always an object passed to the callback, exactly as if connect() were being called.
----- Original Message ----- From: "Steph Fox" <steph@zend.com> To: "Christian Weiske" <cweiske@cweiske.de>; "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Monday, October 24, 2005 7:44 PM Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GladeXML: signal_autoconnect to an object?
> OK, I can see how to do it I think (looking at Zend API), but you'd need to > change your handler name within the Glade file, not within PHP. > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Steph Fox" <steph@zend.com> > To: "Christian Weiske" <cweiske@cweiske.de> > Sent: Monday, October 24, 2005 7:32 PM > Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GladeXML: signal_autoconnect to an object? > > > > hrrrrrrrrmm... passing an object as a parameter works in the sense that > > signal->autoconnect($button) would pass $button to each callback function, > > not in the sense that $button would be the object 'owning' the callback, > so > > there's a syntactic error in that concept, although obviously: > > > > $glade->signal_connect('btnClicked', array($this, 'btnClicked')); > > > > would work. > > > > I'll look into it... I can see how it would be useful. > > > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > From: "Christian Weiske" <cweiske@cweiske.de> > > To: "Steph Fox" <steph@zend.com> > > Sent: Monday, October 24, 2005 6:39 PM > > Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GladeXML: signal_autoconnect to an object? > > > > > > > Steph, > > > > > > > Sample pseudocode? > > > Assume I have a glade file with a button, and that button's "clicked" > > > signal has been connected to the "btnClicked" function. > > > Now when doing a $glade->signal_autoconnect(), I have to have the > > > following code: > > > > > > <?php > > > $glade = null;//load glade here > > > $glade->signal_autoconnect(); > > > > > > function btnClicked() > > > { > > > echo "button has been clicked"; > > > } > > > ?> > > > > > > > > > However, I want to be able to do the following: > > > <?php > > > class MyApp > > > { > > > function init() { > > > $glade = null;//load glade here > > > $glade->signal_autoconnect($this); > > > > > > } > > > > > > function btnClicked() > > > { > > > echo "button has been clicked"; > > > } > > > } > > > $app = new MyApp(); > > > $app->init(); > > > ?> > > > > > > > > > -- > > > Regards/MfG, > > > Christian Weiske > > > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GladeXML: signal_autoconnect to an object?
email.body:
Good morning Steph,
> Staying with your example below, you need to declare either > "self::btnClicked" or "MyApp::btnClicked" as the callback handler within the > Glade file, rather than plain-vanilla "btnClicked". MyClass::btnClicked works, but it's obvious a static call which should be ok. What not works is self::btnClicked, at least for all five of my signals - I always get a ------------------- cweiske:/data/php-gtk/two/PEAR_Frontend_Gtk2> p5 run.phpw PHP Warning: Unable to invoke signal callback 'self::quitDialog' specified in /data/php-gtk/two/PEAR_Frontend_Gtk2/Gtk2.php on line 55 in /data/php-gtk/two/PEAR_Frontend_Gtk2/run.phpw on line 4 -------------------
But even self:: should have the meaning that the signal is being connected to the static function of the current class. So I vote for no prefix (no "self::" or so) if that's possible.
I added a test script in the test/ directory.
Btw, could it be that you forgot to commit your new_from_buffer-patch which used strlen() instead of some zend zval size things? The test script doesn't work for me, and the other new_from_buffer-test script not, too.
> Adding any parameter to the signal_autoconnect() call simply passes that > data to the callback(s), no change there.
> I'd like to make static GTK calls work in a similar way to this - especially > main_quit, for obvious reasons! - but that'll take a little more umming and > ahhing over here... at present there's always an object passed to the > callback, exactly as if connect() were being called. A signal_autoconnect_simple doesn't really help as _all_ sigs would be connected that way. I think that is a pretty hopeless thing; at least if you can't split the signal handler functions into groups - those which shall be connected simple, and those not.
-- Regards/MfG, Christian Weiske
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GladeXML: signal_autoconnect to an object?
email.body:
Christian,
If MyClass::btnClicked had worked in the first place, I wouldn't have bothered going to some lengths to make it work last night.
Your test script is wrong. As I explained earlier, you _cannot_ have $this as a parameter. Also, GladeXML::new_from_buffer() isn't implemented at present (and hasn't been).
Throughout Glade, you have the option to add 'object' or 'after' to any signal, including signal_autoconnect(). Glade doesn't even _use_ connect_simple()...
The whole point of allowing gtk::main_quit as a handler was that you wouldn't need to call anything more than signal_autoconnect() to use it.
I have no idea (yet) why your test script fails and my almost exactly similar test script succeeds. Looking into it, but bear in mind I also have a job.
- Steph
----- Original Message ----- From: "Christian Weiske" <cweiske@cweiske.de> To: "Steph Fox" <steph@zend.com> Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Tuesday, October 25, 2005 7:25 AM Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GladeXML: signal_autoconnect to an object?
> Good morning Steph, > > > > Staying with your example below, you need to declare either > > "self::btnClicked" or "MyApp::btnClicked" as the callback handler within the > > Glade file, rather than plain-vanilla "btnClicked". > MyClass::btnClicked works, but it's obvious a static call which should > be ok. > What not works is self::btnClicked, at least for all five of my signals > - I always get a > ------------------- > cweiske:/data/php-gtk/two/PEAR_Frontend_Gtk2> p5 run.phpw > PHP Warning: Unable to invoke signal callback 'self::quitDialog' > specified in /data/php-gtk/two/PEAR_Frontend_Gtk2/Gtk2.php on line 55 in > /data/php-gtk/two/PEAR_Frontend_Gtk2/run.phpw on line 4 > ------------------- > > But even self:: should have the meaning that the signal is being > connected to the static function of the current class. So I vote for no > prefix (no "self::" or so) if that's possible. > > I added a test script in the test/ directory. > > Btw, could it be that you forgot to commit your new_from_buffer-patch > which used strlen() instead of some zend zval size things? > The test script doesn't work for me, and the other new_from_buffer-test > script not, too. > > > > Adding any parameter to the signal_autoconnect() call simply passes that > > data to the callback(s), no change there. > > > I'd like to make static GTK calls work in a similar way to this - especially > > main_quit, for obvious reasons! - but that'll take a little more umming and > > ahhing over here... at present there's always an object passed to the > > callback, exactly as if connect() were being called. > A signal_autoconnect_simple doesn't really help as _all_ sigs would be > connected that way. I think that is a pretty hopeless thing; at least if > you can't split the signal handler functions into groups - those which > shall be connected simple, and those not. > > -- > Regards/MfG, > Christian Weiske

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: Correct PEAR package.xml php-gtk dependencytag?
email.body:
Hi Scott,
> > If it became a PECL package I'd have to rewrite the entire win32 build > > system from scratch :-\ > > > > Perhaps a better idea would be to figure some way to integrate > > <channel>gtk.php.net</channel> - could anyone point me to the PEAR installer > > mechanism's internals (backend) so I can look into that possibility? > > Setting up the PEAR Channel server is the easy part. I have a PEAR > server already set up that you can use to test this if you want. Just > let me know and I will create you an account.
I think I just got lost somewhere down the line - my question wasn't about setting up a PEAR channel server, it was about having gtk.php.net as a channel that could be searched. Or did I grab completely the wrong end of the stick? It'd be nice to see some backend code so I could get a grip on the way the installer works...
> Even if we have a PHP-GTK channel server, the PEAR/PECL installer will > still need to be used so that will still require rewriting the build system.
Whoa, wait just a minute. Remember we're talking about a situation whereby PHP-GTK is never going to be enabled in a version of PHP used for the web, and PHP-GTK *always* has to be loaded via php.ini these days. So what we really need to look into is a way of checking whether the PHP-GTK module is loaded. If it isn't loaded, ipso facto we've got the wrong PHP for any GTK-related PEAR classes. That's the simple part, you'd think.
> Is this a show stopper?
Yes, I think it probably would be a show stopper if we had to rewrite that - not only from my perspective, but also from Andrei's, given that he's had so many struggles with the *nix setup already.
> I know you just spent a lot of time > getting it to work right but I am picturing the day when someone writes > to the dev list for installation advice and we can just write back: > > $> pecl install gtk/PHP_GTK2
I think that would be problematic, for the reason given above. We don't WANT people to be able to install php-gtk in a web server environment! and the only way I can see to even halfway prevent it would be to check that the PHP used was a cli SAPI before proceeding with a PHP-GTK install... It'd be better to have our own equivalent installer on gtk.php.net IMHO, if only to avoid potential confusion.
At most, all we really need from the PEAR installer is the ability to update an existing PHP-GTK installation and extensions as necessary. So basically (I think) we'd only be looking at throwing an error message if someone attempted to use the PEAR installer to install a GTK-related class when PHP-GTK isn't loaded. On the other hand, we need those PEAR classes to be able to 'relate' to a loaded PHP-GTK module and extensions, and it seems the way PEAR does this is via the package.xml system alone - am I wrong?
- Steph
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: [PEAR-DEV] Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: Correct PEAR package.xml php-gtk
email.body:
Steph,
> At most, all we really need from the PEAR installer is the ability to update > an existing PHP-GTK installation and extensions as necessary. So basically > (I think) we'd only be looking at throwing an error message if someone > attempted to use the PEAR installer to install a GTK-related class when > PHP-GTK isn't loaded. That's right.
> On the other hand, we need those PEAR classes to be > able to 'relate' to a loaded PHP-GTK module and extensions, and it seems the > way PEAR does this is via the package.xml system alone - am I wrong? Now I understand what you mean with "our own package.xml". You are partly right: The package.xml file contains data about the package including version information. But it's mainly used when installing the given package. Now it's just the question if we can "inject" a bogus php-gtk package in a PEAR installation when php-gtk gets installed by its own system. I doubt it, mainly because you can have many pear installations around (I'm one of these crazy people).
Best thing would IMO be if there would be a special treatment for php-gtk OR even better for any extension - if it's loaded, and if it's loaded, check the version with the reflection classes as Andrei has shown us.
-- Regards/MfG, Christian Weiske
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] PHP-GTK manual and demo scripts coding standards [WAS: Viewport critical warnings
email.body:
> > I don't like Gtk::main() either - I think functions without an object should > > be treated as standard PHP functions, i.e. lowercased. > So gtk::main()? > But then you *have* to do a gtk::SELECTION_SINGLE.
I realise it _seems_ inconsistent, but the internal name for that is actually GTK_SELECTION_SINGLE. Calling it GTK:: is more a matter of convenience for our generator than it is any other thing.
> > Also we need to decide where to put our Coding Standards file - should it be > > in php-gtk-doc or php-gtk module, or both? > php-gtk as the demos are there, and the doc people will know that the CS > are in the php-gtk module, or we make a link to that file.
Fine by me - Andrei, any opinion on this?
> > (Internals is easier, everyone that contributed already went with PHP's > > internal CS recommendations). > "Internals" refers to what?
All things written in C...
- Steph
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: stristr()
email.body:
On Oct 22, 2005, at 2:31 AM, Rolland Santimano wrote:
> Ah, right. But, I see that context/locale-sensitive full-case mapping > is only possible via u_strToLower(), which works on code units. And I > can't find any ICU funcn that works with codepts.
No, u_strToLower() works on code points. The fact that it takes a UChar* parameter doesn't mean that it works on code units.
> Should I use simple case mapping for the time being ? I'll hold the > impl of strripos(), str_replace() & str_ireplace() pending some > clarity on this issue. I'll also need to re-work stripos() and > stristr() after that. > > I've CC'ed Tex to get his input on this.
u_strToLower() will not actually helps us with stristr() and others, since:
a) we actually want case-folding, not lowercasing b) we do not want to lowercase both strings and compare them (it's expensive)
One of the ICU guys had the following suggestion, when I asked about case insensitive version of u_strstr() a while back:
> 1. Go one step further and make your string search language-sensitive, > using ICU's string search API (which is based on collation). See > http://icu.sourceforge.net/userguide/searchString.html > > 2. Use ICU regular expressions. It currently does not handle case > foldings well that map a single character (like ?) to multiple (like > ss). > > 3. Look at the implementation behind functions like u_strcasecmp() and > try to adapt it to a string search. The implementation case-folds both > strings incrementally. For a search, you would want to case-fold the > pattern beforehand, but not the text in which you are searching. > > 4. You might try the following: Take the first character in the > pattern and get the set of all characters that have the same case > folding (see the UnicodeSet/USet API). Then search in the string for > the occurrence of any one of the set items (which include strings!). > Then do a case-insensitive comparison, allowing a match that does not > end with the end of the text. > > The problematic cases are of course those ?->ss and similar. The > collation-based string search API has settings for whether you want to > find "sta" in "Flu?tal" and such (the pattern matches the second half > of a text character). > > Usually, users seem to be happy to do 1. or 2. Long-term, we would > like to beef up the regex implementation to handle more complicated > case foldings and also canonically equivalent (i.e., normalization) > variants.
I am leaning towards 3 or 4. Not sure which one would be faster, but we definitely would want to write a generic function that does case-insensitive search and re-use it in stristr(), stri_replace(), and others.
-Andrei
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Fw: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GladeXML: signal_autoconnect to an object? (Mystery solved)
email.body:
Wrong scope. The Zend engine likes to know where it stands :)
If you have gtk::main() in your constructor (which my script had), then the scope is within that class. If you don't (which your script didn't), the scope's general and you need to specify the class.
Not a bug.
----- Original Message ----- From: "Steph Fox" <steph@zend.com> To: "Christian Weiske" <cweiske@cweiske.de> Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Tuesday, October 25, 2005 2:16 PM Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GladeXML: signal_autoconnect to an object?
> Christian, > > If MyClass::btnClicked had worked in the first place, I wouldn't have > bothered going to some lengths to make it work last night. > > Your test script is wrong. As I explained earlier, you _cannot_ have $this > as a parameter. Also, GladeXML::new_from_buffer() isn't implemented at > present (and hasn't been). > > Throughout Glade, you have the option to add 'object' or 'after' to any > signal, including signal_autoconnect(). Glade doesn't even _use_ > connect_simple()... > > The whole point of allowing gtk::main_quit as a handler was that you > wouldn't need to call anything more than signal_autoconnect() to use it. > > I have no idea (yet) why your test script fails and my almost exactly > similar test script succeeds. Looking into it, but bear in mind I also have > a job. > > - Steph > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Christian Weiske" <cweiske@cweiske.de> > To: "Steph Fox" <steph@zend.com> > Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> > Sent: Tuesday, October 25, 2005 7:25 AM > Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GladeXML: signal_autoconnect to an object? > > > > Good morning Steph, > > > > > > > Staying with your example below, you need to declare either > > > "self::btnClicked" or "MyApp::btnClicked" as the callback handler within > the > > > Glade file, rather than plain-vanilla "btnClicked". > > MyClass::btnClicked works, but it's obvious a static call which should > > be ok. > > What not works is self::btnClicked, at least for all five of my signals > > - I always get a > > ------------------- > > cweiske:/data/php-gtk/two/PEAR_Frontend_Gtk2> p5 run.phpw > > PHP Warning: Unable to invoke signal callback 'self::quitDialog' > > specified in /data/php-gtk/two/PEAR_Frontend_Gtk2/Gtk2.php on line 55 in > > /data/php-gtk/two/PEAR_Frontend_Gtk2/run.phpw on line 4 > > ------------------- > > > > But even self:: should have the meaning that the signal is being > > connected to the static function of the current class. So I vote for no > > prefix (no "self::" or so) if that's possible. > > > > I added a test script in the test/ directory. > > > > Btw, could it be that you forgot to commit your new_from_buffer-patch > > which used strlen() instead of some zend zval size things? > > The test script doesn't work for me, and the other new_from_buffer-test > > script not, too. > > > > > > > Adding any parameter to the signal_autoconnect() call simply passes that > > > data to the callback(s), no change there. > > > > > I'd like to make static GTK calls work in a similar way to this - > especially > > > main_quit, for obvious reasons! - but that'll take a little more umming > and > > > ahhing over here... at present there's always an object passed to the > > > callback, exactly as if connect() were being called. > > A signal_autoconnect_simple doesn't really help as _all_ sigs would be > > connected that way. I think that is a pretty hopeless thing; at least if > > you can't split the signal handler functions into groups - those which > > shall be connected simple, and those not. > > > > -- > > Regards/MfG, > > Christian Weiske > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: Enums, flags and ::
email.body:
On Oct 25, 2005, at 8:50 AM, Steph Fox wrote:
> Before it's too late (assuming it isn't already): Is there any way we > can > return enums/flags to the standard GTK format, as they were in PHP-GTK > 1? > > If you remember that far back, I spent more than a day trying to work > out > what I was doing wrong when every enum in sight failed in an old > script I > upgraded to PHP-GTK 2. I don't think I'm going to be the only > scriptkiddie > baffled by that change. > > It's also the one area Christian and I can't come to an agreement over > in > our coding standards discussions, because what _should_ be a constant > is > being treated as some kind of a pseudo-method, which makes either > approach > inconsistent by definition.
Huh, what pseudo-method? It's a class constant, that's all.
> I know it'd be a BC breakage for PHP-GTK 2 to change this now, but then > again we haven't released v. 2 yet. At present it's a BC breakage for > PHP-GTK 1, which is probably more serious. > > So the question is, do enums and flags _have_ to be registered as class > entry constants for ZE 2 to deal with them? Or is it just a matter of > convenience?
It's a matter of not polluting global namespace.
> - and the next question is, assuming it's possible to register them as > global constants, should we?
I don't think so.
-Andrei
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] PHP-GTK2 new Example 11. Using get_char_count() to manual...
email.body:
This is a user question. Please use the appropriate forum for it.
(That would be php-gtk-general@lists.php.net)
I'm not talking about what you're aiming to achieve here, I'm talking about the question itself, which is basically about how to save a file as far as I can see. That is in no way a development question.
If you figure out (or someone on php-gtk-general tells you) how to save a file and you find it doesn't work under PHP-GTK 2, it's called a 'bug'. You should report bugs to http://bugs.php.net as a PHP-GTK issue.
Please, as I said to you already, there is more than enough noise on this list, and practically none on php-gtk-general over the last few months. The kind of questions you're asking aren't development issues, they're user issues. And out there somewhere, there are users who will be more than happy to see some life in the project, because they don't necessarily subscribe to the developers list so don't know just how busy it is here (and why should they?) - all they see is 'nothing's happening'. There are people who aren't subscribed to the dev list, but can tell you exactly how you should be saving your file. Use those people. Not the people who wrote the stuff and just hope it works.
- Steph
