email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: [PHP-GTK] Re: Enums, flags and ::
email.body:
Relax, the CS are in CVS now :)
----- Original Message ----- From: "Jeremy Johnstone" <phpdev@gmail.com> To: "Steph Fox" <steph@zend.com> Cc: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com>; "PHP-GTK gen" <php-gtk-general@lists.php.net>; "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Thursday, October 27, 2005 7:27 AM Subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: [PHP-GTK] Re: Enums, flags and ::
Honestly I have to agree with you gtk::main() "looks" better, but from a logical standpoint I think it is actually not as clear as Gtk::main(). It's a subtle difference, but having the first letter uppercase makes it a lot clearer that it is a static class method rather than a function. On the other point, please remember that you aren't forced to use Gtk::WHATEVER for your own code if you absolutely don't want too. It's not something I would do, but you are of course free to do something like the following:
define("GTK_WHATEVER", Gtk::WHATEVER);
The flip side is that it's not feasible to do the reverse (atleast not easily), so it's more flexible doing it the way we are. I also feel very strongly about segregating the constants because it makes looking them up so much easier. If I am looking for all Gtk constants it much easier this way than having to grep all the hundreds of global constants for things starting with GTK_.
-Jeremy
On 10/26/05, Steph Fox <steph@zend.com> wrote: > > > Well, it is a class after all. What's wrong with Gtk as a class name? > > I'd rather we choose one case standard for class names and stick to > > it. Let's not be inconsistent. > > > <sigh /> > > I better not run for any kind of candidacy this year, eh? > > - Steph > > -- > PHP-GTK General Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > >
-- --------------------------- Jeremy Johnstone http://www.jeremyjohnstone.com jsjohnst@php.net
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Fw: [php-gtk-cvs] cvs: php-gtk / CODING_STANDARDS
email.body:
Next you'll be saying we should have Php::OS :)
jk
OK, that's two votes for taking that approach so I'll change it.
- Steph
----- Original Message ----- From: "Jeremy Johnstone" <phpdev@gmail.com> To: "Steph Fox" <steph@zend.com> Cc: "Scott Mattocks" <scott@crisscott.com>; "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Thursday, October 27, 2005 7:13 AM Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Fw: [php-gtk-cvs] cvs: php-gtk / CODING_STANDARDS
We have PHP5, so we should use it, IMHO. There is no reason to be backwards compatible as the same code wouldn't run in PHP4 anyway.
If your writing a class and have constants related to the class, then they belong inside the class. If instead your making a constant which isn't related to a class, then global constants are fine. To word another way no MYCLASS_* only MyClass::* but BLAHBLAHBLAH is allowed.
-Jeremy
On 10/26/05, Steph Fox <steph@zend.com> wrote: > > That's consistent with PHP-GTK 2's approach to GTK+, but not to PHP... > > Anyone else have any strong feelings about this (hands up - I don't). > > - Steph > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Scott Mattocks" <scott@crisscott.com> > To: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> > Sent: Wednesday, October 26, 2005 4:59 PM > Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Fw: [php-gtk-cvs] cvs: php-gtk / > CODING_STANDARDS > > > > The only thing that I would change is the part about user defined global > > constants: > > > > For other constants in the global namespace (that is, constants in > > your PHP code), stay with the PEAR format: MYCLASS_CONSTANT_NAME. > > > > The PEAR CS has to be backward compatible for PHP 4. That is why they > > require MYCLASS_*. Since we don't have to worry about PHP 4 any more, I > > think we should divert from PEAR a little here. Consistency would be > > better in my opinion. How about this: > > > > User defined classes should not declare constants in the global > > namespace. All user defined classes should declare constants in the > > class namespace. For example: MyClass::SOME_CONSTANT instead of > > MYCLASS_SOME_CONSTANT. > > > > Scott > > > > Steph Fox wrote: > > > OK guys, tear it apart :) > > > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > > From: "Steph Fox" <sfox@php.net> > > > To: <php-gtk-cvs@lists.php.net> > > > Sent: Wednesday, October 26, 2005 2:14 PM > > > Subject: [php-gtk-cvs] cvs: php-gtk / CODING_STANDARDS > > > > > > > > >> sfox Wed Oct 26 09:14:32 2005 EDT > > >> > > >> Added files: > > >> /php-gtk CODING_STANDARDS > > >> Log: > > >> Initial commit of coding standards file. > > >> > > >> > > >> -- > > >> PHP-GTK CVS Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > > >> To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > > >> > > > > > > > -- > > Scott Mattocks > > scott@crisscott.com > > http://www.crisscott.com > > http://pear.php.net/user/scottmattocks > > > > -- > > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > > > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > >

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Fatal Error -> Gdk::pixmap_create_from_xpm_d
email.body:
Hi Tabber,
It isn't deprecated, it's just not being generated. That means one of us needs to write it manually - along with 28 other functions, according to my build log:
====================================== Gdk Coverage ====================================== Functions : 63.8% written (67/105) Methods : 75.7% written (252/333) Constructors : 80.0% written (20/25) Property accessors : 100.0% written (46/46)
We're close to having PHP-GTK 2, but we're not _that_ close to having it 100% spot-on and perfect.
- Steph
----- Original Message ----- From: "Tabber Watts" <tabber.watts@gmail.com> To: <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Friday, October 28, 2005 10:05 PM Subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Fatal Error -> Gdk::pixmap_create_from_xpm_d
In my attempt to port my current program over to the new PHP-GTK 2 and test it on Windows I've ran into a problem with the Gdk::pixmap_create_from_xpm_d function. When I run the simple test script below I get:
Fatal error: Call to undefined method Gdk::pixmap_create_from_xpm_d() in g:\test\xpm.php on line 18
I've checked the current manuals and have not seen that this function has been depreciated or any mention that these functions must be installed via a seperate extension(s).
Mahalo for any help, Tabber Watts
<?php if (!class_exists('gtk')) { die('Please load the php-gtk2 module in your php.ini' . "\r\n"); }
$xpm_timeline_red = array( "5 5 2 1", " c None", ". c #FF0000", ".....", ".....", ".....", ".....", ".....");
$window = &new GtkWindow(); list($pixmap, $mask) = Gdk::pixmap_create_from_xpm_d($window->window,null,$xpm_timeline_red); $pixmap_id = &new GtkPixmap($pixmap, $mask); $window->show_all();
Gtk::main(); ?>
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Glade current status?
email.body:
On Oct 17, 2005, at 11:10 PM, Jeremy Johnstone wrote:
> Test.php: > > <?php > > define("FILESYSTEM_PATH", dirname(__FILE__)); > > echo $glade_xml = file_get_contents(FILESYSTEM_PATH . '/ > test_project.glade'); > $window =& new GladeXML($glade_xml, strlen($glade_xml), NULL, NULL);
Please don't use "=& new" in PHP-GTK 2.
Secondly, the GladeXML() constructor signature has changed. I adjusted the sample to use the correct signature and the window came up for me. Try again please.
- Andrei

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Weird behaviour with declared PHP classes and GDK drawing functions
email.body:
:)
----- Original Message ----- From: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> To: "Steph Fox" <steph@zend.com> Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Sunday, October 30, 2005 1:04 AM Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Weird behaviour with declared PHP classes and GDK drawing functions
> Oh, Zend Engine, the paragon of confoundry and head-scratching > incentivizer. After several hours of enjoy close and intimate > relationship with gdb, this bug should be fixed in CVS. For the > curious ones in the audience, the problem is described in the fix > comment: > > /* > * This is required to trick Zend into performing the global > class table cleanup in a > * different manner. EG(full_table_cleanup) is 0 normally, and > is set to 1 if any > * module is loaded via dl(), because the module may register > internal classes. When > * we register an internal class at runtime, it is added to the > end of the class list. > * shutdown_executor() has to remove user-declared classes from > the class list. It > * does it by iterating through the list in reverse order and > cleaning up all user > * classes until it encounters an internal class, but since we > have just added an > * internal class at the very end, it stops right away and does > not clean up the user > * ones. We circumvent it by pretending to be a dynamically > loaded module so that the > * hash cleanup does not stop on the first internal class and > proceeds through the > * whole table. > * > * Whether there is a better way to do it is still to be seen. > */ > EG(full_tables_cleanup) = 1; > > > -Andrei > > > On Oct 22, 2005, at 9:22 AM, Steph Fox wrote: > > > Andrei, can you look into this please? It's very, very weird. > > > > Try adding the line > > > > class Scribble {} > > > > to the top of the enclosed working script. > > > > That's all you have to do to break the 3 drawing functions in it > > and cause > > PHP-GTK to crash on exit. You don't even need to instantiate the > > class (or > > make it instatiatable, if that's a word). > > > > Outcomment the drawing functions, and it stops crashing. Bizarre. > > > > PHP bug, GTK bug or PHP-GTK bug? > > > > - Steph > > > > <scribble.php.txt> > > -- > > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >

In PHP-GTK > >>> 1, if you > >>> set up the object to be passed in Glade it never worked, because > >>> signal_autoconnect() didn't recognise it. > >>> > >> > >> PHP-GTK 1 only cared about functions, really. > >> > >> > >>> This way, it does work, and > >>> signal_autoconnect() caters for four separate kinds of signals. > >>> Its only > >>> problems are a) passing data and b) connecting to a callback > >>> defined within > >>> a class, non-statically. > >>> > >> > >> I'm still not sure what you're talking about here, "four separate > >> kinds of signals". I think it may be best if I just re-implement > >> signal_autoconnect() and take a vote on the implementation. > >> > > > > connect(), connect_after(), connect_object() and > > connect_object_after() are > > the types of signals that can be created from within Glade. Please > > don't > > mess with that, it's the first time it's worked properly! > > > > > >>> I think it would be sensible to have a separate function that > >>> passed an > >>> object as first parameter if you wanted to be able to access > >>> callbacks > >>> within that class, and data mapping as a second parameter. I don't > >>> think it > >>> would be a good idea to call it signal_autoconnect_object() though, > >>> because > >>> that means something other. > >>> > >> > >> Ok, I definitely need to reimplement it now. Build faster, Glade2! > >> > > > > Huh? > > > > > >> > >> - Andrei > > >

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Long way from China
email.body:
Morning Andrei,
I started testing the unicode-enforcing thingie ready to throw a few utf8 conversions into the mix, but I'm seeing some anomalies.
For example, if I _only_ alter gtk_label_new() to accept 'u', GtkButtons won't pick up on that and use it for their own labels - they need the 'u' representation in their own constructor. At the same time, the dialogmessage.php script from the demos crashes at the second click of the 'Interactive' button if GtkLabel is utf8-friendly (and not if it's not).
On the other hand, if I _only_ alter gtk_button_new_from_stock, the buttonbox.php script crashes on opening. Though all the other bits and pieces function normally... including the dialogmessage.php script that didn't like GtkLabel changes.
It's only stable if I keep everything as 's', and I can't see any clear pattern in the instability - it might be that both scripts are constructing stock buttons multiple times, but this in itself doesn't make sense because the 'interactive dialog' callback creates and destroys the likeliest suspects on every call. (It _is_ really destroying them, yes?)
When 'u' works, it works really well :-(
Sorry to be so vague, it's left me clueless.
- Steph
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] digging into enums and flags
email.body:
Andrei,
I think the weird behaviour I reported earlier was probably just down to me getting confused - I can't find the particular script that provoked one request for a string from the PHP side and another for an int from the GTK side, but I do know how it happened now.
Here's a short test script from my ever-increasing hello.php:
<?php
/* tricksy params - and can the final param work at all if local_files is set to TRUE by default? */ $fcdialog = new GtkFileChooserDialog('GtkFileChooserDialog', null, Gtk::FILE_CHOOSER_ACTION_OPEN, array('first', Gtk::RESPONSE_CANCEL, 'second', Gtk::RESPONSE_ACCEPT, 'third', Gtk::RESPONSE_OK, '_fourth', Gtk::RESPONSE_APPLY), 'tmp://'); $fcdialog->connect_object('destroy', array('gtk', 'main_quit')); $fcdialog->show_all();
?>
Now in PHP-GTK 2 you need to type stuff like:
Gtk::FILE_CHOOSER_ACTION_OPEN
rather than version 1's:
GTK_FILE_CHOOSER_ACTION_OPEN
thanks to the g_typing. But if you don't know this in advance and do it the old fashioned way, you get something like "Notice: Use of undefined constant GTK_RESPONSE_ACCEPT - assumed 'GTK_RESPONSE_ACCEPT' in C:\php5\hello.php on line 4". In some cases that actually works - submitting the string 'GTK_FILE_CHOOSER_ACTION_OPEN' appears to, presumably because it evaluates to 0 - but submitting 'GTK_RESPONSE_ACCEPT' will cause a PhpGtkConstructException to be thrown.
Warning: GtkFileChooserDialog::__construct(): each pair in button list has to string/number in C:\php5\hello.php on line 4
Fatal error: Uncaught exception 'PhpGtkConstructException' with message 'could not construct GtkDialog object' in C:\php5\hello.php:4 Stack trace: #0 C:\php5\hello.php(4): GtkFileChooserDialog->__construct('GtkFileChooserD...', NULL, 0, Array, 'tmp://') #1 {main} thrown in C:\php5\hello.php on line 4
You can see how I got confused. OK so this is a documentation issue at heart, but is there any way to give a saner E_NOTICE than the one thrown by PHP?
- Steph NB This means we can eliminate misbehaviour in enums from the 'u' issue, in the sense I meant it at least.
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Moving on to GtkNotebook
email.body:
Hi all,
Ploughing through the class/function part of the TODO, where there are no less than 4 items open regarding GtkNotebook.
Does anyone (Christian maybe?) happen to have any code lying around that demonstrates any or all of the issues listed there? It'd save some time here...
- Steph
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] [PATCH] GtkNotebook-related stuff
email.body:
Hi Andrei,
I know this isn't a brilliant attempt, but it allows the signal that was prevented from working, to work.
It seems safer to return a long than anything else.
I can't find a way to check what the pointer's actually pointing _to_, otherwise it'd be able to cope with strings, objects, arrays, etc. But as far as I recollect, the only place the lack of gpointer support hurt PHP-GTK 1 was in this single GtkNotebook signal. All the PHP-GTK 2 demo and test scripts I have at my disposal still work with the patch applied.
Should I commit it, or does it require further investigation?
- Steph
["pointer.txt" (text/plain)]
Index: main/phpg_gvalue.c =================================================================== RCS file: /repository/php-gtk/main/phpg_gvalue.c,v retrieving revision 1.23 diff -u -r1.23 phpg_gvalue.c --- main/phpg_gvalue.c 2 Sep 2005 09:16:55 -0000 1.23 +++ main/phpg_gvalue.c 16 Sep 2005 19:46:16 -0000 @@ -173,6 +173,13 @@ break; }
+ case G_TYPE_POINTER: + { + MAKE_ZVAL_IF_NULL(*value); + ZVAL_LONG(*value, (long)g_value_get_pointer(gval)); + break; + } + default: php_error(E_WARNING, "PHP-GTK internal error: unsupported type %s", \ g_type_name(G_VALUE_TYPE(gval))); MAKE_STD_ZVAL(*value);

As for TODO, yes, it should contain only outstanding items.

> Andrei, all... > > I've a handful of outstanding patches that need checking, but after > those > are resolved/committed I'd like to ask what's missing that actually > prevents > an initial release? > > The three people able to test the Windows version have given useful > feedback, but it'd be good to extend the field some and find out where > users' priorities lie - and I know a lot of people want to try PHP-GTK > 2, > but just don't have the opportunity until we release something. > > Comments, anyone? - if nothing else, it would be good to have an idea > of the > areas that most need focus. > > - Steph > > PS - Andrei, the TODO's kinda confusing at present because it > sometimes gets > things added to it when they're complete, like a NEWS file should. > Can we > stick to using it as a TODO and create a NEWS file following the > initial > release? >

Hi Steph,
Tuesday, September 20, 2005, 7:00:41 AM, you wrote: S> The only outstanding generator issue from the win32 side is Tom's S> line-endings problem, which as Frank said is a very simple fix. I'll commit S> it later tonight.
I think there is something wrong in the cvs copies of certain files. Can you get a clean copy of confutils.js and look at the line endings. In Homesite for example it triggers the double line spacing dialog. I am sure it has crcrlf line endings. (I don't use Homesite it was just another test).
That is probably what is triggering the errors I am seeing.

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Error-killing
[PHP-GTK-DEV] Why the libglade extension doesn't work
email.body:
The ATK library I'm building PHP-GTK 2 against has a function missing, as do our own sources (presumably originating from ATK 1.8.0 or earlier).
The libglade .dll was built against ATK 1.9.0, and references (uses?) the missing ATK function.
Have written to Tor (who distributes the GTK+ dev headers and libs we use for win32)... the override's simple enough to add, but should I be taking this route? or trying to find another, possibly less recent, libglade distribution?
- Steph
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Why the libglade extension doesn't work
email.body:
How widely available is ATK 1.9.0? Do most distributions have it?
-Andrei
On Sep 22, 2005, at 12:34 PM, Steph wrote:
> ps I just tried building against a full version of ATK 1.9.0 with my > overrides patch and everything loads now, including the GladeXML > class and > something that thinks it's called Libglade :) > > Andrei, would you mind making 1.9.0 ATK rather than 1.8.0 > required? It > builds & works OK with that single change to the defs file. > > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> > To: "Andrei" <andrei@gravitonic.com> > Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> > Sent: Thursday, September 22, 2005 8:11 PM > Subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Why the libglade extension doesn't work > > > >> The ATK library I'm building PHP-GTK 2 against has a function >> missing, as >> > do > >> our own sources (presumably originating from ATK 1.8.0 or earlier). >> >> The libglade .dll was built against ATK 1.9.0, and references >> (uses?) the >> missing ATK function. >> >> Have written to Tor (who distributes the GTK+ dev headers and libs >> we use >> for win32)... the override's simple enough to add, but should I be >> taking >> this route? or trying to find another, possibly less recent, >> libglade >> distribution? >> >> - Steph >> >> -- >> PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) >> To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >> >> > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] [PATCH] Core changes needed for ext/libglade support
email.body:
Andrei, hi,
If you can't/aren't prepared to bump the version requirement for ATK, let me know and I'll find an earlier libglade to work with. Please let me know fairly soon though, as some of the GladeXML functions have changed too. (I haven't started work on the overrides yet.)
Question: how worried would you be if the gobject methods turned up in an extension class?
Any clues as to what's happening here would be very welcome.
C:\php5>php -r "print_r(get_class_methods('GladeXML'))"; Array ( [0] => __construct [1] => construct [2] => get_widget [3] => relative_file [4] => signal_autoconnect // so far so good, this part matches gen_libglade.c [5] => __tostring // enter chaos... [6] => connect [7] => connect_after [8] => connect_object [9] => connect_object_after [10] => get_property [11] => set_property [12] => get_data [13] => set_data [14] => block [15] => unblock [16] => disconnect [17] => is_connected [18] => signal_list_ids [19] => signal_list_names [20] => signal_query )
C:\php5>php -r "print_r(get_class_methods('Libglade'))"; Array ( [0] => get_widget_name // no problems here whatsoever [1] => get_widget_tree )
Could it be anything to do with gobject also having __construct() and construct() methods declared?
- Steph
["libglade.txt" (text/plain)]

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] September News
email.body:
Hello,
Any news this month? Steph, can you give me a summary of the changes you have commit so far? Those seem pretty news worthy to me.
Also, I have this message from Mark Crane that I think can make for some good news:
"Here is a link for the first version of PHPGtk that is portable on a USB drive. It can be run from any folder root or elsewhere. However despite efforts to use quotes around the path it will not launch if the path has a space in it.
http://portablewebap.com/downloads/PortablePHPgtk.zip
The link may will change so I will put up page specifically for the Portable PHP GTK soon. That will provide some information and the new download link."
I also have this http://apress.com/book/bookDisplay.html?bID=10072 but I am not sure it belongs on the home page (or at least not yet).
Let me know if there is anything else.
Thanks, Scott

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] PHP-GTK2 Extensions?
email.body:
I have been tinkering with PHP-GTK2 windows build.
I would like to use extensions. Mainly the mysql or mysqli extensions.
I have tried several different versions of php_mysqli.dll and have got as far as module does not match.
Is it possible to load extensions yet? If so how?
Any answer helps!
Thanks,
Josh

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] PHP-GTK2 Extensions?
email.body:
If you build php, php_gtk and the other extensions you need from the same set of source files you can load all the extension you need. This has nothing to do with php_gtk.
You can find the latest build of extension on snaps.php.net or on my page http://kromann.info/php.php. These are build from a freash CVS snapshot every night.
- Frank
> I have been tinkering with PHP-GTK2 windows build. > > I would like to use extensions. Mainly the mysql or mysqli extensions. > > I have tried several different versions of php_mysqli.dll and have got as > far as module does not match. > > Is it possible to load extensions yet? If so how? > > > > Any answer helps! > > > > Thanks, > > Josh > >

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] September News
email.body:
Hi Scott,
Basically we have a working win32 .dll, and Edin Kadribasic's just given me the means of distributing a pre-release version ('just', as in about ten minutes ago, I'm still uploading stuff at present). We know for sure it works as advertised on WinXP and Windows 98; nobody's tried other varieties of doze yet.
I've gone through the TODO and attempted to clear the items that seem relatively straightforward on there, but I still have some patches outstanding from that burst of energy which Andrei will look into when he gets five minutes' free time.
Edin is threatening to build php-gtk2.dll as part of his snaps downloads on snaps.php.net, but we still need to find out whether that's possible.
- Steph

email.body:

I'm totally confused as to why we're seeing different behaviour under the same plaform, but it's not the first time you've mentioned this.
It'll need an OS check...
- Steph
----- Original Message ----- From: "Tom Rogers" <trogers@kwikin.com> To: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Saturday, September 17, 2005 6:37 AM Subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] win32 line endings again
> Hi > > I just did a completely new checkout and came across a problem with > windows line endings again in the generator scripts. This patch fixes > the problem. > > > diff -u -w -b -r1.28 override.php > --- override.php 4 Sep 2005 06:02:27 -0000 1.28 > +++ override.php 17 Sep 2005 05:35:30 -0000 > @@ -92,9 +92,11 @@ > > function _parse_block($block, $blocklineno, $file_name) > { > - if (strpos($block, "\n")) > - list($line, $rest) = explode("\n", $block, 2); > - else { > + if (strpos($block, "\n")) { > + $test = preg_split('/\r\n|\n/',ltrim($block)); > + $line = array_shift($test); > + $rest = implode("\n",$test); > + } else { > $line = $block; > $rest = ''; > } > > -- > > Tom > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] win32 line endings again
email.body:
Aha, got it! You're copying files across and producing win32 line endings in the process, no? The original files are in CVS with Unix line endings, and _should_ be checked out that way... but I can see how that might fail, one way or another. The Tortoise CVS client provides win32 line endings by default too.
OK, so that eventuality still needs accounting for. Not an OS check then, a check for the existence of 
.
- Steph

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] [PATCH] GtkTextBuffer::set_text() inc utf8 conversion
email.body:
Andrei,
I can't see anything wrong with this one, but I'll bet you find something ;)
I'd muffed the free-ing, as you anticipated, in the earlier attempts at utf8 input conversion. All that's working and committed now, I just held this one back because it's a new override function.
I'm not able to get _anything_ back in the encoding WinXP actually uses. This is also true of methods like GtkLabel::get_text(), which are automated. I can synth similar functions (well okay there's only one at present, GtkLabel::get(), which is deprecated anyway) but as it's not working there's not a lot of point in committing that change.
I'm assuming I should be able to put returned utf8 string values through phpg_from_utf8() before returning them to userspace, and should then be able to print them out readably on my console. If I've got hold of the wrong end of the stick.... let me know, eh?
- Steph
["textbuffer.txt" (text/plain)]
Index: ext/gtk+/gtktextview.overrides =================================================================== RCS file: /repository/php-gtk/ext/gtk+/gtktextview.overrides,v retrieving revision 1.2 diff -u -r1.2 gtktextview.overrides --- ext/gtk+/gtktextview.overrides 31 Jul 2005 10:12:19 -0000 1.2 +++ ext/gtk+/gtktextview.overrides 14 Sep 2005 13:16:32 -0000 @@ -120,4 +120,37 @@ phpg_gboxed_new(&return_value, GTK_TYPE_TEXT_ITER, &iter, TRUE, TRUE TSRMLS_CC); }
+%% +add-arginfo GtkTextBuffer set_text +static +ZEND_BEGIN_ARG_INFO(ARGINFO_NAME, 0) + ZEND_ARG_INFO(0, text) + ZEND_ARG_INFO(0, len) +ZEND_END_ARG_INFO(); + +%% +override gtk_text_buffer_set_text +PHP_METHOD +{ + + char *text; + zend_bool free_text; + long php_len, len = 0; + + NOT_STATIC_METHOD(); + + if (!php_gtk_parse_args(ZEND_NUM_ARGS(), "u|i", &text, &free_text, &php_len)) + return; + + if (!php_len) { + len = strlen(text); + } else { + len = php_len; + } + + gtk_text_buffer_set_text(GTK_TEXT_BUFFER(PHPG_GOBJECT(this_ptr)), text, (guint)len); + + if (free_text) g_free(text); +} + %% }}}
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Fw: [PHP-GTK-DEV] [PATCH] GtkNotebook-related stuff
email.body:
OK, a little more background info for this patch.
I made that change to phpg_gvalue_to_zval(), which is only called from two places in PHP-GTK 2 source.
One is the signal marshaller, phpg_closure_marshal(), i.e. all GTK signal parameter values are checked this way.
The signals potentially affected by this patch, apart from the switch-page signal in GtkNotebook which is fixed by it, are:
insert-text signal (GtkEditable) files-added signal (GtkFileSystem) toggle-size-request signal (GtkMenuItem) path-clicked signal (GtkPathBar) input signal (GtkSpinButton)
all of which contain a gpointer type parameter.
The other place is gtk_tree_model_get_value(), which is unlikely to be broken by the patch (because there isn't a way to set a gpointer as a value for a GtkTreeModel).
If anyone has any scripts handy for testing the other signals there, please let me know. I've no idea how to test GtkFileSystem :)
- Steph
----- Original Message ----- From: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> To: "Andrei" <andrei@gravitonic.com> Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Saturday, September 17, 2005 4:10 PM Subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] [PATCH] GtkNotebook-related stuff
> Hi Andrei, > > I know this isn't a brilliant attempt, but it allows the signal that was > prevented from working, to work. > > It seems safer to return a long than anything else. > > I can't find a way to check what the pointer's actually pointing _to_, > otherwise it'd be able to cope with strings, objects, arrays, etc. But as > far as I recollect, the only place the lack of gpointer support hurt PHP-GTK > 1 was in this single GtkNotebook signal. All the PHP-GTK 2 demo and test > scripts I have at my disposal still work with the patch applied. > > Should I commit it, or does it require further investigation? > > - Steph >
---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ----
> -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php
["pointer.txt" (text/plain)]
Index: main/phpg_gvalue.c =================================================================== RCS file: /repository/php-gtk/main/phpg_gvalue.c,v retrieving revision 1.23 diff -u -r1.23 phpg_gvalue.c --- main/phpg_gvalue.c 2 Sep 2005 09:16:55 -0000 1.23 +++ main/phpg_gvalue.c 16 Sep 2005 19:46:16 -0000 @@ -173,6 +173,13 @@ break; }
+ case G_TYPE_POINTER: + { + MAKE_ZVAL_IF_NULL(*value); + ZVAL_LONG(*value, (long)g_value_get_pointer(gval)); + break; + } + default: php_error(E_WARNING, "PHP-GTK internal error: unsupported type %s", \ g_type_name(G_VALUE_TYPE(gval))); MAKE_STD_ZVAL(*value);
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] win32 line endings again
email.body:
I made some of the files (involved in the win32 build process only) with DOS endings because Windows 98 fights back otherwise, e.g. it won't run .bat files as later versions will. Everything else should have *nix endings.
Forget 'should have'. Has.
BTW Madeleine confirmed last week that PHP-GTK 2 _does_ run under Windows 98, so this is still a consideration :)
----- Original Message ----- From: "Tom Rogers" <trogers@kwikin.com> To: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Sunday, September 18, 2005 5:41 AM Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] win32 line endings again
> Hi, > > Saturday, September 17, 2005, 3:37:50 PM, you wrote: > TR> Hi > > TR> I just did a completely new checkout and came across a problem with > TR> windows line endings again in the generator scripts. This patch fixes > TR> the problem. > > Having investigated a bit further it looks like some of the files are > coming down as crcrlf (it is only files that have to do with windows) > everything else is crlf. > > Maybe someone uploaded with a Mac???? > > -- > regards, > Tom > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] First release?
email.body:
Andrei, all...
I've a handful of outstanding patches that need checking, but after those are resolved/committed I'd like to ask what's missing that actually prevents an initial release?
The three people able to test the Windows version have given useful feedback, but it'd be good to extend the field some and find out where users' priorities lie - and I know a lot of people want to try PHP-GTK 2, but just don't have the opportunity until we release something.
Comments, anyone? - if nothing else, it would be good to have an idea of the areas that most need focus.
- Steph
PS - Andrei, the TODO's kinda confusing at present because it sometimes gets things added to it when they're complete, like a NEWS file should. Can we stick to using it as a TODO and create a NEWS file following the initial release?
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Fw: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Error-killing
email.body:
Fixed. It needs this patch, and it needs gen_gtk.c to be included at the end of php_gtk+.h. If Andrei will allow me to do that, we have the means of building extensions now, give or take a couple of minor alterations to confutils.js for the doze sector.
Whether php_gtk_libglade2.dll actually works is a different matter, naturally :)
- Steph
----- Original Message ----- From: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> To: "Andrei" <andrei@gravitonic.com> Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Thursday, September 22, 2005 4:27 AM Subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Error-killing
> Creating library Release\php-gtk2.lib and object Release\php-gtk2.exp > gen_libglade.c > php_libglade.c > Creating library Release\php_gtk_libglade.lib and object > Release\php_gtk_libglade.exp > gen_libglade.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol > _phpg_handle_gerror > gen_libglade.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol _gtk_globals_id > gen_libglade.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol _gtkwidget_ce > gen_libglade.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol > _phpg_construct_exception > gen_libglade.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol _gobject_ce > Release\php_gtk_libglade.dll : fatal error LNK1120: 5 unresolved externals > NMAKE : fatal error U1077: '"C:\PROGRA~1\MICROS~3\VC98\BIN\link.exe"' : > return code '0x460' > Stop. > > Attached API-giving patch gets rid of the first of those. Three of the > others are in php-gtk2.lib anyway, and I don't know why they aren't being > picked up from there. The rank outsider is gtkwidget_ce, which turns up as > 'unresolved' even after I added #include "ext/gtk+/gen_gtk.h" to > libglade.overrides to replace the missing 'included include'. > > Naming's going to be an issue in this extension anyway I think, but it'd be > nice to get it as far as compiling... > > I'm about to update CVS with what I have, just in case anyone's feeling > bright. > > - Steph > > > >
---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ----
> -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Fw: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Why the libglade extension doesn't work
email.body:
ps I just tried building against a full version of ATK 1.9.0 with my overrides patch and everything loads now, including the GladeXML class and something that thinks it's called Libglade :)
Andrei, would you mind making 1.9.0 ATK rather than 1.8.0 required? It builds & works OK with that single change to the defs file.
----- Original Message ----- From: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> To: "Andrei" <andrei@gravitonic.com> Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Thursday, September 22, 2005 8:11 PM Subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Why the libglade extension doesn't work
> The ATK library I'm building PHP-GTK 2 against has a function missing, as do > our own sources (presumably originating from ATK 1.8.0 or earlier). > > The libglade .dll was built against ATK 1.9.0, and references (uses?) the > missing ATK function. > > Have written to Tor (who distributes the GTK+ dev headers and libs we use > for win32)... the override's simple enough to add, but should I be taking > this route? or trying to find another, possibly less recent, libglade > distribution? > > - Steph > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] #26067 [Ana->Csd]: node_get_cell_style doesn't work
email.body:
ID: 26067 Updated by: sniper@php.net Reported By: cweiske at cweiske dot de -Status: Analyzed +Status: Closed Bug Type: PHP-GTK related Operating System: windows xp PHP Version: 1.0.0 (PHP-GTK)
Previous Comments: ------------------------------------------------------------------------
[2004-01-28 18:23:07] andrei@php.net
By default the CTreeNodes do not have styles set. There are couple of things wrong with your script, consequently. You have to create a new style via "new GtkStyle()". Then you have to allocate the color correctly, by getting a colormap and using alloc() call on it. I modified the code to do that and it worked.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
[2004-01-19 00:17:35] sfox@php.net
Actually it's returning a stdClass instead of a GtkStyle object - but only if the style hasn't been set using node_set_cell_style(). It looks like the style object isn't being initialised at the point of realization. The question is whether this is deliberate :) I'm still trying to verify this, one way or the other.
BTW you're correct in assuming that the GtkCList equivalent works in much the same way; they use the same internal objects way deep in the mix (clistrow, cell).
------------------------------------------------------------------------
[2004-01-17 11:34:39] sfox@php.net
Apologies Christian, I didn't notice this report was outstanding until today's bug summary came through.
Looking into it.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
[2003-11-01 00:25:50] cweiske at cweiske dot de
Description: ------------ The "node_get_cell_style" of the GtkCTree widget does not work, it just returns NULL. The same problem should apply to the GtkCList.
Reproduce code: --------------- <?php dl( "php_gtk." . ( strstr( PHP_OS, "WIN") ? "dll" : "so")); function delete_event() { return false; } function destroy() { Gtk::main_quit(); } $window = &new GtkWindow(); $window->set_default_size( 200, 200); $window->connect('destroy', 'destroy'); $window->connect('delete-event', 'delete_event'); $tree = &new GtkCTree( 1, 0, array( "Style")); $window->add( $tree); $window->show_all();
$node = $tree->insert_node( null, null, array( "Text"), 5, null, null, null, null, false, false); $nodestyle = $tree->node_get_cell_style( $node, 0); print_r( $nodestyle);//should be NOT null $col1 = &new GdkColor(0, 56000, 0); $nodestyle->base[GTK_STATE_NORMAL] = $col1; $tree->node_set_cell_style( $node, 0, $nodestyle); Gtk::main(); ?>
Expected result: ---------------- the cell style of the first tree cell should have a nice color
------------------------------------------------------------------------
-- Edit this bug report at http://bugs.php.net/?id=26067&edit=1
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Fw: [PHP-GTK-DEV] [PATCH] Core changes needed for ext/libglade support
email.body:
Aha!
gobject is GladeXML's parent these days....
It's still _wrong_, but at least now I know why it's wrong :)
----- Original Message ----- From: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> To: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Cc: "Andrei" <andrei@gravitonic.com> Sent: Friday, September 23, 2005 11:50 AM Subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] [PATCH] Core changes needed for ext/libglade support
> Andrei, hi, > > If you can't/aren't prepared to bump the version requirement for ATK, let me > know and I'll find an earlier libglade to work with. Please let me know > fairly soon though, as some of the GladeXML functions have changed too. (I > haven't started work on the overrides yet.) > > Question: how worried would you be if the gobject methods turned up in an > extension class? > > Any clues as to what's happening here would be very welcome. > > C:\php5>php -r "print_r(get_class_methods('GladeXML'))"; > Array > ( > [0] => __construct > [1] => construct > [2] => get_widget > [3] => relative_file > [4] => signal_autoconnect // so far so good, this part matches > gen_libglade.c > [5] => __tostring // enter chaos... > [6] => connect > [7] => connect_after > [8] => connect_object > [9] => connect_object_after > [10] => get_property > [11] => set_property > [12] => get_data > [13] => set_data > [14] => block > [15] => unblock > [16] => disconnect > [17] => is_connected > [18] => signal_list_ids > [19] => signal_list_names > [20] => signal_query > ) > > C:\php5>php -r "print_r(get_class_methods('Libglade'))"; > Array > ( > [0] => get_widget_name // no problems here whatsoever > [1] => get_widget_tree > ) > > Could it be anything to do with gobject also having __construct() and > construct() methods declared? > > - Steph > >
---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ----

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Wish I'd tested this from the start..
email.body:
gtkaccelgroup_ce = phpg_register_class("GtkAccelGroup", gtkaccelgroup_methods, gobject_ce, 0, NULL, NULL, GTK_TYPE_ACCEL_GROUP TSRMLS_CC);
C:\php5>php -r "print_r(get_class_methods('GtkAccelGroup'))"; Array ( [0] => disconnect_key [1] => __construct [2] => __tostring [3] => connect [4] => connect_after [5] => connect_object [6] => connect_object_after [7] => get_property [8] => set_property [9] => get_data [10] => set_data [11] => block [12] => unblock [13] => disconnect [14] => is_connected [15] => signal_list_ids [16] => signal_list_names [17] => signal_query )
'Tis happening with every item that has GObject as a parent. Not just my extension.
I guess this needs fixing prior to release, but I've absolutely no idea where to start.
- Steph (who is going to stop being noisy now and clear off for the weekend)

Have a great weekend :-\

email.body:
Did you try with a fresh checkout since yesterday morning?
I hadn't found the GTK_SHARED cflag until then - that ought to help you some. Plus you need to include gen_gtk.h via php_gtk.h - I didn't apply this in CVS because it's core stuff and Andrei might need it to be absent for now.
RCS file: /repository/php-gtk/ext/gtk+/php_gtk+.h,v retrieving revision 1.21 diff -u -r1.21 php_gtk+.h --- ext/gtk+/php_gtk+.h 16 May 2005 21:00:02 -0000 1.21 +++ ext/gtk+/php_gtk+.h 22 Sep 2005 17:32:22 -0000 @@ -49,6 +49,8 @@
void php_gtk_plus_register_types();
+#include "gen_gtk.h" + #if 0 PHP_GTK_API extern int le_gtk_object; PHP_GTK_API extern int le_php_gtk_wrapper;

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] drawing functions
email.body:
It does work, actually - the var_dump($a) came good from the start.
I just got scribble.php running here (after a fashion) with a few internals adjustments, but I'm not getting anything useful from GTK_POINTER_MOTION_HINT_MASK - so is_hint is NEVER true. Fixing that's way beyond my capabilities.
gdk_window_get_pointer() apparently doesn't exist at all, which is pretty unhelpful :) I tried overriding it and got a bunch of errors related to the arg_info struct, whether I tried adding arg-info or not:
gen_gdk.c ext\gtk+\gen_gdk.c(4450) : error C2065: 'zif_GdkWindow_get_pointer' : undeclared identifier ext\gtk+\gen_gdk.c(4450) : error C2099: initializer is not a constant ext\gtk+\gen_gdk.c(4450) : warning C4047: 'initializing' : 'struct _zend_arg_info *' differs in levels of indirection from 'unsigned int ' NMAKE : fatal error U1077: 'cl' : return code '0x2'
although the actual function declaration went through OK.
I'll commit the rest of the event stuff tomorrow, still some bits to do there. I don't know of a good reason to have gdk_pixmap_new ignored, either... it seems to work fine?
----- Original Message ----- From: "Andrei Zmievski" <andrei@gravitonic.com> To: "Pablo Dall'Oglio" <pablo@dalloglio.net> Cc: <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Monday, September 26, 2005 5:45 PM Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] drawing functions

This code > > gives me an error: > > > > $a = new GdkGC($gdkwindow); > > var_dump($a); > > GdkDrawable::draw_rectangle($drawingarea, $a, 4, 4, 580, 340); > > > > Fatal error: Argument 1 must be an instance of GdkGC.... > > > > Does someone know how it works ? > > > > regards > > Pablo > > -- > > :: Pablo Dall'Oglio > > :: www.solis.coop.br - Lajeado, RS - Brasil > > :: www.dalloglio.net - Personal Home Page > > :: The software is free, but the work isn't. > > > > -- > > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Deeply nested properties
email.body:
Not an argument, just an opinion. I ran into same issue with DOM, although they are real and not psydo objects. The output was useless due to too much information and some properties were recursive.
I went for the all or none approach in implementing get_properties. If I couldnt show everything then show nothing. At least having to do some type of debugging would then be consistant rather than having a small subset of properties available in a var dump and requiring another mechanism to get the rest. This way its at least consistant in that some other technique must be used to dump any property info.
Rob
Andrei Zmievski wrote:
> What is his argument? > > -Andrei > >
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] win32 attempts
email.body:
Hi Steph,
> Frank, I'm confused - I started working on it because I thought you didn't > have time to do this? But I'll probably be glad when you do :) I haven't > had access to a full dev environment for most of the past year, it's like > starting over.
If everything works out as I plan I'll get more time in a couple of weeks. i'm putting some finishing touches on a new PHP5 book and an article for PHP Magazine.
> FWIW, I don't see any point in compiling PHP-GTK under Cygwin either - as > you said, it'd mean using a Cygwin runtime environment rather than native > win32 .dlls... pretty pointless given the nature of the beast. At present > the only 'extras' we need are those we needed for PHP-GTK 1 compilation > anyway, y'know, sed and grep, and then only for pre-compile src file > generation.
These are only needed for compilation and not for rge precompiled runtime. We might want to provide these files as an extra download so the extension can be compiled without extra tools.
- Frank > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Frank M. Kromann" <frank@kromann.info> > To: "Markus Fischer" <markus@fischer.name> > Cc: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> > Sent: Monday, August 08, 2005 5:08 AM > Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] win32 attempts > > > > Hi Markus, > > > > The first attempt from my side will be with Visual Studio, but it's > > possoble to compile PHP undr CugWin so I guess the next step would be to > > try that. Using CygWin will most likely require CygWin to be installed and > > as we already provide binaries for native Win32 installations I don't see > a > > real need for this. > > > > - Frank > > > > > Hi, > > > > > > what are you exactly trying to use as your build environment under > > > windows? I'm not sure if the definitive answer was that you need Visual > > > > > Studio components in some way or if you could rely on mingw or if cygwin > > > > > is sufficient. > > > > > > thanks, > > > - Markus > > > > > > Steph wrote: > > > > Hi Frank > > > > > > > > > > > >>My plan is to change the build system to allow building pgo php-gtk2 > > > >>sources the same way as we build pecl extensions > > > > > > > > > > > > Yes, that's what I'm doing :) My question was whether I should be > > doing it > > > > from the php-gtk2 toplevel src directory rather than the toplevel > > php-src > > > > directory. Thinking about it, I probably should - otherwise PHP-GTK > > > > extensions will believe they're PHP extensions, no? email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Deeply nested properties
email.body:
Andrei Zmievski wrote:
> a) expose everything and let those who use var_dump() haphazardly suffer. > b) do not expose GtkStyle properties. > > Option b) means that you will not see any properties on var_dump > ($style), that get_object_vars($style) will return an empty array, and > so on. You would still be able to access them normally, $style- >fg etc.
I vote for a. I can't think of a good reason off the top of my head but I am sure some one at some point will want to do this:
foreach (get_object_vars($style) as $key => $value) { .... }
Scott

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] win32 attempts
email.body:
Hi Andrei, Frank, all -
I've been messing around with the win32 build system today, with a little help from Rob Richards (who turned out to be a regex guru :).
The problems I'm hitting are mostly related to include paths - probably because I've opted to use the existing PHP build system and work from PHP's src root dir. Before I get too deeply snared up in this, is there any other good reason not to take that approach?
The win32 build system has a lot of utility functions, most of which would need to be ported across to PHP-GTK if it can't be used from the PHP source. (I should only need to add one to it to automate the generator.)
Thoughts? Clues? Flames?
- Steph
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] echo, log info and gen_* files
email.body:
Did I do some Bad Thing?
I'm getting info like:
======================================================================== Gtk Coverage ======================================================================== Functions : 57.4% written (85/148) Methods : 83.0% written (1604/1933) Constructors : 97.4% written (147/151) Property accessors : 100.0% written (174/174)
Unused arginfo overrides: GtkDialog::new_with_buttons ext\gtk+/gtk.overrides#541 GtkFileChooserDialog::new_with_backend ext\gtk+/gtk.overrides#699 GtkTreeStore::apend ext\gtk+/gtktreeview.overrides#303 GtkTreeViewColumn::new_with_attributes ext\gtk+/gtktreeview.overrides#592
- both in gen_gtk.c and in the logfile I (eventually) set for it.
Out-commenting line 94 in generator.php ("echo $output;") gets rid of it, but I can't see any other clear way to run the generator via this build system... the gen_* files need to be set up during the configure process, and 'the new win32 system' is pure wscript at that point. Calling PHP directly hangs the jabberscript process, so I'm having to go via a temporary batch file, which means the gen_* files pick up whatever goes to stdout.
Does anyone really need it to be echoed when it has the potential to be fully logged? Or do I need to find a way that doesn't pick up stdout? :)
BTW GtkTreeStore::apend is a typo...
- Steph
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] the error that won't go away
email.body:
Hi all,
I finally got the flags right (or at least, it looks that way), and am starting to produce healthy bouncing .obj files (and friends) from the files listed in php_gtk.m4.
At present if I run them through the mill I get through the gen_* files with nothing worse than a bunch of type conversion warnings (once I'd deleted the compiler-unfriendly debugging lines and 'fixed' all the phpg_rectangle_from_zval() calls with a dummy NULL parameter for build purposes), but then...
php_gtk+_types.c ext\gtk+\php_gtk+_types.c(141) : error C2198: 'phpg_tree_path_from_zval' : too few actual parameters ext\gtk+\php_gtk+_types.c(251) : error C2198: 'phpg_object_check' : too few actual parameters ext\gtk+\php_gtk+_types.c(265) : error C2198: 'phpg_object_check' : too few actual parameters ext\gtk+\php_gtk+_types.c(425) : error C2065: 'tsrm_ls' : undeclared identifier NMAKE : fatal error U1077: 'cl' : return code '0x2' Stop.
:-(
Adding TSRMLS_FETCH(); to line 393 fixes the tsrm_ls error there, on my box at least. There are further fatal compilation errors in phpg_support.c, phpg_gtype.c, php_gtk_util.c and phpg_gobject.c:
phpg_support.c main\phpg_support.c(128) : error C2198: 'function through pointer' : too few actual parameters // dodgy addition of dummy NULL param
phpg_gtype.c main\phpg_gtype.c(95) : error C2082: redefinition of formal parameter 'tsrm_ls' // remove TSRMLS_FETCH() main\phpg_gtype.c(166) : error C2065: 'tsrm_ls' : undeclared identifier // different function, and I am _lost_ here
php_gtk_util.c main\php_gtk_util.c(363) : error C2082: redefinition of formal parameter 'tsrm_ls' // remove TSRMLS_FETCH() main\php_gtk_util.c(535) : error C2198: 'parse_va_args' : too few actual parameters // dummy param main\php_gtk_util.c(831) : error C2198: 'php_gtk_count_specs' : too few actual parameters // dummy param main\php_gtk_util.c(834) : error C2198: 'php_gtk_count_specs' : too few actual parameters // dummy param
phpg_gobject.c main\phpg_gobject.c(345) : error C2198: 'phpg_gobject_watch_closure' : too few actual parameters // dummy param main\phpg_gobject.c(645) : error C2198: 'phpg_gtype_new' : too few actual parameters // dummy param main\phpg_gobject.c(649) : error C2198: 'phpg_gtype_new' : too few actual parameters // dummy param main\phpg_gobject.c(655) : error C2198: 'phpg_gtype_new' : too few actual parameters // dummy param
I got around most of them, probably breaking working code as I went, but that error in phpg_gtype.c has me completely beat. The relevant bit of code is in phpg_gtype_from_zval() and goes:
case IS_OBJECT: if (Z_OBJCE_P(value) == gtype_ce) { /* fatal error thrown here */ phpg_gtype_t *object = zend_object_store_get_object(value TSRMLS_CC); /* mere warnings that get more strident if I touch anything */ if (object) { return object->type; }
Anyone with clue, temporary or otherwise?
Cheers, - Steph
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

>>No. That's just a message for the php-gtk developers which do the >>reflection infos (that is, me). > Do you need it to go to stdout for reflection to work? or just for > debugging? Debugging. The functions listed there have reflection infos, but they aren't used. It would be a shame to waste them.
>>>Does anyone really need it to be echoed when it has the potential to be >>>fully logged? Or do I need to find a way that doesn't pick up stdout? >>I can disable it if you want to. > Thanks, but hold back a bit - it's probably best to wait for Wez to wake up > and respond, he'll know if there's a way around it.
It's really only for debugging. If everything is ok with the implemented arginfos, there wouldn't be any message. So it is an indicator that there is something which should be fixed.

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: From the wxPHP project
email.body:
Hello,
on 08/13/2005 05:12 PM Arthur Wiebe said the following: > I'm the admin and main developer from the > wxPHP<http://wxphp.sourceforge.net>project. > > Before anything else I want to say that my goal is not to compete with > GTK-PHP but to make it easy for anyone to build cross platform GUI apps > using PHP. > While I'm not against GTK itself, being a MacOS X user it's not exactly very > nice (currently it runs under X11). > wxWidgets is truly cross platform and I'm sure many will appreciate that. > > The work you guys are doing it great and because of that, I would like to > ask you a few questions. (I have just started doing actual work on the wxPHP > project so thought I'd better ask now.) > > Is there any advice you could give about writing PHP extensions that must > interact with the GUI or PHP extensions of this nature in general? > > Are there any major hurdles in building extensions such as this?
Why don't you just submit your project to PECL and ask about your difficulties in the PECL list where you will find some of the most qualified people in PHP extension development? You may start here:
http://pecl.php.net/account-request.php
--
Regards, Manuel Lemos

The functions listed there have reflection infos, but they > aren't used. It would be a shame to waste them. > > >>>Does anyone really need it to be echoed when it has the potential to be > >>>fully logged? Or do I need to find a way that doesn't pick up stdout? > >>I can disable it if you want to. > > Thanks, but hold back a bit - it's probably best to wait for Wez to wake up > > and respond, he'll know if there's a way around it. > > It's really only for debugging. If everything is ok with the implemented > arginfos, there wouldn't be any message. So it is an indicator that > there is something which should be fixed.
I was getting the full summary - headings and pretty formatting and all :) - because log_print() is called every time configure does something right, as well as when it does something wrong...
Do you get to see your debug info if you set "generator.php -l php://stdout" (etc etc etc)?
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] echo, log info and gen_* files
email.body:
(For list history purposes)
Wez' advice is that there isn't another approach that I could take, so the debugging info should be written to php://stderr instead - which is where it's sent by default anyway.
We need a) to remove the 'echo' call and b) to set it so that all the config logging info per run is appended to the same file, if possible.
Cheers, - Steph
(going on to fight with nmake now that's sorted)

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Edin's wonderful :)
email.body:
All,
I'm sitting here looking at a copy of php-gtk2.dll. php.exe thinks it should live in C:\php5 and won't load it from anywhere else, and it's asking for the GTK dlls it'll need to run, assuming it will at all. But it's looking hopeful :) and weighs a nice healthy 1.01Mb.
Thanks Edin.
Andrei, there are two ZEND_API declarations in PHP-GTK that shouldn't be there. One's the OnUpdateCodepage function in main\php_gtk.c, the other's the style_helper_free_storage function in ext\gtk+\php_gtk+_types.c. I'd got around the errors thrown by those two by defining LIBZEND_EXPORTS in the PHP-GTK 2 Makefile, and that clashed with the 'real' export declaration.
Going to celebrate first (naturally) and then will come back and download all the runtime stuff I need to test this baby.
Thanks to all of you for the various tips, tricks and nudges along the way!
- Steph
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Some strange errors in lastest from CVS
[PHP-GTK-DEV] Build problems
email.body:
I removed most of the extensions from HEAD, because some of them are not supported in PHP-GTK 2 yet and others don't make sense (like gdkpixbuf one). So, I'd like everyone to test downloading fresh CVS version and running buildconf on it and seeing whether you run into the same issues as before.
-Andrei

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Build problems
email.body:
On Aug 1, 2005, at 2:05 PM, Jani Taskinen wrote:
> > a) You still rely on aclocal being run. The real problem most > likely > has nothing to do with atk.
How do we avoid using aclocal? PHP build system only respects toplevel config.m4 file in the extension. PHP-GTK extensions have their own .m4 files. Do you see a solution without aclocal?
> b) What's the point with having config0.m4 and config.m4 in ext/ > gtk+/ ?
Just separation .. config0.m4 is the stuff copied from glib-2.0.m4 and gtk-2.0.m4 and config.m4 is the invocation of them.
-Andrei
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.body:

> On Aug 1, 2005, at 2:05 PM, Jani Taskinen wrote: > >> >> a) You still rely on aclocal being run. The real problem most likely >> has nothing to do with atk. > > How do we avoid using aclocal? PHP build system only respects toplevel > config.m4 file in the extension. PHP-GTK extensions have their own .m4 files. > Do you see a solution without aclocal?
Check the paths and versions with own macros.
--Jani

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] echo, log info and gen_* files
email.body:
On Aug 6, 2005, at 10:57 PM, Steph wrote:
> Out-commenting line 94 in generator.php ("echo $output;") gets rid > of it, > but I can't see any other clear way to run the generator via this > build > system... the gen_* files need to be set up during the configure > process, > and 'the new win32 system' is pure wscript at that point. Calling PHP > directly hangs the jabberscript process, so I'm having to go via a > temporary > batch file, which means the gen_* files pick up whatever goes to > stdout. > > Does anyone really need it to be echoed when it has the potential > to be > fully logged? Or do I need to find a way that doesn't pick up > stdout? :)
Yes, I very much prefer having the info appear during generation, as well as logged for future purposes. So, we'll just have to figure out a way to keep this functionality for everything but Windows.
-Andrei
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] echo, log info and gen_* files
email.body:
> Yes, I very much prefer having the info appear during generation, as > well as logged for future purposes. So, we'll just have to figure out > a way to keep this functionality for everything but Windows. >
We'll need to ifdef it then, that way you can send it anywhere you like. It comes into my files if it goes through stderr too, but as I said - setting a logfile in the generator call solves that problem, so long as the echo isn't there.
Am I correct in believing we only need the gen_*.c and gen_*.h files now, there's no gen_*.ce to worry about any more?
- Steph
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

What about a switch in the debug function: if (windows) {return;} else { print_out}?
-- Regards/MfG, Christian Weiske

email.subject: RE: [PHP-GTK-DEV] win32 attempts
email.body:
I can't help you with any of this, but I'm glad to see you're attempting to build it under win32. Is there a good explanation available on howto build php-gtk2 under win32 or is it far from complete? If there is one, I'd be glad to read it, cause I'm most anxious to start testing php-gtk2 my own.
Davy
-----Oorspronkelijk bericht----- Van: Steph [mailto:steph@zend.com] Verzonden: vrijdag 5 augustus 2005 20:20 Aan: PHP-GTK dev Onderwerp: [PHP-GTK-DEV] win32 attempts
Hi Andrei, Frank, all -
I've been messing around with the win32 build system today, with a little help from Rob Richards (who turned out to be a regex guru :).
The problems I'm hitting are mostly related to include paths - probably because I've opted to use the existing PHP build system and work from PHP's src root dir. Before I get too deeply snared up in this, is there any other good reason not to take that approach?
The win32 build system has a lot of utility functions, most of which would need to be ported across to PHP-GTK if it can't be used from the PHP source. (I should only need to add one to it to automate the generator.)
Thoughts? Clues? Flames?
- Steph
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] win32 attempts
email.body:
Well you could turn that argument arround to 'We should not support an OS used by only a handfull of geeks. We should support the OS where the most users are.'
PHP-GTK is intended for client application and not for web servers and the last time I checked Linux on the desktop did not account for many percent of the total desktop market.
- Frank

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] win32 attempts
email.body:
Hi Frank
> My plan is to change the build system to allow building pgo php-gtk2 > sources the same way as we build pecl extensions
Yes, that's what I'm doing :) My question was whether I should be doing it from the php-gtk2 toplevel src directory rather than the toplevel php-src directory. Thinking about it, I probably should - otherwise PHP-GTK extensions will believe they're PHP extensions, no? (NB At present I'd be happy with a base PHP-GTK build, and I guess it doesn't matter which directory that's based in for now.)
> That I don't expect to be too hard.
I agree - it seems a lot more straightforward than the standard .dsp route.
> The bigest problem right now is to get the time to actually work on this. > It's not something I expect done in a single day or week.
I have time, for once. And as I say, it _appears_ absolutely straightforward. I just needed an answer to the question I asked.
- Steph

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] win32 attempts
email.body:
Frank, I'm confused - I started working on it because I thought you didn't have time to do this? But I'll probably be glad when you do :) I haven't had access to a full dev environment for most of the past year, it's like starting over.
FWIW, I don't see any point in compiling PHP-GTK under Cygwin either - as you said, it'd mean using a Cygwin runtime environment rather than native win32 .dlls... pretty pointless given the nature of the beast. At present the only 'extras' we need are those we needed for PHP-GTK 1 compilation anyway, y'know, sed and grep, and then only for pre-compile src file generation.

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Deeply nested properties
email.body:
> Andrei Zmievski wrote: > > > a) expose everything and let those who use var_dump() haphazardly suffer. > > b) do not expose GtkStyle properties. > > > > Option b) means that you will not see any properties on var_dump > > ($style), that get_object_vars($style) will return an empty array, and > > so on. You would still be able to access them normally, $style- >fg etc. > > I vote for a. I can't think of a good reason off the top of my head but > I am sure some one at some point will want to do this: > > foreach (get_object_vars($style) as $key => $value) { > .... > } > > Scott
ugh - that's 'haphazardly' :)
It's a tough decision because GtkStyle isn't a widget. I don't have GTK 2 source handy but, assuming it's the same principle as GTK 1, GtkStyle's not even cast as an object - it's just a struct, pure'n'simple. So I'd look at that as a documentation issue rather than as a dev issue - would you expect get_object_vars() to return the (nested or otherwise) properties of a third-party struct? Likewise, what would you expect var_dump() to return?
ps Andrei I took advice on irc and it was suggested I look at ext/simplexml for a precedent, but I'm afraid I didn't get far with that 'cos as far as I can see php_sxe_object _is_ treated as a genuine object....? (soap looked more promising).
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

Regards/MfG, Christian Weiske -- XMMS is playing now:

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: Deeply nested properties
email.body:
My 2 cents is don't do it. For example, within the DOM extension, I purposely didnt add this functionality. Nesting goes too deep and not too mention many of the properties are recursive.
If the var is being debugged, there are probably much better ways to get info of the variable than output everything under the sun and trying to sift through it all.
just my 2 cents.
Rob
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: Deeply nested properties
Fw: [PHP-GTK-DEV] the error that won't go away [probably solved]
email.body:
OK, following off-list advice (thanks Wez) I'll replace all those dummy NULLs with TSRMLS_CC's /TSRMLS_DC's and matching bits in the headers as appropriate. Wez also said that anyone wanting to help from a *nix perspective could do so here, if they'd like to build against a ZTS version of PHP - that way you'll get to see the code errors anyone attempting to build on Windows would fall across.
Somewhere between times I've jumped ahead and found my build target (php-gtk.dll) has a circular dependency, described as 'The given target is a dependent of one of the dependents of the given target'. I guess that means I should've followed the .m4 files more closely and kept the /main and /ext/gtk+ files apart during make...
----- Original Message ----- From: "Steph" <steph@zend.com> To: "PHP-GTK dev" <php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net> Sent: Wednesday, August 10, 2005 5:33 AM Subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] the error that won't go away
> Hi all, > > I finally got the flags right (or at least, it looks that way), and am > starting to produce healthy bouncing .obj files (and friends) from the files > listed in php_gtk.m4. > > At present if I run them through the mill I get through the gen_* files with > nothing worse than a bunch of type conversion warnings (once I'd deleted the > compiler-unfriendly debugging lines and 'fixed' all the > phpg_rectangle_from_zval() calls with a dummy NULL parameter for build > purposes), but then... > > php_gtk+_types.c > ext\gtk+\php_gtk+_types.c(141) : error C2198: 'phpg_tree_path_from_zval' : > too few actual parameters > ext\gtk+\php_gtk+_types.c(251) : error C2198: 'phpg_object_check' : too few > actual parameters > ext\gtk+\php_gtk+_types.c(265) : error C2198: 'phpg_object_check' : too few > actual parameters > ext\gtk+\php_gtk+_types.c(425) : error C2065: 'tsrm_ls' : undeclared > identifier > NMAKE : fatal error U1077: 'cl' : return code '0x2' > Stop. > > :-( > > Adding TSRMLS_FETCH(); to line 393 fixes the tsrm_ls error there, on my box > at least. There are further fatal compilation errors in phpg_support.c, > phpg_gtype.c, php_gtk_util.c and phpg_gobject.c: > > phpg_support.c > main\phpg_support.c(128) : error C2198: 'function through pointer' : too few > actual parameters // dodgy addition of dummy NULL param > > phpg_gtype.c > main\phpg_gtype.c(95) : error C2082: redefinition of formal parameter > 'tsrm_ls' // remove TSRMLS_FETCH() > main\phpg_gtype.c(166) : error C2065: 'tsrm_ls' : undeclared identifier // > different function, and I am _lost_ here > > php_gtk_util.c > main\php_gtk_util.c(363) : error C2082: redefinition of formal parameter > 'tsrm_ls' // remove TSRMLS_FETCH() > main\php_gtk_util.c(535) : error C2198: 'parse_va_args' : too few actual > parameters // dummy param > main\php_gtk_util.c(831) : error C2198: 'php_gtk_count_specs' : too few > actual parameters // dummy param > main\php_gtk_util.c(834) : error C2198: 'php_gtk_count_specs' : too few > actual parameters // dummy param > > phpg_gobject.c > main\phpg_gobject.c(345) : error C2198: 'phpg_gobject_watch_closure' : too > few actual parameters // dummy param > main\phpg_gobject.c(645) : error C2198: 'phpg_gtype_new' : too few actual > parameters // dummy param > main\phpg_gobject.c(649) : error C2198: 'phpg_gtype_new' : too few actual > parameters // dummy param > main\phpg_gobject.c(655) : error C2198: 'phpg_gtype_new' : too few actual > parameters // dummy param > > I got around most of them, probably breaking working code as I went, but > that error in phpg_gtype.c has me completely beat. The relevant bit of code > is in phpg_gtype_from_zval() and goes: > > case IS_OBJECT: > if (Z_OBJCE_P(value) == gtype_ce) { /* fatal error thrown here */ > phpg_gtype_t *object = zend_object_store_get_object(value TSRMLS_CC); > /* mere warnings that get more strident if I touch anything */ > if (object) { > return object->type; > } > > Anyone with clue, temporary or otherwise? > > Cheers, > - Steph > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] From the wxPHP project
email.body:
Hi,
I'm the admin and main developer from the wxPHP<http://wxphp.sourceforge.net>project.
Before anything else I want to say that my goal is not to compete with GTK-PHP but to make it easy for anyone to build cross platform GUI apps using PHP. While I'm not against GTK itself, being a MacOS X user it's not exactly very nice (currently it runs under X11). wxWidgets is truly cross platform and I'm sure many will appreciate that.
The work you guys are doing it great and because of that, I would like to ask you a few questions. (I have just started doing actual work on the wxPHP project so thought I'd better ask now.)
Is there any advice you could give about writing PHP extensions that must interact with the GUI or PHP extensions of this nature in general?
Are there any major hurdles in building extensions such as this?
I've been sort of following GTK-PHP for awhile now. I simply hope you might be able to share your thoughts a little. I'm all for this project and believe that wxPHP will only improve the way people view PHP and also believe it will compliment this GTK-PHP project.
Thanks and blessings -- <Arthur/>

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: From the wxPHP project
email.body:
Hello,
on 08/15/2005 06:18 PM Arthur Wiebe said the following: > I've thought about starting it on PECL but decided it would be better to get > a "working something" to announce first. I do plan on adding it to PECL > though.
That is wise too.
I think wxWindows would have been a much better solution than GTK to provide cross platform GUI development for PHP because AFAIK wxWindows uses native windows and widgets. GTK applications provide a look and feel that really does not match the underlying platform GUI on Windows and Mac OS X. So IMHO your wxPHP will be a very welcome extension.
--
Regards, Manuel Lemos
PHP Classes - Free ready to use OOP components written in PHP http://www.phpclasses.org/
PHP Reviews - Reviews of PHP books and other products http://www.phpclasses.org/reviews/
Metastorage - Data object relational mapping layer generator http://www.meta-language.net/metastorage.html

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] nearly there (I think)
email.body:
OK, back from holiday now.
C:\PROGRA~1\MICROS~3\VC98\BIN\link.exe /out:Release\php-gtk.dll /dll /nologo Release\main\php_gtk.obj Release\main\phpg_support.obj Release\main\phpg_gtype.obj Release\main\phpg_exceptions.obj Release\main\php_gtk_util.obj Release\main\phpg_gvalue.obj Release\main\phpg_closure.obj Release\main\phpg_gboxed.obj Release\main\phpg_gobject.obj Release\ext\gtk+\gen_atk.obj Release\ext\gtk+\gen_pango.obj Release\ext\gtk+\gen_gdk.obj Release\ext\gtk+\gen_gtk.obj Release\ext\gtk+\php_gdk.obj Release\ext\gtk+\php_gtk+.obj Release\ext\gtk+\php_gtk+_types.obj php5ts.lib atk-1.0.lib glib-2.0.lib gmodule-2.0.lib gthread-2.0.lib gobject-2.0.lib pango-1.0.lib pangowin32-1.0.lib gdk_pixbuf-2.0.lib gdk-win32-2.0.lib gtk-win32-2.0.lib kernel32.lib user32.lib gdi32.lib winspool.lib comdlg32.lib advapi32.lib shell32.lib ole32.lib Release\php-gtk.dll.res Creating library Release\php-gtk.lib and object Release\php-gtk.exp php_gtk.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol _php_gtk_startup_all_extensions gen_gtk.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol _executor_globals_id php_gtk+_types.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol _executor_globals_id phpg_support.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol _executor_globals_id php_gtk_util.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol _executor_globals_id phpg_closure.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol _executor_globals_id phpg_gobject.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol _executor_globals_id phpg_exceptions.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol _zend_throw_exception_internal gen_gtk.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol _gtk_plug_get_type gen_gtk.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol _gtk_socket_get_type php_gtk+.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol _core_globals_id Release\php-gtk.dll : fatal error LNK1120: 6 unresolved externals
zend_throw_exception_internal() isn't exported anyway - shouldn't this break on other compilers too?
No idea why the PHP/Zend global macros aren't resolved, given that they're sitting prettily in php5ts.lib - could it be a ZTS thing?
GtkPlug and GtkSocket are missing from Tor's win32 GTK implementation, which explains those two (I guess they need if'n'def-ing for PHP-GTK 2, for now at least).
I'm completely clueless about the problem with php_gtk_startup_all_extensions... anyone have any idea?
- Steph
