email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] ZTS specific fixes - all clues welcome
email.body:
C:\sandbox\php-gtk>nmake
Microsoft (R) Program Maintenance Utility Version 6.00.8168.0 Copyright (C) Microsoft Corp 1988-1998. All rights reserved.
C:\PROGRA~1\MICROS~3\VC98\BIN\link.exe /out:Release\php-gtk.dll /dll /machine:I386 /nologo Release\main\phpg_support.obj Release\main\phpg_gtype.obj Release\main\phpg_exceptions.obj Release\main\php_gtk_util.obj Release\main\phpg_gvalue.obj Release\main\phpg_closure.obj Release\main\phpg_gboxed.obj Release\main\phpg_gobject.obj Release\main\php_gtk_ext.w32.obj Release\main\php_gtk.obj Release\ext\gtk+\gen_atk.obj Release\ext\gtk+\gen_pango.obj Release\ext\gtk+\gen_gdk.obj Release\ext\gtk+\gen_gtk.obj Release\ext\gtk+\php_gdk.obj Release\ext\gtk+\php_gtk+.obj Release\ext\gtk+\php_gtk+_types.obj php5ts.lib atk-1.0.lib glib-2.0.lib gmodule-2.0.lib gthread-2.0.lib gobject-2.0.lib pango-1.0.lib pangowin32-1.0.lib gdk_pixbuf-2.0.lib gdk-win32-2.0.lib gtk-win32-2.0.lib kernel32.lib user32.lib gdi32.lib winspool.lib comdlg32.lib advapi32.lib shell32.lib ole32.lib Release\php-gtk.dll.res Creating library Release\php-gtk.lib and object Release\php-gtk.exp gen_gtk.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol _executor_globals_id php_gtk+_types.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol _executor_globals_id phpg_support.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol _executor_globals_id php_gtk_util.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol _executor_globals_id phpg_closure.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol _executor_globals_id phpg_gobject.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol _executor_globals_id php_gtk+.obj : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol _core_globals_id Release\php-gtk.dll : fatal error LNK1120: 2 unresolved externals NMAKE : fatal error U1077: 'C:\PROGRA~1\MICROS~3\VC98\BIN\link.exe' : return code '0x460' Stop.
zend_globals.h and php_globals.h both differentiate between ZTS and other builds for the executor/core globals respectively, so I guess there's something generic I need to add to PHP-GTK 2 source to kill the error every time EG() or PG() is called. Anyone know what that 'something generic' might be?
Thanks, - Steph
PS I replaced zend_throw_exception_internal() with zend_throw_exception_object() because the former isn't exported as part of the Zend API...

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] diagnosed but hard to fix segfault
email.body:
Hi Wez,
I ran my shiny new but painfully silent php-gtk.dll under the MSVC++ debugger last night, and found that php.exe isn't registering the php-gtk module as it should. It gets as far as module_registry_request_startup():
module->module_number 22 - module->name 0x00d01118 "php-gtk" 112 'p' module->request_startup_func 0x00b7eea0 module->type 1 '' zend_printf 0x10004d04 _php_printf
but then bails out. In zend_hash_apply(), pLast and pListNext for arKey 'php-gtk' are both completely data-free zones. From userland, php -m lists the loaded php-gtk module as expected, but php -v or any attempt to run a script while php-gtk.dll is loaded will crash PHP. I'm assuming the debug stuff and the userland stuff match up here.
Today I looked through configure.js properly, and found that what happens during EXTENSION() includes adding the header with the module pointer declaration to main\internal_functions.c.
That'll be where this falls down then, I guess? Not only is the (relative-to-src-root) giving the wrong module path information, but PHP is already built anyway.
So, is there a way to build against an existing copy of php5ts.lib from outside the PHP source tree using the 'new' win32 build system? Or do I still need to use .dsp files to do this? Or am I swimming up completely the wrong creek in a paddle-free manner?
- Steph
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: diagnosed but hard to fix segfault
email.body:
Sounds like you want to force the extension to build as a shared extension.... but if you already have php-gtk.dll it's doing that. The problem is probably something else. My suggestion is to run it under a debugger and see where it blows up.
My personal preference for this kind of thing is WinDBG, part of Debugging Tools for Windows (google will show you where on microsoft.com you can get this). Run WinDBG, then tell it to "open executable", browse to your php.exe and enter the command line arguments (path to the script) and then click OK; it will load up php but pause it before it runs main(). Then click the "go" button (F5). It should run and catch the problem before it blows up. The view menu will let you see the call stack.
You should be able to do the same kinds of things with the visual studio/visual c++ debugger that you already have installed. Although it has a more friendly interface, I personally find that it takes too long to launch and occupies too much memory for my tastes.
For best results, make sure you're building a debug build of PHP and a debug build of php-gtk.dll. (in fact, the debug-ness of both those things must match in any case).
As for building extensions from outside the main trees, you're the first to have tried that with the new build system... In theory there should be no problems if your compiler is using the same header files and simply links against the .lib file.
As a hack, I'd suggest sticking your php-gtk sources in the following arrangement:
php5src/configure.js pecl/phpgtk/config.w32
eg: have a pecl dir alongside the php-src checkout, and under that, have the gtk sources. The built-in configure process should pick that up as though it were a regular pecl package and build it as part of the main build. Not quite what you were asking for, but useful to verify that the package works.
Hope that helps,
--Wez.
Steph wrote: > Hi Wez, > > I ran my shiny new but painfully silent php-gtk.dll under the MSVC++ > debugger last night, and found that php.exe isn't registering the php-gtk > module as it should. It gets as far as module_registry_request_startup(): > > module->module_number 22 > - module->name 0x00d01118 "php-gtk" > 112 'p' > module->request_startup_func 0x00b7eea0 > module->type 1 '' > zend_printf 0x10004d04 _php_printf > > but then bails out. In zend_hash_apply(), pLast and pListNext for arKey > 'php-gtk' are both completely data-free zones. From userland, php -m lists > the loaded php-gtk module as expected, but php -v or any attempt to run a > script while php-gtk.dll is loaded will crash PHP. I'm assuming the debug > stuff and the userland stuff match up here. > > Today I looked through configure.js properly, and found that what happens > during EXTENSION() includes adding the header with the module pointer > declaration to main\internal_functions.c. > > That'll be where this falls down then, I guess? Not only is the > (relative-to-src-root) giving the wrong module path information, but PHP is > already built anyway. > > So, is there a way to build against an existing copy of php5ts.lib from > outside the PHP source tree using the 'new' win32 build system? Or do I > still need to use .dsp files to do this? Or am I swimming up completely the > wrong creek in a paddle-free manner? > > - Steph > >
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Some strange errors in lastest from CVS
email.body:
I have fixed this in the latest CVS. Note that GtkProgressBar inherits from GtkProgress and set_value() method is deprecated. You are supposed to use set_fraction() instead.
-Andrei
On Aug 10, 2005, at 7:42 AM, Escuder Nicolas wrote:
> Hello, > > > > > > Some strange action in the lastest php-gtk2 from CVS : > > > > > > - We get an GtkProgress when doing an "new GtkProgressBar" > > - We get Critical Error when construct GtkAdjustment > > > > > > I known GtkProgressBar doesn't need GtkAdjustment but I get this > message : > (test.php:23073): Gtk-CRITICAL **: > gtk_progress_bar_new_with_adjustment: > assertion `GTK_IS_ADJUSTMENT (adjustment)' failed > > If I don't pass an GtkAdjustment > > > > > > Hope this help to improve php-gtk2 > > > > See you > > > > Nicolas. > > > > > > > > Here the sample script : > > > > <? > > if (!class_exists('gtk')) > > dl( 'php_gtk2.' . (strstr( PHP_OS, 'WIN') ? 'dll' : 'so')); > > > > $wd = new GtkWindow(GTK_WINDOW_TOPLEVEL); > > > > $adj = new GtkAdjustment(0, 0, 100, 1, 10, 0); > > $progress = new GtkProgressBar($adj); > > > > $progress->set_size_request(360, 20); > > $wd->add($progress); > > $wd->show_all(); > > > > > > function changebar() { > > global $pourcent, $progress, $adj; > > if ($pourcent == 100) > > $pourcent = 0; > > else > > $pourcent++; > > > > $adj->set_value($pourcent); > > $progress->set_value($pourcent); > > Gtk::timeout_add(1000, changebar); > > echo "change to $pourcent\n"; > > } > > > > Gtk::timeout_add(1000, changebar); > > > > > > Gtk::main(); > > ?> > > > > > > Here the result : > > > > [root@toad tmp]# php test.php > > > > (test.php:23066): GLib-GObject-CRITICAL **: g_value_set_float: > assertion > `G_VALUE_HOLDS_FLOAT (value)' failed > > > > (test.php:23066): GLib-GObject-CRITICAL **: g_value_set_float: > assertion > `G_VALUE_HOLDS_FLOAT (value)' failed > > > > (test.php:23066): GLib-GObject-CRITICAL **: g_value_set_float: > assertion > `G_VALUE_HOLDS_FLOAT (value)' failed > > > > (test.php:23066): GLib-GObject-CRITICAL **: g_value_set_float: > assertion > `G_VALUE_HOLDS_FLOAT (value)' failed > > > > (test.php:23066): GLib-GObject-CRITICAL **: g_value_set_float: > assertion > `G_VALUE_HOLDS_FLOAT (value)' failed > > > > (test.php:23066): GLib-GObject-CRITICAL **: g_value_set_float: > assertion > `G_VALUE_HOLDS_FLOAT (value)' failed > > PHP Warning: GtkProgress::set_value() is deprecated: use > GtkProgressBar in > /tmp/test.php on line 24 > > > > Warning: GtkProgress::set_value() is deprecated: use GtkProgressBar in > /tmp/test.php on line 24 > > change to 1 > > PHP Warning: GtkProgress::set_value() is deprecated: use > GtkProgressBar in > /tmp/test.php on line 24 > > > > Warning: GtkProgress::set_value() is deprecated: use GtkProgressBar in > /tmp/test.php on line 24 > > change to 2 > > > > > > > > > >

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Possible bugs
email.body:
On Jul 31, 2005, at 3:15 AM, Christian Weiske wrote:
> Hi Andrei, > > > - I noted that gtk_file_chooser_dialog_new_with_backend and > gtk_dialog_new_with_buttons aren't created. Shall that be so? > (gtk_tree_view_column_new_with_attributes isn't created, too - but > there > is a number of alternative constructors (GtkButton) which are created, > so it shouldn't be the generator)
The functionality of gtk_file_chooser_dialog_new_with_backend() and gtk_dialog_new_with_buttons() is incorporated into the respective constructors, so generating them is not necessary.
> - gtktree.overrides#gtk_tree_store_append has optional parameters > only. > Why? (Or didn't I fully understand the meaning of the "|" in > php_gtk_parse_args?)
That is correct. Without any parameters, GtkTreeStore::append() will append an empty row and return an iterator pointing to it. After that you can use the set() method to set the column values. If you pass parameters to append() then those value will be set right away.
> - Same for gtk_tree_model_iter_children
See http://developer.gnome.org/doc/API/2.0/gtk/GtkTreeModel.html#gtk- tree-model-iter-children.
-Andrei
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re-parenting widgets (php-gtk2)
email.body:
Hi,
While playing around with re-parenting widgets, I noted that if I re-parent a widget back to one where it already has been, the widgets don't react to any action anymore.
Oh yeah, and you can't use widgets as array keys - that's not so nice.
Demo: http://xml.cweiske.de/phpgtk2/reparent.phpw (Click "reparent" some times and try a "down" -> widgets hang)
Regards/MfG, Christian Weiske -- XMMS is playing now:
["signature.asc" (application/pgp-signature)]

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Arginfo
email.body:
Christian,
I saw you added a new keyword 'add-arginfo'. That's fine, but I think we should templatize the arginfo variable name, like I do with PHP_METHOD declaration.
Instead of doing:
add-arginfo arginfo_gdk_gdkcolor_color_parse
We should do something like:
add-arginfo GdkColor parse
You should be able to derive the arginfo variable name based on this and use it in declaration and PHP_ME() entry. Much more convenient.
-Andrei
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.body:
> Instead of doing: > add-arginfo arginfo_gdk_gdkcolor_color_parse > We should do something like: > add-arginfo GdkColor parse Ok.
Regards/MfG, Christian Weiske -- XMMS is playing now:
["signature.asc" (application/pgp-signature)]

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re-parenting widgets (php-gtk2)
email.body:
Hi Christian,
Christian Weiske wrote:
> Oh yeah, and you can't use widgets as array keys - that's not so nice.
This is a PHP thing not a PHP-GTK issue. From http://us2.php.net/manual/en/language.types.array.php: "A key may be either an integer or a string."
Scott
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re-parenting widgets (php-gtk2)
email.body:
Christian,
Have you seen this FAQ entry?
http://gtk.org/faq/#AEN636
It is very easy to reparent widgets with simple remove() and add() without even needing to do the refcounting. I modified your example to do just that and it works fine.
-Andrei

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] July News
email.body:
Ok. Here is a first round (I'll add links later):
PHP-GTK 2 at the International PHP Conference Jeremy Johnstone will be presenting a talk titled "GUI Development in PHP-GTK2" at the International PHP Conference in November. Anyone going to the conference should be sure to check out his talk. The discussion includes "in depth coverage of developing a GUI application in PHP-GTK2 including tools you can use to allow you to rapidly develop new applications."
Win9x Support in PHP 5.1 There is talk on the PHP Internals mailing list about removing support for Win9x (95/98/2000/ME) from PHP 5.1. For most PHP developers this isn't much of a big deal but for PHP-GTK 2 developers it may a much more significant impact. If you have reasons to keep Win9x support in PHP, make sure to voice your opinion! http://marc.theaimsgroup.com/?l=php-dev&m=112142925911670&w=2
Send more news!
Scott

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: [PHP-GTK] Menu Help
email.body:
Hi Christopher,
Christopher Logan wrote:
> I am trying to create the same thing I got the File -> Open menu and the > GtkFileChooserDialog to work. Just trying to figure out now how to get > the selected file name and location back from the dialog then I suppose > buffer it and add it to the textarea. > > Here is what I have thus far: > http://www.okphp.org/downloads/texteditor.txt
What you need to do is create a function that is called when the user hits the OK/Submit/Whatever button on the file chooser. That function should be passed the fileChooser and the textView so that it can get the file name, then get the file contents and then put them in the textView.
Scott
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Signal handler methods
email.body:
Scott Mattocks wrote: > I am having trouble finding some of the GtkWidget methods in PHP-GTK 2. > In particular the *signal_handler methods. There is no information in > the source files or overrides and the methods don't show up in the > output from getMethods() on a reflection instance. Do these methods need > to be written by hand? They are still a part of Gtk+ 2 > (http://developer.gnome.org/doc/API/2.0/gtk/gtk-Signals.html#gtk-signal-handler-block) > but I can't find them anywhere in PHP-GTK 2. They are also not being > generated in the docs.
In ext/gtk+/gtk.overrides in the ignore-glob group is:
gtk_signal_*
which means that the complete family of gtk_signal_* is not generated in any way.
As of why: I'm not exactly sure, but the gtk signals page you gave states "For future usage, direct use of the GSignal API is recommended," and since we don't wrap the glib api that may be the reason.
- Markus
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Signal handler methods
FW: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Getting PHP-GTK 2 from CVS
email.body:
I'm very anxious to start testing with php-gtk2 (so are two friends of mine, but because of the lack of a decent explanation (for someone not very into building projects) on how to do this properly and the steps that have to be taken (and what can - and will probably - go wrong.) I'm not capable of doing this.
Someone a somewhat novice explanation? Win32 would be great, but I have ubuntu installed as well as second os.
regards
-----Oorspronkelijk bericht----- Van: Christopher Logan [mailto:chris@b40d.com] Verzonden: dinsdag 5 juli 2005 23:56 Aan: php-gtk-dev@lists.php.net Onderwerp: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Getting PHP-GTK 2 from CVS
What is the address to get PHP-GTK 2 from cvs? I finally got PHP 5.1 installed it was the development package of libxml2. I tried
cvs -d :pserver:cvsread@cvs.php.net:/repository co -r PHP_GTK_1 php-gtk
but thats PHP-GTK 1 and I tried
cvs -d :pserver:cvsread@cvs.php.net:/repository co -r PHP_GTK_2 php-gtk
I also tried to login with
cvs -d :pserver:cvsread@cvs.php.net:/repository login
password: phpfi but with no luck.

email.body:
Ok got libglade and libglade-devel ./configure worked all the way through with no problems that I see typed make and get a bunch of errors from glib2 I have to be missing something but have checked and can't find anything:
/usr/include/glib-2.0/gobject/gparam.h:30: error: syntax error before 'G_BEGIN_DECLS' /usr/include/glib-2.0/gobject/gparam.h:49: error: syntax error before 'typedef' /usr/include/glib-2.0/gobject/gparam.h:141: error: syntax error before 'gchar' /usr/include/glib-2.0/gobject/gparam.h:142: error: syntax error before 'gchar' /usr/include/glib-2.0/gobject/gparam.h:143: error: syntax error before 'gchar'
/usr/include/glib-2.0/gobject/gsourceclosure.h:28: error: syntax error before 'G_BEGIN_DECLS' /usr/include/glib-2.0/gobject/gsourceclosure.h:30: error: syntax error before 'void' /usr/include/glib-2.0/gobject/gsourceclosure.h:30: error: syntax error before '*' token In file included from /usr/include/glib-2.0/glib-object.h:33, from /root/php-gtk/main/php_gtk.h:56, from /root/php-gtk/./ext/gtk+/php_gtk+.c:23:
/root/php-gtk/./ext/gtk+/php_gtk+.c:162: warning: assignment makes pointer from integer without a cast make: *** [ext/gtk+/php_gtk+.lo] Error 1
Any ideas on what this is? I think I remember reading that it would compile with the newest version of GCC or Make would that be the problem? I'm running Fedora Core 4 with Make 3.80 and GCC 4.0.
> Running ./buildconf a second time fixed the problem. Just got to get > libglade now and I should have it. > >> Ok next issue, when I got the source from: >> cvs -d :pserver:cvsread@cvs.php.net:/repository co php-gtk >> >> Which is hopefully right, I do ./buildconf but the configure comes back >> as >> a blank file. email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] PHP-GTK 2 status update needed
email.body:
What would you consider an alpha version? What set of features should it have? How much of Gtk+ API should it cover? These are the questions that need to be answered before releasing anything.
I have been pretty much the only one working on the new version of PHP-GTK for months now (as opposed to PHP-GTK 1 where I had Markus, Alan, and others who were helping out). It is becoming clear that the bottleneck is also due to my simply being busy with other things in my life. Architecturally, I know what needs to be done and what sort of code needs to be written, but I just lack the available cycles to sit down and do it every day. I may be able to dedicate a few hours every other week to this, and there is still a lot of work to finish. So unless I get a couple of helpers I'm afraid this is the pace we're going to continue at.
-Andrei
On Jul 5, 2005, at 11:54 AM, Christopher Logan wrote:
> Is everyone on vacation or has PHP-GTK 2 come to a major slowdown. I > wouldn't mind testing PHP-GTK 2 but can't get PHP 5.1 to compile on > Fedora Core 4 even though Fedora should have everything it needs since > PHP 5 comes compiled with Fedora. At any rate I think a compiled alpha > version is in order to get people both bug testing and using so they > can create some documentation for PHP-GTK 2. > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Getting PHP-GTK 2 from CVS
email.body:
Christopher Logan wrote: > Could it be that I am using the PHP 5.1 beta 2 and not from cvs?
I don't claim to be any kind of authority on install issues but I don't think this issue has anything to do with PHP. The messages you are getting are from C code not PHP. There was a nice long discussion on configure and build issues about a month ago. Check the mailing list archives and see if there is anything in there that might help.
-- Scott Mattocks scott@crisscott.com http://www.crisscott.com http://pear.php.net/user/scottmattocks
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] #33472 [Opn->Bgs]: header redirection at the middle of PHP+HTML file
email.body:
ID: 33472 Updated by: edink@php.net Reported By: tarun27in at gmail dot com -Status: Open +Status: Bogus Bug Type: PHP-GTK related Operating System: Windows Xp PHP Version: 4.3.10 New Comment:
Thank you for taking the time to write to us, but this is not a bug. Please double-check the documentation available at http://www.php.net/manual/ and the instructions on how to report a bug at http://bugs.php.net/how-to-report.php
Previous Comments: ------------------------------------------------------------------------
[2005-07-05 13:07:08] timo dot schmid at gmail dot com
Hi again, I found about the response.redirect that it sends a HTML-Header with a <meta> tag. If you do this AFTER outputting any data (except headers) you will get a document that is NOT valid HTML/XHTML or whatever. Not beautyful. As I think, JS is the only Possibility to make it conform.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
[2005-07-05 12:24:18] tarun27in at gmail dot com
dude , i m already doin that way , but this is not a permanent solution in PHP , like the way u have in ASP response.redirect which does not give any header sent error there shud be something through which u can redirect even at the middle of the page withour caring for whats sent and whats not.
Anyways thanks for ur reply.
Cheers
------------------------------------------------------------------------
[2005-07-05 12:19:16] timo dot schmid at gmail dot com
This is not a Bug, this is becaus the Headers of your Page MUST been sent BEFORE you output any Text/Html. Use the following instead: <script type="text/javascript"> document.location = 'http://www.php.net'; </script>
------------------------------------------------------------------------
[2005-06-25 13:08:42] tarun27in at gmail dot com
Description: ------------ Though I m not a php guru but still i have been obsessed with a big with header location which often troubles me a lot , I often use html tags in php file as i use dreamweaver as html editor and whenever i want to redirect to some remote url in the middle of the page it always prompt me of a warning that headers already sent , i have researched a lot but didn't find any satisfactory solutions. Though i was able to redirect via javascript href tag but i think thats quite a bug as I also designed sites on ASP and response.redirect works anywhere in a file.
Just want to take in to your considerations.
thanks and regards TARUN SHARMA
------------------------------------------------------------------------
-- Edit this bug report at http://bugs.php.net/?id=33472&edit=1
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.body:
Yes.
-Andrei
On Jul 11, 2005, at 1:23 PM, Scott Mattocks wrote:
> Andrei Zmievski wrote: > >> We're not going to wrap gtk_signal_* funcs automatically. Besides, >> they are deprecated. But I've been adding relevant methods to GObject >> actually. > > I found this in the phpg_gobject.c file. Is this one of the relevant > methods? If so, can I just call it with > $widget->block($signalHandlerId)? > > static PHP_METHOD(GObject, block) > { > guint handler_id; > > NOT_STATIC_METHOD(); > > if (!php_gtk_parse_args(ZEND_NUM_ARGS(), "i", &handler_id)) { > return; > } > > g_signal_handler_block(PHPG_GOBJECT(this_ptr), handler_id); > } > > Thanks, > Scott > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Talk of dropping win98 and NT
email.body:
Guys 'n' gals,
There's talk on PHP internals of dropping support in PHP for win98 and NT. The justification is that there are useful APIs that could become part of PHP if we do so.
I used to support win98 in PHP for a while - Frank, I don't know how long it is since you did that too, I gave up last summer when I got XP and lost my 98 box.
There are no bug reports open against PHP 'proper' from those platforms, and on that basis I added to the general consensus on the internals list that we should drop support for these platforms.
It occurred to me, _after_ I'd expressed agreement there, that there may be subscribers to this list that actually do have users on win98 or NT; they're likely to be more common in offices than in web development houses - or are they?
If anyone here has a large user base running PHP-GTK on old Windows systems, it might be a good time to write to internals@ and make that point.
- Steph
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: Talk of dropping win98 and NT
email.body:
Hi Steph,
I have wanted to drop the support for these systems for a long while. I think PHP5 is a good place to do that. We still have PHP4 with a working PHP-GTK implementation.
I have nver used Windows 98 or 95 for that matter I switched from 3.11 directly to NT 3.5 and never looked back :-). I think that was close to 10 years ago.
- Frank
> Guys 'n' gals, > > There's talk on PHP internals of dropping support in PHP for win98 and NT. > The justification is that there are useful APIs that could become part of > PHP if we do so. > > I used to support win98 in PHP for a while - Frank, I don't know how long it > is since you did that too, I gave up last summer when I got XP and lost my > 98 box. > > There are no bug reports open against PHP 'proper' from those platforms, and > on that basis I added to the general consensus on the internals list that we > should drop support for these platforms. > > It occurred to me, _after_ I'd expressed agreement there, that there may be > subscribers to this list that actually do have users on win98 or NT; they're > likely to be more common in offices than in web development houses - or are > they? > > If anyone here has a large user base running PHP-GTK on old Windows systems, > it might be a good time to write to internals@ and make that point. > > - Steph > > > > > > > > >

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] July News
email.body: Last call! PHP-GTK 2 at the International PHP Conference Jeremy Johnstone will be presenting a talk titled "GUI Development in PHP-GTK2" at the International PHP Conference in November. Anyone going to the conference should be sure to check out his talk. The discussion includes "in depth coverage of developing a GUI application in PHP-GTK2 including tools you can use to allow you to rapidly develop new applications." Win9x Support in PHP 5.1 There is talk on the PHP Internals mailing list about removing support for Win9x (95/98/2000/ME) from PHP 5.1. For most PHP developers this isn't much of a big deal but for PHP-GTK 2 developers it may have a much more significant impact. If you have reasons to keep Win9x support in PHP 5, make sure to voice your opinion! Steph wrote: > Could you please link the 'voice your opinion' part to Wez' blog when you > add those links? > > Cheers, > - Steph > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Scott Mattocks" > To: "PHP-GTK Dev" > Sent: Wednesday, July 20, 2005 1:49 PM > Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] July News > > > >>Ok. Here is a first round (I'll add links later): >> >>PHP-GTK 2 at the International PHP Conference >>Jeremy Johnstone will be presenting a talk titled "GUI Development in >>PHP-GTK2" at the International PHP Conference in November. Anyone going >>to the conference should be sure to check out his talk. The discussion >>includes "in depth coverage of developing a GUI application in PHP-GTK2 >>including tools you can use to allow you to rapidly develop new >>applications." >> >>Win9x Support in PHP 5.1 >>There is talk on the PHP Internals mailing list about removing support >>for Win9x (95/98/2000/ME) from PHP 5.1. For most PHP developers this >>isn't much of a big deal but for PHP-GTK 2 developers it may a much more >>significant impact. If you have reasons to keep Win9x support in PHP, >>make sure to voice your opinion! >>http://marc.theaimsgroup.com/?l=php-dev&m=112142925911670&w=2 >> >>Send more news! >> >>Scott >> >>Steph wrote: >> >>>It's still at 'possibility' level. I'll keep my ear to the ground on > > that > >>>one and let y'all know when that changes. >>> >>>----- Original Message ----- >>>From: "Jeremy Johnstone" >>>To: "Scott Mattocks" >>>Cc: "PHP-GTK Dev" >>>Sent: Wednesday, July 20, 2005 6:16 AM >>>Subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] July News >>> >>> >>>Dunno if its news worthy or if it's strictly GTK related, but might >>>want to mention something about the discussion about the possibility >>>(is it still a possibility or is it fact already>) of PHP dropping >>>Win9x support in future versions soon. >>> >>>-Jeremy >>> >>>On 7/18/05, Scott Mattocks wrote: >>> >>> >>>>I added a note about a new release last week but does anyone have >>>>anything else news worthy for this month? email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Deeply nested properties
email.body:
If you run var_dump() on a realized widget right now, you will get a few thousand lines of the output, owing to the deeply nested structure of widgets and especially the multitude of properties that the GtkStyle object has. This is even without exposing GdkGC properties yet. So, I can provide two approaches:
a) expose everything and let those who use var_dump() haphazardly suffer. b) do not expose GtkStyle properties.
Option b) means that you will not see any properties on var_dump ($style), that get_object_vars($style) will return an empty array, and so on. You would still be able to access them normally, $style- >fg etc.
-Andrei
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Re: Arginfo
email.body:
I ran into another bug with arginfo stuff. All of a sudden, PHP started bailing out when GtkImage::set_from_pixbuf(null) was called, even though the argument is allowed to be a null. Turns out that the arginfo spec for this function requires the arg to be a GdkPixbuf. Can you figure out a way to fix this?
-Andrei
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.body:

also .... the current errors I am having ..
configure.in:8: /usr/bin/m4: Undefined macro `AC_PROG_EGREP'
.. would make sense to me if indeed configure.in had AC_PROG_EGREP at line 8 or indeed anywhere ?? but it does not , or am I looking in the wrong place ? please explain , AC_PROG_EGREP is defined in build/libtool.m4 though
[root@home build]# cat libtool.m4 | grep AC_PROG_EGREP # AC_PROG_EGREP ifdef([AC_PROG_EGREP], [], [AC_DEFUN([AC_PROG_EGREP], [AC_REQUIRE([AC_PROG_EGREP])dnl [AC_REQUIRE([AC_PROG_EGREP])dnl
so is my aclocal/autoconf/make just borked , or is build/libtool.m4 not getting `parsed `

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] June News
email.body:
On Jun 17, 2005, at 5:39 AM, Scott Mattocks wrote:
> Here are some parts that I have noticed. > > GtkObject::signal_handler* (or it may be GtkWidget I forget)
Implemented now in CVS as methods of GObject class.
> GtkContainer::children, get_children
Both implemented, although children() is deprecated and issues appropriate notice.
> There is a GtkContainer::get_child in the docs that shouldn't be > there. I don't know if that is a problem with docgen or the sources.
It's a method of GtkBin class.
> Several of the GtkTextBuffer methods require parameters of type > GObject.
Like what? I couldn't find any.
> > There are some conflicting messages if you try to add a window to > another window. Try the following code: > > <?php > $window1 = new GtkWindow(); > $window2 = new GtkWindow(); > $button = new GtkButton(); > > $window1->add($window2); > $window1->add($button); > ?> > > The first call to add will give you an appropirate message about > window being a top level widget and how it can't be added to > another widget. No problem there right? The second call to add > gives a message about how window is a bin and can't have two > children. That message shouldn't appear because the first add > should have failed. This is not so much a missing implementation > thing as it is a bug I think. > >
Nothing we can do about this. gtk_container_add() does not return any sort of status flag to let us know whether addition succeeded or failed.
-Andrei
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Signal handler methods
email.body:
We're not going to wrap gtk_signal_* funcs automatically. Besides, they are deprecated. But I've been adding relevant methods to GObject actually.
On Jun 3, 2005, at 5:21 PM, Markus Fischer wrote: > In ext/gtk+/gtk.overrides in the ignore-glob group is: > > gtk_signal_* > > which means that the complete family of gtk_signal_* is not generated > in any way. > > As of why: I'm not exactly sure, but the gtk signals page you gave > states "For future usage, direct use of the GSignal API is > recommended," and since we don't wrap the glib api that may be the > reason. > > - Markus > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

I got demotivated by the slowness of Gtk+ startup in Tiger and by the lack of any sort of progress on the docs. What's the point of writing PHP-GTK if it'll be just another undocumented project?
-Andrei

No > product releases? > > Scott Mattocks wrote: > > >> I know I am a little early but I may be away later this month. >> Please send me your PHP-GTK related news. >> Thanks, >> > > -- > Scott Mattocks > scott@crisscott.com > http://www.crisscott.com > http://pear.php.net/user/scottmattocks > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] June News
email.body:
A -
Okay, caveat. -- I'm only speaking for myself here. ---
And speaking for myself, I've got an entire senior management that is doing a tap dance on my tush waiting for PHP-Gtk2. Just the promise of it has been enough to reassure them that there is a future where we're going, not to mention some of the features it offers. If it were here yesterday, it wouldn't be soon enough.
As for the docs, speaking for myself only, I can always get what I need from the Gtk people, regardless of what is or is not on our site. I've had to do that in several cases, so I'm already used to it. I've also gotten a lot more from our discussion lists than from the docs, right from the beginning. I know that's no fun for the newcomer - I was there myself, but if it's that or no PHP-Gtk2, I think the latter is much worse.
Madeleine D.
At 03:30 PM 6/15/05 -0700, Andrei Zmievski wrote: >I got demotivated by the slowness of Gtk+ startup in Tiger and by the >lack of any sort of progress on the docs. What's the point of writing >PHP-GTK if it'll be just another undocumented project? > >-Andrei > > >On Jun 15, 2005, at 10:42 AM, Scott Mattocks wrote: > >> Has the last month really been that slow? No articles? No talks? No >> product releases? >> >> Scott Mattocks wrote: >> >> >>> I know I am a little early but I may be away later this month. >>> Please send me your PHP-GTK related news. >>> Thanks, >>> >> >> -- >> Scott Mattocks >> scott@crisscott.com >> http://www.crisscott.com >> http://pear.php.net/user/scottmattocks >> >> -- >> PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) >> To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >> > >-- >PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) >To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > >
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] June News
email.body:
On Jun 16, 2005, at 6:03 AM, Scott Mattocks wrote:
> I understand your frustration but I don't think the progress of the > docs should really have much of an impact. Speaking for myself, my > progress with the docs has slowed because of the progress with > development. I want to write about the basics of widgets and signals > but there is some stuff that just isn't there yet. I also tried moving > some of my apps to PHP-GTK 2 but ran into some trouble spots because > of things that aren't ready yet. It is frustrating to start working on > a class and then find out that you can't use half the functions. I > can't document features that aren't implemented because I don't fully > understand them. I don't like just copying blindly from Gtk+ because > all that does is give us two copies of the Gtk+ docs.
Scott,
If you are slowed down because certain fundamental classes are not fully implemented yet, by all means, raise it to my attention. You said that some basics of widgets and signals are missing: what are they? With such a large API it is hard for me to keep track of what is generated and what is not right now.
I'd also like to ask if there is anyone out there who wants to help out with actual C code development.
-Andrei
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] June News
email.body:
Ugh. I hate autoconf/automake/aclocal and the whole big mess of it. If someone has time and knowledge (or desire to acquire such knowledge) and dig into this and fix it, I'll buy him/her a case of beer.
I think Jani was telling us that these errors are due to us using aclocal. We could probably avoid that by copying all the external .m4 files into the respective extension directories.. so, that's one approach.

OK , > > .. removed all the build tools & now have the recommended > autoconf 2.13, automake 1.4 and libtool 1.4.3 , I searched for all > traces of aclocal since it seemed to be in several places and removed > them before compiling the above.. , aclocal --print-ac-dir seems to > give the correct output > > php5.1 CVS would not make for me , not evean an error as such .. > however a 5.1 snapshot did (using the above tools) > > On to php-gtk ( rm -rf *.cache ) I still get the below... which , to > be fair is different to what I am used to and a change is as good as a > rest ;) > > [root@home php-gtk]# aclocal > [root@home php-gtk]# ./buildconf > rebuilding aclocal.m4 > rebuilding configure > configure.in:8: /usr/bin/m4: Undefined macro `AC_PROG_EGREP' > autoconf: Undefined macros: > configure.in:23: AC_MSG_ERROR(Cannot find php-config. Please use > --with-php-config=PATH) > make[1]: *** [configure] Error 1 > make: *** [all] Error 2 > > > anyone on fedora/rh here that can give me any numbers that worked for > them ? > > Regards, > Simon > > > > Ivan Rodriguez wrote: > >> Simon you need PHP 5.1 to compile PHP-GTK2 >> >> When i do something with php-gtk all times i go to gnome devolper web >> or to the gnome devolper book, the PHP-GTK docs can´t based on the >> gnome docs?¿ what need to get the docs of PHP-GTK to add some examples >> and explanations of PHP-GTK2, I think that the best help to learn is >> with goog examples ... I can write some examples for many widgets ... >> but i don´t know when can i download the docs of php-gtk2 >> >> On 6/16/05, Simon Wheeler <simon@firepages.org> wrote: >> >>> Can`t build it , so can't play with it / understand it == can`t >>> document >>> it :) >>> >>> OK so giving up on debian (Xandros) for now (could not build on >>> Ubuntu >>> even following instructions here), I am reinstalling Fedora & >>> crossing >>> my fingers it builds. >>> >>> To parrot Madeleine ... >>> >>> `If it were here yesterday, it >>> wouldn't be soon enough.` >>> >>> ... too right , php-gtk is (IMO) a serious part of PHP's future , >>> all the .. >>> >>> whoot , while writing php-5.0.4 finally built (CVS would not build >>> for me) , so a deep breath and here I go :D >>> >>> >>> Regards, >>> Simon. >>> >>> >>> Andrei Zmievski wrote: >>> >>> >>>> I got demotivated by the slowness of Gtk+ startup in Tiger and by >>>> the >>>> lack of any sort of progress on the docs. What's the point of >>>> writing >>>> PHP-GTK if it'll be just another undocumented project? >>>> >>>> -Andrei >>>> >>>> >>> -- >>> PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) >>> To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >>> >>> >>> >> >> > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] June News
email.body:
Madeleine D. wrote: > A - > > Okay, caveat. -- I'm only speaking for myself here. --- > > And speaking for myself, I've got an entire senior management that is doing > a tap dance on my tush waiting for PHP-Gtk2. Just the promise of it has > been enough to reassure them that there is a future where we're going, not > to mention some of the features it offers. If it were here yesterday, it > wouldn't be soon enough. > > As for the docs, speaking for myself only, I can always get what I need > from the Gtk people, regardless of what is or is not on our site. I've had > to do that in several cases, so I'm already used to it. I've also gotten a > lot more from our discussion lists than from the docs, right from the > beginning. I know that's no fun for the newcomer - I was there myself, but > if it's that or no PHP-Gtk2, I think the latter is much worse.
Funny .. it's the same position as I am in, exactly. As for the docs: I can't write a single page without consulting the real GTK+ API documentation anyway. Because there I know the information is definitely there. Still there are some parts missing in certain areas, but this are tiny. While I tested the List/Tree, it was unavoidable. They've plenty of tutorials and such. Also I regulary consulted the C tutorials in the source distribution and sometimes even looked up the implementation itself. Yes, this is not what newcomers do, I know.
When I need to look into the php-gtk docs it's only for things written in the override files, because the usually differ to match the PHP language things.
Apart from that I'm in need of a windows binary. Linux is nice, but our production operators are running windows of course.
- Markus
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

OK so giving up on debian (Xandros) for now (could not build on Ubuntu even following instructions here), I am reinstalling Fedora & crossing my fingers it builds.
To parrot Madeleine ...
`If it were here yesterday, it wouldn't be soon enough.`
... too right , php-gtk is (IMO) a serious part of PHP's future , all the ..
whoot , while writing php-5.0.4 finally built (CVS would not build for me) , so a \ deep breath and here I go :D
Regards, Simon.

> I got demotivated by the slowness of Gtk+ startup in Tiger and by the > lack of any sort of progress on the docs. What's the point of writing > PHP-GTK if it'll be just another undocumented project? > > -Andrei >

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Naming of exceptions
email.body:
Hi,
while reading Andreis php_gtk2.pdf I saw that exceptions are named 'PhpGtk'. Since everything else in php-gtk is named just 'Gtk' I was wondering why exceptions are an exception here?
- Markus

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Some constants
email.body:
Hello
I'm trying to use the constants GTK_CELL_RENDERER_MODE_* for GtkCellRenderers and I can't, I try with Gtk::CELL_RENDERER_MODE_EDITABLE and PHP says Undefined class constant, I use the method set_property('mode', Gtk::CELL_RENDERER_MODE_EDITABLE) but don't works :-( there other names for GtkCellRenderers modes?¿
Any idea?¿
regards

Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Some constants
email.body:
Hello Ivan,
> I'm trying to use the constants GTK_CELL_RENDERER_MODE_* for > GtkCellRenderers and I can't, I try with > Gtk::CELL_RENDERER_MODE_EDITABLE and PHP says Undefined class > constant, I use the method set_property('mode', > Gtk::CELL_RENDERER_MODE_EDITABLE) but don't works :-( there other > names for GtkCellRenderers modes?¿
Attached is a *very* simple "Reflection browser", which runs under php5 and gtk2. Select the "Constants" tab, then search the Gtk class in the list, click on it - you will see all defined constants for that one.
Regards/MfG, Christian Weiske -- XMMS is playing now: Sarah Connor - Sweet Thang
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Some constants
email.body:
Ivan Rodriguez wrote: > I'm trying to use the constants GTK_CELL_RENDERER_MODE_* for > GtkCellRenderers and I can't, I try with > Gtk::CELL_RENDERER_MODE_EDITABLE and PHP says Undefined class > constant, I use the method set_property('mode', > Gtk::CELL_RENDERER_MODE_EDITABLE) but don't works :-( there other > names for GtkCellRenderers modes?
For now you can also use the set_property("editable", true) method of e.g. GtkCellRendererText.
HTH, - Markus

email.body:
This works for me:
var_dump(Gtk::CELL_RENDERER_MODE_EDITABLE);
Can you check your ext/gtk+/gen_gtk.c file and see whether it has this line in it:
phpg_register_enum(GTK_TYPE_CELL_RENDERER_MODE, strip_prefix, gtk_ce);
-Andrei

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Naming of exceptions
email.body:
Because Gtk+ does not have exceptions. They are a PHP feature.
-Andrei
On May 6, 2005, at 4:05 AM, Markus Fischer wrote:
> Hi, > > while reading Andreis php_gtk2.pdf I saw that exceptions are named > 'PhpGtk'. Since everything else in php-gtk is named just 'Gtk' I was > wondering why exceptions are an exception here? > > - Markus > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Naming of exceptions
email.body:
Hi,
makes sense, thanks.
Another thing: what do you think about adding a base exception class, e.g. "PhpGtkException", where all other exception classes are based on so there's a "all catch" exception for php-gtk?
- Markus

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] June News
email.body:
Andrei Zmievski wrote:
> I got demotivated by the slowness of Gtk+ startup in Tiger and by the > lack of any sort of progress on the docs. What's the point of writing > PHP-GTK if it'll be just another undocumented project?
Andrei,
I understand your frustration but I don't think the progress of the docs should really have much of an impact. Speaking for myself, my progress with the docs has slowed because of the progress with development. I want to write about the basics of widgets and signals but there is some stuff that just isn't there yet. I also tried moving some of my apps to PHP-GTK 2 but ran into some trouble spots because of things that aren't ready yet. It is frustrating to start working on a class and then find out that you can't use half the functions. I can't document features that aren't implemented because I don't fully understand them. I don't like just copying blindly from Gtk+ because all that does is give us two copies of the Gtk+ docs.
Thanks, Scott
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

[root@home php-gtk]# sh -x /usr/local/bin/phpize + prefix=/usr/local ++ eval echo /usr/local +++ echo /usr/local + exec_prefix=/usr/local ++ eval echo /usr/local/lib/php +++ echo /usr/local/lib/php + scan_makefile_in.awk shtool libtool.m4' + FILES='acinclude.m4 Makefile.global config.sub config.guess ltmain.sh' + CLEAN_FILES='acinclude.m4 Makefile.global config.sub config.guess ltmain.sh *.o *.lo *.la .deps .libs/ build/ include/ modules/ install-sh mkinstalldirs missing config.nice config.sub conf ig.guess configure configure.in aclocal.m4 config.h config.h.in conftest* ltmain.sh libto ol config.cache autom4te.cache/ config.log config.status Makefile Makefile.fragments Make file.objects confdefs.h' + case "$1" in + phpize_check_configm4 0 + test '!' -r config.m4 + phpize_check_build_files + test '!' -d /usr/local/lib/php/build + phpize_print_api_numbers + phpize_get_api_numbers ++ grep '#define PHP_API_VERSION' /usr/local/include/php/main/php.h ++ sed 's/#define PHP_API_VERSION//' -bash: shx.txt: command not found + PHP_API_VERSION=' 20041225' ++ grep '#define ZEND_MODULE_API_NO' /usr/local/include/php/Zend/zend_modules.h ++ sed 's/#define ZEND_MODULE_API_NO//' + ZEND_MODULE_API_NO=' 20041031' ++ grep '#define ZEND_EXTENSION_API_NO' /usr/local/include/php/Zend/zend_extensions.h ++ sed 's/#define ZEND_EXTENSION_API_NO//' + ZEND_EXTENSION_API_NO=' 220050610' + echo 'Configuring for:' Configuring for: + echo 'PHP Api Version: ' 20041225 PHP Api Version: 20041225 + echo 'Zend Module Api No: ' 20041031 Zend Module Api No: email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] June News
email.body:
On Wed, 15 Jun 2005, Andrei Zmievski wrote:
> Ugh. I hate autoconf/automake/aclocal and the whole big mess of it. If someone > has time and knowledge (or desire to acquire such knowledge) and dig into this > and fix it, I'll buy him/her a case of beer. > > I think Jani was telling us that these errors are due to us using aclocal. We > could probably avoid that by copying all the external .m4 files into the > respective extension directories.. so, that's one approach.
Yes, that'd help. :)
But this error: configure.in:8: /usr/bin/m4: Undefined macro C_PROG_EGREP' is likely have been just caused by not having up-to-date PHP install (HEAD). As that macro comes from the libtool.m4 that is bundled in HEAD.
--Jani

You said > that some basics of widgets and signals are missing: what are they? > With such a large API it is hard for me to keep track of what is > generated and what is not right now. > > I'd also like to ask if there is anyone out there who wants to help out > with actual C code development. > > -Andrei > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php >

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] June News
email.body:
Andrei Zmievski wrote:
> If you are slowed down because certain fundamental classes are not fully > implemented yet, by all means, raise it to my attention. You said that > some basics of widgets and signals are missing: what are they? With such > a large API it is hard for me to keep track of what is generated and > what is not right now.
Here are some parts that I have noticed.
GtkObject::signal_handler* (or it may be GtkWidget I forget) GtkContainer::children, get_children There is a GtkContainer::get_child in the docs that shouldn't be there. I don't know if that is a problem with docgen or the sources. Several of the GtkTextBuffer methods require parameters of type GObject.
There are some conflicting messages if you try to add a window to another window. Try the following code:
<?php $window1 = new GtkWindow(); $window2 = new GtkWindow(); $button = new GtkButton();
$window1->add($window2); $window1->add($button); ?>
The first call to add will give you an appropirate message about window being a top level widget and how it can't be added to another widget. No problem there right? The second call to add gives a message about how window is a bin and can't have two children. That message shouldn't appear because the first add should have failed. This is not so much a missing implementation thing as it is a bug I think.
Thanks, Scott
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GDK set_cursor
email.body:
Hi,
I'm trying to set a custom cursor on a window, the operation should be the following in C:
cursor = gdk_cursor_new (GDK_WATCH); gdk_window_set_cursor (GTK_WIDGET (mainwindow)->window, cursor); gdk_cursor_unref (cursor);
I can create a new cursor with
$c = new GdkCursor(Gdk::WATCH);
but I can't find a way to call gdk_window_set_cursor correctly.
It's defined as GdkWindow::set_cursor but refers to 'this_ptr' in the source, when there's no object context to call it from; calling it statically fails:
gdk_window_set_cursor(GDK_WINDOW(PHPG_OBJECT(this_ptr)), cursor);
any ideas?
- Markus
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] php-gtk2 on ubuntu
email.body:
My little how-to on how to install php-gtk2 on ubuntu linux 5.04 (horay) it's very easy :)
-- :: Pablo Dall'Oglio + 55 (51) 3714-6653 :: www.solis.coop.br - Lajeado, RS - Brasil :: www.varianet.com.br - Personal Home Page :: The software is free, but the work isn't.
["compile.txt" (compile.txt)]
# apt-get remove automake1.4 # apt-get remove autoconf2.13 # apt-get install gawk # apt-get install autoconf // 2.59 by default # apt-get install automake1.8 # apt-get install libglib2.0 # apt-get install libglib2.0-dev # apt-get install libgtk2.0 # apt-get install libgtk2.0-dev
=> PHP5 # ./configure --prefix=/usr/local/php5 --enable-cli --disable-cgi # make # make install # cp php.ini-dist /usr/local/php5/lib/php.ini # echo extension=php_gtk2.so >> /usr/local/php5/lib/php.ini # /usr/local/php5/bin/php-config --extension-dir |xargs echo \ 'extension_dir='>>/usr/local/php5/lib/php.ini
=>PHP-GTK2 # ./buildconf --with-phpize=/usr/local/php5/bin/phpize \ --with-php-config=/usr/local/php5/bin/php-config
# './configure' \ '--prefix=/usr/local/php5' \ '--exec-prefix=/usr/local/php5' \ '--with-php-config=/usr/local/php5/bin/php-config' \ '--disable-scrollpane' \ '--disable-spaned' \ '--disable-sqpane' \ '--disable-combobutton' \ '--disable-libglade' \ '--disable-piemenu' \
# make # make install
# php5 -m [PHP Modules] ctype dom iconv libxml pcre PDO pdo_sqlite php-gtk (here) !!!! posix session SimpleXML SPL SQLite standard tokenizer xml

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] C API vs PHP API, e.g. gtk_tree_selection_get_selection
email.body:
Hi,
I'm not really happy with the way the API calls change from C to PHP in some places, for example in gtk_tree_selection_get_selection.
What is pretty clean in C looks quirky in PHP. I'm no real solution, just want to start discussions on what others think.
In C, the function would work like:
boolean_result = gtk_tree_selection_get_selected(tree, model, iter);
if boolean_result is true, model and iter will be initialized
if boolean_result if false, model is initialized, the iter isn't
now in PHP we will always get a return value, an array, and have to look into the array to decide if all has gone well or not:
always_array = $tree->get_selection()->get_selected();
and then we have to check whether always_array[1] is NULL or not, always_array[0] is always the model.
The model is optional in the C function, it's only provided for convinienve. I can't think of a case where you cannot access the model but only have the selection (at least if you develop carefully).
What do you think about the proposel to return the iter or false?
if (iter = $tree->get_selection()->get_selected()) { // do something clever }
vs.
array = $tree->get_selection()->get_selected()) { if (!is_null(array[1])) { // do something clever }
The model would be available with $tree->get_model() if there would be no existing reference already.
cheers, - Markus
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Help with the wiki
email.body:
Hello,
It seems that a very dedicated wiki spammer has gotten to our site. If you have time can you please help to clean it up? The spammer added a section that says ==See also== 1 2 3 ...
To the bottom of EVERY page. I have cleaned up everything except for the PMWiki section. Some of the pages I had to do twice because he came back! Anyway, cleaning it up is easy just tedious.
1) Click all recent chagnes 2) Click on a change from today or yesterday that doesn't have my name next to it 3) Go to the bottom of the page 4) Hit page history 5) Find a good restore point and click on the restore link 6) Double check that there is not spam in the textarea 7) Add your name as the author (if you don't it will be hard to tell what has been cleaned and what is spam) 8) Hit save
Thanks in advance, Scott
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.body:
This is the simplest fix... - change the HTML on the form:
<form real:post="http://gtk.php.net/wiki/Main/HomePage" action="file:/dev/null" onsubmit="this.action=this.getAttribute('real:post'); \ this.chk.value=this.text.value; return true;" method="post" > <input type='hidden' name='chk' value='' />
then add if (!isset($_POST['chk']) || ($_POST['chk'] != $_POST['text'])) { echo "please enable javascript"; exit; }
It should remove 99% of the wiki spam.. Regards Alan
On Wed, 2005-05-25 at 12:23 -0400, Scott Mattocks wrote: > Hello, > > It seems that a very dedicated wiki spammer has gotten to our site. If > you have time can you please help to clean it up? The spammer added a > section that says > ==See also== > 1 2 3 ... > > To the bottom of EVERY page. I have cleaned up everything except for the > PMWiki section. Some of the pages I had to do twice because he came > back! Anyway, cleaning it up is easy just tedious. > > 1) Click all recent chagnes > 2) Click on a change from today or yesterday that doesn't have my name > next to it > 3) Go to the bottom of the page > 4) Hit page history > 5) Find a good restore point and click on the restore link > 6) Double check that there is not spam in the textarea > 7) Add your name as the author (if you don't it will be hard to tell > what has been cleaned and what is spam) > 8) Hit save > > Thanks in advance, > Scott >
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] C API vs PHP API, e.g. gtk_tree_selection_get_selection
email.body:
On May 23, 2005, at 2:51 PM, Markus Fischer wrote:
> Hi, > > I'm not really happy with the way the API calls change from C to > PHP in some places, for example in gtk_tree_selection_get_selection. > > What is pretty clean in C looks quirky in PHP. I'm no real > solution, just want to start discussions on what others think. > > In C, the function would work like: > > boolean_result = gtk_tree_selection_get_selected(tree, model, iter); > > if boolean_result is true, model and iter will be initialized > > if boolean_result if false, model is initialized, the iter isn't > > now in PHP we will always get a return value, an array, and have to > look into the array to decide if all has gone well or not: > > always_array = $tree->get_selection()->get_selected(); > > and then we have to check whether always_array[1] is NULL or not, > always_array[0] is always the model. > > The model is optional in the C function, it's only provided for > convinienve. I can't think of a case where you cannot access the > model but only have the selection (at least if you develop carefully).
Some people don't develop carefully, I guess.
> > What do you think about the proposel to return the iter or false? > > if (iter = $tree->get_selection()->get_selected()) { > // do something clever > } > > vs. > > array = $tree->get_selection()->get_selected()) { > if (!is_null(array[1])) { > // do something clever > } > > The model would be available with $tree->get_model() if there would > be no existing reference already.
I modeled the PHP API mainly on PyGTK. If there is a better way to do something, I am open to changes, if there is a consensus about it.
-Andrei
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] C API vs PHP API, e.g. gtk_tree_selection_get_selection
email.body:
Andrei Zmievski wrote: > I modeled the PHP API mainly on PyGTK. If there is a better way to do > something, I am open to changes, if there is a consensus about it.
It's always hard to get an API right. I mean companies spend years to do it right.
On second thought, I'm not so sure if an API change would be good anyway. The following is sexy enough
list($oModel, $oIter) = $tree->get_selection()->get_selected(); if ($oIter) { }
and will probably do it. For any sane interaction for the iter the model is required anyway.
- Markus
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] C API vs PHP API, e.g. gtk_tree_selection_get_selection
email.body:
Markus Fischer wrote:
> list($oModel, $oIter) = $tree->get_selection()->get_selected(); > if ($oIter) { > }
I would like to preface this with "I have no idea what I am talking about." That being said, what about an exception? If you are really trying to get the iter and it isn't initialized, I would think not having th iter would be an exception case. Therefore, I would expect to catch an exception. But I have never used this method/function in C or PHP so I may not understand the context properly.
Scott

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] buildconf on debian any workarounds?
email.body:
Hi,
yes its really tricky on debian. I'm fighting it every time I install it new and try not to modify my environment once it works.
However one thing for me was pretty sure that I need automake 1.9 (currently 1.9.5). autoconf is 2.59, libtool is 1.4.3, flex is 2.5.4 (flex-old package).
HTH
Simon Wheeler wrote: > Hi , > I am having problems with buildconf on debian, I see the error probably > relates to versions of autoconf,automake & libtool though I have to use > autoconf >=2.5 for other (xandros) dependecies. > automake & libtool are `correct` versions 1.4 && 1.4.3. > > [Last time I tried I had no such issues on Fedora & it compiled out of > the box] > > >> > configure.in:65: error: possibly undefined macro: AC_PROG_LIBTOOL > If this token and others are legitimate, please use m4_pattern_allow. > See the Autoconf documentation. > > Any workarounds or ideas for a non-hardcore linux user? > > Regards, > Simon. >
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] buildconf on debian any workarounds?
email.body:
Hi , tricky indeed :D
I made sure I had the same versions as yourself with the same results. Then after seeing on a google a ref to `aclocal --print-ac-dir` noticed that the ac dir was in fact wrong (had to symlink /usr/local/share/aclocal to /usr/share/aclocal)
That solved my original issue with AC_PROG_LIBTOOL , but now I get stuck at AC_MSG_ERROR....
I also tried Andrei's advice in another thread ... >> XANFIRE:/root_old/php-gtk/php-gtk# sh -x /root_old/php-5.0.3/scripts/phpize which does call aclocal but I still get configure.in:22: error: possibly undefined macro: AC_MSG_ERROR ...etc
The thing that PUZZLES me most is why when I ./buildconf --force for PHP-5.0.3 itself I get no such errors ??? & AC_MSG_ERROR must be defined somewhere as it gets called if I deliberately break ./configure
So if it works for PHP5 itself surely it can't be my automake/autoconf/libtool versions that are the issue ? if that makes sense where would I start looking to fix ? I have done a fair bit of googling but obviously I am out of my depth at this level... a starter for 10 would be the answer to where AC_MSG_ERROR is defined or is it internal to aclocal or whatever , or why does it work for PHP5 itself ?
Regards, Simon.
Markus Fischer wrote:
> Hi, > > yes its really tricky on debian. I'm fighting it every time I install > it new and try not to modify my environment once it works. > > However one thing for me was pretty sure that I need automake 1.9 > (currently 1.9.5). autoconf is 2.59, libtool is 1.4.3, flex is 2.5.4 > (flex-old package). > > HTH > > Simon Wheeler wrote: > >> Hi , >> I am having problems with buildconf on debian, I see the error >> probably relates to versions of autoconf,automake & libtool though I >> have to use autoconf >=2.5 for other (xandros) dependecies. >> automake & libtool are `correct` versions 1.4 && 1.4.3. >> >> [Last time I tried I had no such issues on Fedora & it compiled out >> of the box] >> >> >> >> configure.in:65: error: possibly undefined macro: AC_PROG_LIBTOOL >> If this token and others are legitimate, please use >> m4_pattern_allow. >> See the Autoconf documentation. >> >> Any workarounds or ideas for a non-hardcore linux user? >> >> Regards, >> Simon. >> >

Why is there no object context? I don't see anything wrong with that function. this_ptr should be filled in by the time set_cursor() is called.
-Andrei

> I can create a new cursor with > > $c = new GdkCursor(Gdk::WATCH); > > but I can't find a way to call gdk_window_set_cursor correctly. > > It's defined as GdkWindow::set_cursor but refers to 'this_ptr' in the > source, when there's no object context to call it from; calling it > statically fails: > > gdk_window_set_cursor(GDK_WINDOW(PHPG_OBJECT(this_ptr)), cursor);

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GDK set_cursor
email.body:
Hi,
I wonder what I'm missing here ...
I'm calling set_cursor of GdkWindow ... not GtkWindow. GtkWindow has no set_cursor.
I cannot create a new 'GdkWindow' with 'new GdkWindow': Fatal Error: Class GdkWindow cannot be instantiated directly.
I guess I don't know how I can access the GdkWindow of a GtkWindow?
With some testing I found out that I can get the GdkWindow of a GtkTreeView by calling get_bin_window():
$tree = new GtkTreeView($someModel); $tree->get_bin_window()->set_cursor(new GdkCursor(Gdk::WATCH));
However this looks too specific to me. I thought there was a generalized way to retrieve the GdkWindow of any GtkWindow like it is done in the C source.
- Markus
Andrei Zmievski wrote: > Why is there no object context? I don't see anything wrong with that > function. this_ptr should be filled in by the time set_cursor() is called. > > -Andrei > > On May 19, 2005, at 3:13 AM, Markus Fischer wrote: > >> I can create a new cursor with >> >> $c = new GdkCursor(Gdk::WATCH); >> >> but I can't find a way to call gdk_window_set_cursor correctly. >> >> It's defined as GdkWindow::set_cursor but refers to 'this_ptr' in the >> source, when there's no object context to call it from; calling it >> statically fails: >> >> gdk_window_set_cursor(GDK_WINDOW(PHPG_OBJECT(this_ptr)), cursor); > > >

email.body: GtkLabel() constructor is not supposed to accept marked-up text. If you want markup, you need to do one of the following: 1) $label = new GtkLabel(); $label->set_markup('string'); 2) $label = new GtkLabel(); $label->set_property('use_markup', true); -Andrei On May 14, 2005, at 6:17 AM, Ivan Rodriguez wrote: > Hello, why when I do: > > $label = new GtkLabel("Label string"); > > supposedly the string would have to be in bold style, but don work ... > don't "parse" the tags, in the firsts release of php-gtk2 this work > perfectly .. somebody has the same problem?¿ other question ... > Christian phpgtk2-demo.php file of demos has the sourcecode with tags > too and don't work for me ... somebdy view the sourcecode colored?¿ > > Regards > > -- > PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) > To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php > -- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

Getting Ready for PHP-GTK 2
PHP-GTK 2 is getting closer and closer to a first release every day. Recently Andrei and Markus Fischer have made excellent progress with trees and editable cells. email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] May News

Version 3:
Getting Ready for PHP-GTK 2
PHP-GTK 2 is getting closer and closer to a first release every day. At the International PHP Conference, Andrei gave a talk about the current status of PHP-GTK 2 and the direction it is heading. Since then, excellent progress has been made with trees and editable cells. Parameter reflection has also been added thanks to Christian. The lastest efforts have lead to the first set of practical applications written with PHP-GTK 2. Christian's reflection browser makes it easy to take a look at the inner workings of PHP-GTK 2 classes and can be used as simple documenation.
Thanks for the help so far. Please keep it coming.
Scott
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] May News
email.body:
On May 16, 2005, at 11:38 PM, Christian Weiske wrote:
> PHP-Gtk has parameter reflection now, so the reflection browser makes > more sense now and could be used as a simple documentation.
Christian,
As far as I remember, we discussed putting parameter reflection info into the generated files, but did not agree on whether this would be done or not. I understand you are enthusiastic about this feature, but it is something that I would have liked to review before having it added to the code. The way you had gone and committed the implementation before the discussion has been finalized shows that you do not understand how open source approach to software development works. One of the main tenets is consensus - without it we may as well have anarchy and opportunistic forking all over the place.
I will review the commit and get back to you. For the record, I still think that this is still a very superficial feature, useful for only a small number of people and brings with it increased memory footprint and such.
-Andrei
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] May News
email.body:
Andrei,
> I will review the commit and get back to you. For the record, I still > think that this is still a very superficial feature, useful for only a > small number of people and brings with it increased memory footprint and > such.
Parameter reflection is disabled by default and doesn't affect anything in this case.
You have to do a "define ENABLE_REFLECTION 1" in config.h to enable it - without, it is as before, so nothing has changed.
Regards/MfG, Christian Weiske -- XMMS is playing now:
["signature.asc" (application/pgp-signature)]

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] May News
email.body:
On May 17, 2005, at 1:22 PM, Christian Weiske wrote: > > Parameter reflection is disabled by default and doesn't affect anything > in this case. > > You have to do a "define ENABLE_REFLECTION 1" in config.h to enable it > - > without, it is as before, so nothing has changed.
We are not going to do selective compilation in this case and offload the task of understand what this is all about onto the user who is compiling the extension. Either we go for this feature or not. So the first thing to fix would be to remove the ENABLE_REFLECTION check and always put in the arg info.
Secondly, what exactly is reflection_class_checker.php for? I could not understand the purpose from your comments.
By the way, since you like this feature so much, it'll be up to you to make sure that all the methods and functions and whatever have the arg info. I don't have time to put this stuff in every time I create an overridden method.
-Andrei
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

> Andrei, > > Before you tell me: I know that constructors and static functions like > the ones of Gtk:: aren't reflected by now, but I haven't had the time > to > fix it. > > Regards/MfG, > Christian Weiske > -- > XMMS is playing now: >
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] May News
email.body:
Andrei,
> We are not going to do selective compilation in this case and offload > the task of understand what this is all about onto the user who is > compiling the extension. Either we go for this feature or not. So the > first thing to fix would be to remove the ENABLE_REFLECTION check and > always put in the arg info. I did that for *you*, because you were nervous about the performance/compile time/whaterver impact on php-gtk2. Second reason for it was that if something goes wrong with the reflection generation, you still had the chance to compile it by just disabling it. I'll remove it.
> Secondly, what exactly is reflection_class_checker.php for? I could not > understand the purpose from your comments. If you reflect a non-existing class (be it in a function parameter), PHP behaves *very* strange: Reflection browser draws all the lines in the lists to the last selected class, you can't close the application, nothing works any more. So this script checks if the generated files contain such non-existing classes (like the enum ones) and spits them out, as they have to be entered in generator.php to be replaced typeless arg_info.
> By the way, since you like this feature so much, it'll be up to you to > make sure that all the methods and functions and whatever have the arg > info. I don't have time to put this stuff in every time I create an > overridden method. I'll be your slave and run after everything you do.
Regards/MfG, Christian Weiske -- XMMS is playing now: Sportfreunde Stiller - Siehst Du Das Genauso?
["signature.asc" (application/pgp-signature)]

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] May News
email.body:
How can you reflect a non-existing class? By the time generator runs, all the Gtk+ types should be mapped to PHP-GTK types. When would you run this script, really?
-Andrei
On May 18, 2005, at 3:15 AM, Christian Weiske wrote:
> If you reflect a non-existing class (be it in a function parameter), > PHP > behaves *very* strange: Reflection browser draws all the lines in the > lists to the last selected class, you can't close the application, > nothing works any more. > So this script checks if the generated files contain such non-existing > classes (like the enum ones) and spits them out, as they have to be > entered in generator.php to be replaced typeless arg_info.
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] May News
email.body:
Hello Andrei,
> How can you reflect a non-existing class? By the time generator runs, > all the Gtk+ types should be mapped to PHP-GTK types. That is right. But if there is one enum which isn't mapped, it there will be the type hint ZEND_ARG_OBJ_INFO(0, myParameter, SomeEnumClass, 0) in the generated files. If you reflect the function now, try to get the parameters and their type (in our case the non-existant SomeEnumClass), you try to reflect an undefined class.
> When would you run > this script, really? After the generator has been run and php-gtk has been installed. It tries to find all the classes used as type in ZEND_ARG_OBJ_INFO, and match them with the classes defined in the running php (so with the get_declared_classes array). That's IMO the only way to find out if there is an enum type which hasn't been mapped.
Regards/MfG, Christian Weiske -- XMMS is playing now: Reamonn - Everytime She Goes Away
["signature.asc" (application/pgp-signature)]

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Some missing things

Again me,
If found the problem to the missing constructor docs:
Have a look at gtk.defs#4943 ================= (define-function gtk_dialog_new (is-constructor-of "GtkDialog") (c-name "gtk_dialog_new") (caller-owns-return #t) (return-type "GtkWidget*") )
(define-function gtk_dialog_new_with_buttons (is-constructor-of "GtkDialog") (c-name "gtk_dialog_new_with_buttons") (caller-owns-return #t) (return-type "GtkWidget*") (parameters '("const-gchar*" "title" (default "NULL") (null-ok)) '("GtkWindow*" "parent" (default "NULL") (null-ok)) '("GtkDialogFlags" "flags") '("const-gchar*" "first_button_text" (default "NULL") (null-ok)) ) (varargs #t) ) ==================
docgen uses the first one as constructor, so there are no parameters generated.
Now php-gtk seems to take the second one as constructor, and has parameters.
How can I distinguish between "normal" constructors and such overridden ones?
Regards/MfG, Christian Weiske -- XMMS is playing now: Silbermond - Letzte Bahn

Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] second patch and question to DOC team
email.body:
Hallo Markus,
> Can not yet documented classes/functions be autogenerated a dummy doc > entry so at least we have a page, even if it's empty? I don't remember > exactly but I found the on or other function not documented. Is the > documentation based on an older gtk version?
No, the new docs (which you get when checking out php-gtk-doc) are based on the php-gtk2 sources. A script called docgen uses the .defs files to generate them. Some methods in the .defs are not available in php-gtk2, and some which are available are not in the .defs... So there are indeed some problems, but most functions should be covered.
Regards/MfG, Christian Weiske -- XMMS is playing now: Sarah Connor - Sweet Thang

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] second patch and question to DOC team
email.body:
Ivan Rodriguez wrote: > Hi Markus > > I try to run your code, but crash in the line of: > > $store = new GtkTreeStore(Gtk::TYPE_STRING, Gtk::TYPE_STRING); > > it can´t declare directly, I have the last version of PHP-GTK from CVS > . You know so that this happens this??
Whenever something crashed -> please provide backtraces. For small errors it doesn't have to be a debug build.
Small backtrace guide: - Make sure 'gdb' is installed - start gdb with php-cli as it's argument, e.g. 'gdb /path/co/php-cli-executeable' - on the new prompt, enter 'r PhpGtkReflector.php' the 'r' stands for 'run' and the second one is the argument passed to the executeable - once it crashes, type in 'bt' for backtrace and e-mail the output to the list. PREFERABLE as *.txt attachment, note copy&paste in the email, as long lines usually get nasty broken all over and make things hard to read. - you can leave gdb with 'quit' ;)
Long guide: http://bugs.php.net/bugs-generating-backtrace.php
- Markus
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

You can find my simple reflection browser at http://xml.cweiske.de/phpgtk2/inspector/
