email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GtkButton and use_underline - wrong default?
email.body:
Steph Fox escreveu: > Yes, I made it that way because it's more convenient for people using > mnemonics.
Grrr, but less convenient for people not using them... Furthermore, people using Gtk+ guides (or that are used to Gtk+) will have a surprise when trying to use underscores... Shouldn't we stick to the generally-accepted-and-everyone's-(but-Steph)-standard Gtk+ references? :)
Just my two cents, feel free to ignore.
-Jp
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] GtkButton and use_underline - wrong default?
email.body:
Jp, Steph,
> Furthermore, people using Gtk+ guides (or that are used to Gtk+) will > have a surprise when trying to use underscores... Shouldn't we stick to > the generally-accepted-and-everyone's-(but-Steph)-standard Gtk+ > references? :)
I vote for Steph's variant, as using accelerators on buttons is very common. We have our own manual to tell people how functions work, and how parameters have to be used. So I think it's right to make things better if we have a reason for it.
-- Regards/MfG, Christian Weiske
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

Very well, point taken. We should update our manual then :P
From the PHP-GTK 2 manual: > The default values for label is null and use_underline defaults to > FALSE.

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Constructor Curiousity
email.body:
Hi!
I just want to double-check with some of you if I am going off-track, because I get some unexpected constructor behaviour (maybe the behaviour was intended?) for certain objects.
Here is an example:
This works fine: $tb = GtkToolButton::new_from_stock(Gtk::STOCK_CUT);
Here comes the part that confuses me a little bit...
This works fine: $imi = new GtkImageMenuItem('Some _Label');
But this also works fine (why does it work?): $imi = new GtkImageMenuItem(Gtk::STOCK_CUT);
This, however, does not work: $imi = GtkImageMenuItem::new_with_label('Some _Label'); // Fatal error: Call to undefined method GtkImageMenuItem::new_with_label()
This also does not work: $imi = GtkImageMenuItem::new_from_stock(Gtk::STOCK_CUT, null); // Fatal error: Call to undefined method GtkImageMenuItem::new_from_stock()
I would just like a bit of insight (mainly out of curiousity), since I am unsure whether, e.g. a) The "new_from_stock" constructor has not been implemented yet. If it hasn't been implemented yet, it's not a big deal, I am just wondering about it, because of (b) below :-) b) Why does "new GtkImageMenuItem(Gtk::STOCK_CUT);" work, and what constructor is exactly called to make it work?
Thank you for your time and effort!
P.S: It's very late and I am very tired, maybe I'm just missing something obvious...
Kind regards, Werner
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Type to store anything in a GtkTreeStore/GtkListStore
email.body:
Should be fixed in CVS.
-Andrei
On Nov 21, 2005, at 3:04 PM, Christian Weiske wrote:
> Andrei, > > >> Gtk::TYPE_PHP_VALUE is supposed to be able to store anything. What >> sort >> of problems do you run into with it? >> > Just execute the following: > <?php > $store = new GtkListStore(Gtk::TYPE_PHP_VALUE); > > //Problem 1: simple data types > $integer = 0; > $store->append(array($integer)); > > //Problem 2: Widgets > $window = new GtkWindow(); > $store->append(array($window)); > > ?> > > Output: > ======================= > PHP Warning: Cannot set row: type of element 0 does not match the > model > in /data/php-gtk/two/problems/gtktreestore.phpw on line 6 > PHP Warning: Cannot set row: type of element 0 does not match the > model > in /data/php-gtk/two/problems/gtktreestore.phpw on line 10 > ======================= > > That damn thing bloated up my Gtk_VarDump2 code.... > > -- > Regards/MfG, > Christian Weiske >

email.subject: [PHP-GTK-DEV] PHP 5.1.1 problems
email.body:
Hi all, specifically Andrei,
I updated to php 5.1.1 today re-compiled php-gtk2, installed it and php5 told me it couldn't load the extension because of an undefined symbol atom_ce or so. So I removed the php-gtk directory completely, did a fresh checkout and installed it.
PHP tells me now ====================== php-gtk GTK+ support => enabled GTK+ v => 2.6.10 ====================== but crashes when I try to run some php-gtk2 scripts. First, scribble: --------------------- /usr/bin/p5: line 2: 26476 Segmentation fault /data/cvs/php/php5install/bin/php -c /data/cvs/php/php5install/bin/ $* --------------------- and my own Dev_Inspector fails, too (while it worked with 5.1.0-dev): --------------------- usr/bin/p5: line 2: 26517 Segmentation fault /data/cvs/php/php5install/bin/php -c /data/cvs/php/php5install/bin/ $* --------------------- What I noted: As soon as I comment out > $this->notebook->connect_after('switch-page', array($this, > 'onSelectNotebookPage')); it doesn't crash any more! I know that this problem existed some time ago, but was fixed in the meantime. Could it be that the lastest php-gtk changes did that?
I just noted that "bug_gtknotebook_switchpage.phpw" still crashes - that was definitely fixed.
-- Regards/MfG, Christian Weiske
["signature.asc" (application/pgp-signature)]

email.subject: Re: [PHP-GTK-DEV] Questions
email.body:
Pedro wrote: > Hello > I have a question > > Using PHP-GTK2 i'm trying to build a menu system using the example code > at gtk.php.net for how to use the GtKItemFactory. > Seems that: > > $fac = &new GtkItemFactory( GtkMenuBar::get_type(), '<mainmenu>', > $accelgroup);
I think GtkItemFactory is deprecated in Gtk+ 2. Use GtkUIManager instead for creating menus. (http://developer.gnome.org/doc/API/2.0/gtk/GtkUIManager.html)
-- Scott Mattocks scott@crisscott.com http://www.crisscott.com http://pear.php.net/user/scottmattocks
-- PHP-GTK Development Mailing List (http://gtk.php.net/) To unsubscribe, visit: http://www.php.net/unsub.php
